"First Round First Minute 9b #Margalef

Thanks for bringing back some good memories Mateu. I hope you send this year! üëçüòÄüôèüí™ #Repost @mateusz_haladaj
„Éª„Éª„Éª
When I first came to Margalef in November 2009 I saw @chris_sharma struggling on his hardcore project at Laboratori sector. Dozens of spectators were watching him getting through some savage moves of the lower part to get to the super strenuous upper sequence where he made a desperate throw to a finishing hold. He had to work on the route for 2 seasons to get it done including some 50 falls on that last sequence. The route was named First Round, First Minute and graded solid 9b. 
That year I've been freshly after climbing my first 9a and watching this masterful performance here at Margalef got me super excited. I would never have dreamed to ever get in the same process myself. 
So here I am, after two seasons of falling on that damned slab, the third round on Firs Round starts. Super stoked on what is to come this time... #chrissharma #firstroundfirstminute #margalef #rockclimbing #climbing #9b #climbingpicturesofinstagram #climbingphotography #escaladadeportiva #wspinaniepl"
"#Repost @tenayaclimbing „Éª„Éª„Éª
‚ÄúClimbing is my lifelong journey. And in the same way you go running and you have days where you really feel in tune, you have some days where you don‚Äôt feel that good. It‚Äôs this never-ending process. Accepting that and enjoying that for what it is, that‚Äôs really where the life of climbing is.‚Äù Words: Tenaya athlete @chris_sharma
Photo: @giancolafoto
#makeithappen #tenayaclimbers #climbing"

Very special indeed to climb Le Minimum 8c (first climbed by Marc in 1986) with Marc belaying me.  Grateful for days like these at perfect crags with good friends, trying your hardest! üòÄüôèüôèüôè"

"Chocolate milk & Oreos.
From a few thousand feet up the world looks very different. At times different enough to possibly even change the way you think & feel this planet of ours.
.

Excited to be sharing this body of work all next week through slideshows & my new book during my west coast tour. Monday night in San Diego at @roarksandiego & Tuesday @albumsurf .
Food, Drinks, Fun & best of all.. Free üëåüèº details in bio."
"West Coast Book Tour starts Monday! San Diego, San Clemente, LA, SF, Berkeley, Portland & Seattle - we are coming for you! My co-author @63mph and I will be touring our new book ‚ÄòAt Glaciers End‚Äô with a signing/slideshow/ food/ drinks and general good times! 
For locations & times check out www.ChrisBurkard.com/events or my bio link!
Hope to see you.
.
PS - every photograph in this book is 100% real . No photoshop EVER. üå±"
Even the harshest environments can at times be peaceful, playful and downright pleasant. It‚Äôs these rare slivers of beauty that are so incredibly rewarding to seek out & document. They can feel almost like a gift after being witness to such defeating weather. This moment felt like a distant dream... not a breath of wind, almost surreal. An Aleutian volcano dressed in its spring coating.
"Boulder CO! I‚Äôll be seeing you this Wednesday evening 6-9pm for my first book signing of ‚ÄòAT GLACIERS END‚Äô at @arcticfox_boulder store on Pearl St. Come hang for food, drinks, books & a short slideshow & presentation about my journey to photograph these rivers! ~Free event~
*If you bought online- books are shipping today! Get yours at www.ChrisBurkardshop.com
.

I‚Äôll also be presenting at the @roam Awards on Thursday! See you there."
"Photographic composition is such an awesome form of expression. Walking up to a subject or landscape & finding your own way of interpreting it. For me, the confluence of these two waterfalls felt impossible to leave out. I loved the way they join together in this glacially fed canyon. Although a frame looking straight down the canyon was incredible & probably visually stronger, it was something I had seen many times before. It was still worth taking & being excited about, but I felt drawn to certain details in the image that give you a little greater sense of place & scale. Love seeing how different lenses interpret these landscpapes
.

My biggest print sale of the year is happen now. 30% off all sizes & finishes using code: GIVING30 at checkout. üëâüèº www.ChrisBurkard.com"
"No greater joy as an artist than to see your work on someone‚Äôs wall. This weekend is my largest print sale of the year. 30% all sizes & mediums. 
Use code GIVING30 at checkout on www.ChrisBurkard.com - sale Ends Monday! .

If you decide to gift this holiday season, consider support the arts."
"The view from the Mesa will always be my favorite perspective of Monument Valley. Amazing how a bit of distance, some elevation & a compressed lens changes the landscape (70-200mm). It was a dream to work here with a talented crew on my last commercial assignment.

I currently am having my largest print sale of the year. 30% off all all sizes & mediums... just use the code GIVING30 at checkout. ü§ôwww.ChrisBurkard.com"
"It has been 7 years in the making, documenting Iceland‚Äôs fragile glacial river systems from above. I never envisioned a enviro book being the end goal as it started as just a personal project with the goal of learning more about this threatened landscape. But today is it finally here and im overjoyed to shared my new book ‚ÄòAT GLACIERS END‚Äô a 145 page book with over 8,000 words of text discussing the importance of a national park to protect these rivers. 
The book is available now for pre-order in two hardcover formats. Standard with a slip cover & limited edition with a hard case & small print included. Only 200 signed & numbered limited editions available. We also have included 3 golden tickets into the first preorder copies for a special large custom print. 
Book starts shipping next weeks. To get yours check my bio link or here: https://bit.ly/35AQucP .

A massive thank you to my co author Matt McDonald for his beautiful words @63mph as well as @volcanopilot for the years of friendship. Thanks for the Icelandic ministry of environment for the support as well."
"I‚Äôve been home for just over a day after spending the last 2 weeks in one of my favorite places. Alaska‚Äôs remote Aleutian chain. It also happens to be one of the more remote and challenging places to access. We decided to gamble this time and go late in the season. Most days hovered below freezing with winds gusting up to 50+ knots regularly. I felt prepared for the conditions mentally & physically but it still wrecked my body and my equipment massively. We walked away from the trip with an overwhelming near 30,000 images. 
I‚Äôve found the hardest part of being in this place is leaving... and I don‚Äôt mean because it‚Äôs so beautiful but because the weather get so bad that being stuck there for 2+ weeks with limited food is a common problem. This place is notorious for grounded flights. Half our crew had to wait out the bad weather for 4 extra days and is just finally departing tonight. 
@_ryanhill_ @benweiland @parkercoffin @natezoller @harrisonsan @mikey_rangel @roark @sonyalpha @blackdiamond @gomacro"
If you really wanna get to know a place you gotta see it from a locals perspective. Preferably the four footed kind.
Splash some #BOSSBottled on ya loved ones this holiday season. @boss
"#Repost @kellyslater „Éª„Éª„Éª
#Bill40 is a Honolulu City & County (O ªahu) measure to phase out a wide-range of single-use plastics commonly used in food service (plastic straws, utensils, foam, etc.), over a two year period. While it‚Äôs convenient to have utensils and such when we can‚Äôt access our kitchen at home, the amount of extra garbage created by all of us using single use plastics over the course of a year, decade or lifetime is astounding and not something we can‚Äôt live without. Traveling across this world and to very remote locations, I‚Äôm always blown away at the amount of garbage either in the rivers in Florida, on the beaches of Hawaii, or on an atoll in the middle of the Pacific. At some point soon we need to decide en masse to start undoing this insanely huge mess we have created on earth, and bills like this are small steps in the right direction to help us all change our actions. Please support and call your local representative to voice your thoughts on this being passed in Hawaii. Here‚Äôs to hoping the next generations of kids learn from our mistakes and epiphanies and take the reigns in better directions as the future unfolds. And if you‚Äôre not in Hawaii, think about starting a movement to have this implemented in your hometown and keep @kokuahawaiifoundation, @surfrider, and @sustainablecoastlineshawaii informed on your progress!"

"#ad Actual Patient. Results may vary. For full Product Information for BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic (onabotulinumtoxinA) including Boxed Warning and Medication Guide, see @BotoxCosmeticPI. .

So excited to announce I‚Äôm partnering up with @BotoxCosmetic for BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic Day! üòç I have an exciting surprise for you all! Make sure you check out my stories to see what it is!! I‚Äôve been seeing my doctor to temporarily improve the look of my moderate forehead lines with #BotoxCosmetic, and I‚Äôm excited to share that you all can have this opportunity too! .
BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic is FDA approved to temporarily make moderate to severe frown lines, crow‚Äôs feet, and forehead lines look better in adults. 
Talk to your doctor about BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic and whether it‚Äôs right for you. There are risks with this product - The effects of BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic may spread hours to weeks after injection causing serious symptoms. Alert your doctor right away as difficulty swallowing, speaking, breathing, eye problems or muscle weakness can be a sign of a life-threatening condition. Patients with these conditions before injection are at the highest risk. Side effects may include allergic reactions, neck and injection-site pain, fatigue and headache. Allergic reactions can include rash, welts, asthma symptoms, and dizziness. Don‚Äôt receive BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic if there‚Äôs a skin infection. Tell your doctor your medical history, muscle or nerve conditions (including ALS/Lou Gehrig's disease, myasthenia gravis, or Lambert-Eaton syndrome), and medications, including botulinum toxins, as these may increase the risk of serious side effects. .
BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic is available by prescription only."

I just returned from the NG Exodus Aveiro Fest @ngexodusaveirofest in Portugal. What a fantastic event! I had a blast, such kind, warm people and inspiring talks by Frans Lanting, Daniel Berehulak, Veronique de Vigueries and many more. #LiveForTheStory #canonambassador @canon @natgeo @insidenatgeo
"A Blue-crowned Motmot eats a palm fruit in a secondary forest in central Panama. Motmots eat a wide range of fruits and insects, and are important seed dispersers in this area. Seed dispersal by birds and bats is essential for regeneration of secondary forests on abandoned farmland.

@geomagazin @thephotosociety #SecondaryForest #Conservation #Rainforests #Nature #LiveForTheStory #CanonAmbassador #Wildlife #Panama"
"A bee visits a beautiful Gustavia superba flower in a secondary forest in Panama. Interactions between plants and animals maintain healthy tropical forest ecosystems, where animals are responsible for pollinating more than 95% of tree species, and disperse the seeds of up to 90% of these species. Although Gustavia is common in secondary forests in Panama bees prefer flowers that are high in the canopy and far out of reach, it took me almost a week to get this image waiting for the occasional bees that came down to visit flowers in the understory.
@geomagazin @thephotosociety #SecondaryForest #Conservation #Rainforests #Nature #LiveForTheStory #CanonAmbassador #Wildlife #Panama #Patience"
"An aerial view of regenerating secondary tropical forest along the Chagres river near Gamboa, Panama.  This was taken at the end of the dry season and you can see yellow flowering Guayacan trees and leafless Cuipo trees that drop their leaves during the dry season. This is near our house in Panama. We love living here - it‚Äôs a jungle! The majority of the forest around Gamboa is secondary forest less than 100 years old - I recently photographed a story for GEO magazine about secondary forest regrowth in the tropics‚Ä¶.. I‚Äôll be posting more from that work over the next few weeks. 
@geomagazin #SecondaryForest #Conservation #Rainforests #Nature #LiveForTheStory #CanonAmbassador #Wildlife #Panama"
"A Keel-billed Toucan feeds on palm fruits in central Panama. Toucans are one of the few birds that can disperse plants with large seeds and play a key role in dispersal in forests in Central and South America.  They are especially important in young forests growing on abandoned land, as they bring in seeds of many different species that will help the forest regenerate a diverse tree community. Today is #WorldEnvironmentDay

Although they are frugivores for most of the year, during breeding season they often forage for animals to feed to their chicks. I have seen them with insects, small lizards or most commonly chicks stolen from the nests of other birds!

#Panama #SecondaryForest #LiveForTheStory #CanonAmbassador #conservation #Rainforests #nature #Wildlife @geomagazin"
"The White-bellied heron is the most endangered bird of Bhutan ‚Äì with less the 20 breeding pairs (2018 census). The white-bellied heron depends of large rivers, but many hydroelectric dams now interupt these waterways reducing habitat and foraging grounds.

Photo by @christianziegler , @insidenatgeo supported me with a grant. @natgeo #insidenatgeo #conservation #liveforthestory"
"A Gee's Golden Langur (Trachypithecus geei) in a forest near Tingtibi. This female licks his hands to eat ‚Äòdirt‚Äô with minerals ‚Äì it helps her to digest the leaves.  Photo by @christianziegler , @insidenatgeo supported me with a grant. Together with @jorisvanalphen and @uwicer in #Bhutan.

@natgeo #insidenatgeo #conservation #liveforthestory"
"A pair of rufous-necked hornbills. This is an endangered bird, less then 10.000 are left.

Photo by @christianziegler , @insidenatgeo supported me with a grant. Together with @jorisvanalphen and @uwicer in #Bhutan.

@natgeo #insidenatgeo #conservation #liveforthestory"
"A collection of fruits and seeds from Manas National Park in May.

@natgeo #insidenatgeo #conservation #liveforthestory"
"The black-necked crane is a wintering guest at 3200 meters ! During the summer they are in Tibet above 5000 meters !.They arrive in November and stay until March.

Photo by @christianziegler , @insidenatgeo supported me with a grant. Together with @jorisvanalphen and @uwicer in #Bhutan.

@natgeo #insidenatgeo #conservation #liveforthestory"

I'd like to send my appreciation and gratitude to all those wonderful editors who helped me sharing and spreading my story through these huge media outlets. "[Elusive: A Typical Day of a Seldom Seen Diurnal Predator]

"[A Work in Progress]

Happy Sunday everyone! In the last 3 months, I visited this place several times and took quite a few pictures and here's the first bunch from those shoots. I had multiple cropping options for the first one and I'm still second-guessing my decision (This happens all the time and honestly,  it needs to stopüòÇ). The 2nd one is probably my favorite. Actually, it is going to be a part of a photo-series titled ""Neighborhood"" (which I'm currently working on). 3rd one is not a kind of photo that I would normally share but I liked it a lot, so there you go üòÅ The 4th and the 5th are very similar to the 1st one. They were taken 2 months earlier from slightly different vantage points. I hope you enjoy them all. Let me know which one you like the best. Peace!"

Communication Breakdown
The word "sade" means "simple" in Turkish (Well, it also means "plain") and as you know simple is how I like my pictures :) My initial idea was to crop out the "e" for a more ironic composition (Obviously there's nothing "sad" with this image) but I decided to go with this one simply because it made much more sense :) Let me know what you think in the comments below. "People always ask me: Where inspiration came from? I have some advices that could work for you. üí°üí°
1. Think less, create more! I'm always thinking about new concepts but it is more important to actually create something from those ideas I get.

2. See beyond your eyes üëÄ. Inspiration could happen in just one second, so be prepared to catch it and work hard everyday, otherwise you'll waste that precious instant and it may never come back.

3. Listen carefully to people üëÇ. Inspiration could come from any phrase or random thought you hear from people!

4. Travel more and learn about the cultures you visit ‚úàÔ∏è. But, remember that your own culture might as well give you fresh ideas.

5. Search for inspiration üîé. Start looking for creative people around the world and if you have the opportunity, listen very carefully to the things they say they get inspiration from. For instance, I'll be assisting @72kilos and his workshop, this year at @reinvention_la where he will be speaking about searching for the positive side of the ideas. 
And finally: Create every single day, despite your skills!
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
#Reinvention2019 #Reinvention #Insights"

On the way back over the sea ice from Siorapaluk. It is one of the world's northernmost inhabited settlements and the northernmost settlement inhabited by natives. #Arctic #Greenland #seaice #dogsled
Uummannaq Fjord and the settlement Saattut are one of my favorite places in the world. #Arctic #Greenland @natgeo
Sea ice reflections of the hunters Uunartoq and Albert with local youth Ulla and Innunguaq. #Onthinice #icefishing #Arctic
After the hunt. Uunartoq with his dogs. @natgeo
Global warming has already reached 1¬∞C above the pre-industrial level, due to past and current greenhouse gas emissions. There is overwhelming evidence that this is resulting in profound consequences for ecosystems and people. The ocean is warmer, more acidic and less productive. Melting glaciers and ice sheets are causing sea level rise, and coastal extreme events are becoming more severe. @ipcc Taken on assignment for @smithsonianmagazine in Greenland.
Boat trip in the Ilulissat Icefjord in Greenland. Seeing the glacier so close up was simply breathe taking.  Sermeq Kujalleq or Jakobshavn is one of the fastest (19 m per day) and most active glaciers in the world. It is melting faster than ever before. #Arctic #Greenland #climatechange #glacier #melting #climatechange #climatestrike

Today is World Fertility Day, and I‚Äôm working with my friends at @avawomen to open the discussion and raise awareness about the struggles so many couples face when working to grow their families. Andrew and I learned how trying that experience can be before we were ultimately blessed with our #rainbowbaby, James. All this month, Ava will be shedding light on fertility related topics, and I encourage you to follow along at @avawomen. If you‚Äôre not familiar with Ava, it‚Äôs a bracelet worn while you sleep to monitor your cycle in real time. Timing is everything when you‚Äôre trying to conceive, and Ava really helps take the guesswork out of the equation. Head to avawomen.com and use code CLAIRE for $20 off your bracelet. #AvaPartner #MyFertilityStory #WorldFertilityDay

The opposite of birth control (Part 3)
Here‚Äôs a #fbf for the 7 male followers I have left. Thanks for sticking around!
As I looked on at my adorable little boy this weekend, dressed in his baby blazer and grinning ear to ear, I realized how much my heart and mind have shifted. After he was born, I questioned whether I was cut out to be a mother. I was riddled with anxiety. I had wanted this baby so desperately and yet he brought me to my knees. Every time I put him down to sleep, I was terrified he would suffocate. I lived in fear that I would drop him or fall down the stairs with him in my arms. I worried daily that I would starve him or not give him what he needed to grow. Sometimes I would sit in my car in the driveway and bawl at the thought of going back inside. I felt sick to my stomach as the sun set, knowing that I needed to wake up every few hours and attempt to feed him (another thing I was failing at). On top of all this, I felt immense guilt. I had plenty of support. My wonderful husband, family, and friends were always there to lighten the load. Yet, I felt crippled by an overwhelming sense of failure. I had no idea how to face the next day, week or month. I‚Äôm sharing all of this to say that if you don‚Äôt feel that earth-shattering connection right away, you are not alone. Many of us feel ashamed to open up if we don‚Äôt instantly feel the perfect bonds of motherhood at the moment of birth, but it‚Äôs so important to be honest if you are struggling. I want to thank all the incredible women who were vulnerable and open - like @ellielemons, who inspired me to share this with her own candid post. I look at my son now and am in absolute awe of him. He is my greatest joy. With lots of support and weekly therapy, I was able to address my feelings of anxiety and inadequacy. They resurface every now and then, but I‚Äôm quick to acknowledge them for what they are: fleeting thoughts. I can now honestly say that being James‚Äô mother is the most beautiful thing to ever happen to me.... but I didn‚Äôt feel that way immediately. If you‚Äôre sad, overwhelmed, hopeless or afraid, I promise it gets better. Be open. Ask for help when you need it. And remember that you‚Äôre doing an amazing job. Keep trying ‚ù§Ô∏è

today is world suicide prevention day. the guy you see behind us in the first picture is my friend Jarrid. He was a pastor at a nearby church and was always open about his struggle with depression. He founded an organization dedicated to helping those dealing with depression and suicidal thoughts. He was a good friend to me and hundreds of others. He was an amazing husband to his wife and dad to his two sons. He loved and pointed people to Jesus. Tragically, Jarrid took his own life last night. I‚Äôm at a loss of words and my heart is broken. "Brown Sugar Bourbon Cookie Butter Bars. Still absolutely drooling over these. @HeritageDistillery  @brownsugarbourbon is one of my FAV additions to baked goods. The bourbon brings on a very similar flavor to browned butter, but better! .
.
Grab this easy recipe below: .
.
1 Stick of unsalted, browned butter
1 Cup of cookie butter, divided
3/4 Cup of brown sugar
3/4 Cup of white granulated sugar
2 Large eggs
1 Tablespoons of vanilla extract
2 Tablespoons of brown sugar bourbon 
2 1/2 Cups of all purpose flour
1 1/2 Teaspoon of salt
1/2 Teaspoon of baking powder
1 Teaspoon of cornstarch
.
.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line with parchment paper and grease a 9X9 inch pan.
In a medium bowl whisk together flour, salt, baking powder and cornstarch, set aside.
In another medium bowl whisk together browned butter, ¬Ω cup of cookie butter, brown sugar and white sugar until smooth. Add in egg yolks and bourbon, vanilla extract, whisk once more until smooth.
.
.
With a rubber spatula, gently fold in the flour mixture to the butter/sugar mixture in two increments until well incorporated. Transfer batter into baking pan and into a preheated oven.
.
.
Bake bars for 20-25 minutes or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.Cool for 20-30 minutes before removing from the pan and cutting blondies.
.
.
In a glass dish melt remaining cookie butter in the microwave for 30 second increments or until smooth. Drizzle over cookie butter bars and serve."

"@chris_sharma / Photograph by @giancolafoto  @finelinesdocumentary 
@finelinesdocumentary looks into why people climb. With any activity that embraces danger there is always the question of ‚Äúwhy‚Äù. Why risk your life? While we don‚Äôt know the answer, we do understand the passion for climbing. It runs deep. Dina and her team have brought together 20 climbers and looked into what makes them unique. 
Look up @finelinesdocumentary and find insight from @highsteph @mo.in.mountains @emilyaharrington @hilareenelson @angelika_rainer @_linacolina_ @tommycaldwell @alexhonnold @jimmychin @leo_houlding @xavierdelerue @reinholdmessner_official and @davidlama_official .

Preorder on iTunes. @jralph @hanslmayr 
#climbing #gravity"
"We wouldn‚Äôt be here if not for our parents. They gave us life, nurtured us, raised us and eventually set us free to discover ourselves. üëµüëµüëµ On this day I am especially grateful for my late mother Helga Anna-Johanna Anker. She passed away this past June, quietly at home while enjoying her needle point.  No pain, no burden; an ideal transition. üåù

Born near Dresden, East Germany in 1933 she met my father Wallace Robert in 1955 in Berlin. As a phlebotomist she and her friends went to a social venue that allowed the tables to telephone each other, an old school dating app. Wally rang Helga and loved ensued. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è Having been born into the atrocity of the Third Reich and witnessed the destruction of war, she knew what hardship was. Moving to San Francisco with a young man was her chance at a new life. As an immigrant she reminded us to work hard. As a child of an immigrant I witnessed prejudice towards a woman with an accent. Both of these experiences shaped who I am and my world view. 
In her 86 years she saw joy and happiness through her family. My older sisters Kim and Denise taught me to be kind. My brother Steve was my partner in adventure and minor league sibling pranks. Together the six of us were a happy family. 
The carbon that constituted my parents is now being recycled. Their souls and energy is carried forward by their children and their legacy. Thanks Mom and Dad for believing in me. I‚Äôll always be there for family because of what you instilled in us.

@helga_anker üì∑: 1. Hiking w Mt Fuji in the background. 2. Atop Mt Dana, Tuolumne, County ‚Äò72. 3. Awkward beach photo ‚Äò70. 4. Sophie, Helga and Hugo ~ Torgau (her parents). After the war. 5. Helga. 6. With @jenniloweanker & @stevenanker at Priest Station, our family restaurant. 7. Helga and her sister in law Ilse. 8. With sister Denise at an event. 9. Family Hawaii vacation with @max.lowe @sam_loweanker @kaylabedey @iloweanker (don‚Äôt hesitate to do something big with your parents if you are reading this) 10. My mother finally saw me walk at @universityofutah May ‚Äò17. üêæüêæüêæ‚ÄúThe best theology is probably no theology; just love one another.‚Äù Charles M. Schulz"
"January 1993 : Photograph by Jay Smith 
Although this looks like winter, the image was taken during the austral summer of 1992/ 93. Jay ‚ÄúNo Spray‚Äù Smith, Steve Gerberding and  I had spent a miserable night in bivouac sacs as a humid storm rolled in and quashed our summit bid. We had spent the season trying a direct line on the east Face of Torre Egger in Patagonia. On our summit bid we were shut down by the proverbial ‚Äústeel glove‚Äù of wind and snow. 
We didn‚Äôt have internet based weather forecasts. Or the internet for that matter. Our summit attempt was based on what the Thommen barometer / altimeter was telling us, if the bits of ice in Laguna Torre were blown northward, if we saw a condor circling and if the camp fox walked through the little sand patch next to our tent. The latter two indicators were superstitious. Perhaps the placebo effect instills confidence? Whatever it takes. 
Jay is a survivor. His climbs, all bad to the bone, span the globe. The lessons he shared with me, passed on from the late Jim Bridwell, helped define how I would interpret the mountains. Be calm under pressure, dial one pitch at a time and it could always be worse. Thanks Jay for the years of friendship.

#highandwild #climbing #bivouac #finealpineadventure 
@thenorthface"
"Sunset with son & mother.
@iloweanker & @jenniloweanker 
#family"

"That climbers appreciate vertical terrain is an understatement. We live for it as it brings us joy and happiness. Living in Montana we have the opportunity to challenge gravity on our public lands. The @u.s.forestservice lands are an integral part of this natural playground. 
Hyalite Canyon offers reliable ice climbing year after year. This year, with several cold fronts and a saturated water table, condition are stellar. The ice is in a growth phase and it most plastic.  Doug Chabot (#notonsocialmedia) and I enjoyed two classic mixed climbs, The Thrill Is Gone and Black Magic. Doug works with the US Forest Service with the Avalanche Forecasting team. 
Respect to the @americanalpine & @accessfund for keeping the dialogue open.

Black Magic üì∑ ~ Doug

#publiclands #climbing #finealpineadventure"
"The American Himalayan Foundation @himalayanfdn brings shelter, safety, education, health, and opportunity to people across the Himalaya. 
My life has been influenced by the people of the Himalaya. My first journey 1988 was about mountains. After being humbled by the paucity of air and cold temps, I was welcomed back to  hospitable climes by kind and generous people. For these moments I reflect with gratitude.

Join us on the 7th of November 2019 in San Francisco for the annual dinner as Matthieu Ricard shares his insight into altruism and happiness. Mr Richard is a French writer, photographer, translator and Buddhist monk who resides at Shechen Tennyi Dargyeling Monastery in Nepal. Matthieu Ricard grew up among the personalities and ideas of French intellectual circles. He received a Ph.D. degree in molecular genetics from the Pasteur Institute in 1972. The connection between cultures is a thought process that benefits all.

Please join us. Link in profile.

With kindness and compassion. (Photos courtesy of the @himalayanfdn and background for Mr Ricard from @wikipedia)"
"@kaijonesski and his uncle @jeremyjones breaking camp at the 2019 @protectourwinters summit in Moab, Utah. 
In 2007 Jeremy Jones realized the effect that anthropogenic climate change was having on winters. Specifically, the snow that blankets the northern hemisphere where Jeremy plies his craft as a big mountain snowboarder. Rather than shrug his shoulders and drop in for another run, Jermey turned his motivation and creativity into a voice for winter. 
Thanks to data and science we understand how a changing climate is affecting human existence. The foundation of life - water, food and shelter will be affected by our existence. A hotter planet will disproportionately affect marginalized communities. The burden will be borne by future generations. 
Climate activism asks of its adherents to care about the future of our planet and species. Our generation, the first to be cognizant of climate change, has the opportunity to act and address critical change to ensure that the planet can support humanity for generations to come.

Humans are not perfect. Those of us who live in modernized cultures have evolved to consume tons of carbon. Our lifestyles leave a big footprint. Each of us can work towards a less energy intensive existence, which will help the CO2 conundrum. More significantly, we need to encourage governments to be proactive in addressing this challenge by reducing carbon centric energy and embracing sustainability. 
Live your life through the prism of future generations. How will our actions today affect their existence?"

"I don't usually frequent ""tourist"" attractions when I'm on assignment, but on a recent trip to Kathmandu with a friend, I brought her to experience all the standard touristy things, from lunch in Thamel to the smashans (creation pyres) of Pashupatinath. 
Pictured here are sadhus photographed on assignment for National Geographic at Pashupatinath in Kathmandu.. almost 10 years ago.  A lot has changed since then from the earthquake to continued westernization. 
I think we all battle with change. It's not easy. And the nostalgic feelings we get from remembering our past can get in the way of the promises of tomorrow. Our past can be used as a reminder - a teacher - on what to do or not do. But we are wired to evolve...and it is up to us to choose to transform towards the best version of ourselves.

#culture #travel #transformation #natgeo #onassignement #nepal #portrait #photography"

"Today is World Children's Day and November 20th has seen two important children's rights declarations. In 1959 the UN adopted the ""Declaration of the Rights of the Child"" and in 1989 UN General Assembly adopted the ""Convention on the Rights of the Child.""
.
We all play a role in making today relevant. Today offers us the opportunity to advocate, promote and celebrate children's rights. It is also the opportunity to create dialogue and transform words into actions.
.
So let's start the dialogue: How will you promote children's rights today? Any action, big or small, is important.

2 avocados
Juice of ¬Ω a lime
Pinch of garlic powder
¬º cup of natural soy yogurt 
¬º cup of olive oil

1 teaspoon of smoked paprika
Sea salt to taste
Chili powder to taste

"Below is a repost from @jacquifink about the current bushfire crisis in Australia.  Jacqui has phrased it so clearly and eloquently that I don‚Äôt think I need to add to it other than to say, if you are a knitter or crocheter, please help if you can. Repost from @jacquifink using @RepostRegramApp - Knitters of the World - Australia needs your help. Over 1 million hectares of land have been burning in 300 fires across NSW and Queensland. Much of this is critical Koala Habitat - a species that is now considered ‚Äúfunctionally extinct‚Äù. Populations have been decimated and those who have survived are badly injured. It‚Äôs important to acknowledge that so many other animals have perished in these devastating fires. So too have people and hundreds of homes leaving families with nothing. Our hearts are heavy and so many of us are in a state of bewilderment and anger at the lack of political will to address the broader issues at play here. But that‚Äôs a conversation for another time and platform. Right now, we need to do what we can to make a difference where we can. There has been a call out for knitted, crocheted or sewn Koala mittens and Joey pouches for our beloved kangaroos, and other natives such as possums and wombats, to help in the treatment of burns. Email me for the patterns at hello@littledandelion.com. I have a fantastic PDF I can send you. No DMs please.  I am happy to be the point of collection and you‚Äôll find my postal address in my Bio information. Please show our global leaders what can be achieved when we act as a collective consciousness and show compassion and love for those in need. We are all one. We are all connected. Let‚Äôs be the light for those who have forgotten to see. Please share this post or tag the crafter in your life so that they can help spread the word. Our beautiful precious Aussie wildlife needs your love and care. Many thanks and much love, Jac 
#australia #bushfires #climatechange #climatemergency #knittersofinstagram #crochetersofinstagram #craftivism #activisim #koala #kangaroos #wildlife #injuredwildlife #rescue"
From the most southern part of the Netherlands last week, to Terschelling, the most northern part of the Netherlands.
The American cemetery in Margraten @inlimburg. What an impressive monument to commemorate the American fallen soldiers that helped liberate us. There are 8.301 graves and crosses on 65 acres, just to give you an idea of the scale of this monument.
The South of the Netherlands is just magical, especially in Fall... @inlimburg #inlimburg
When i was in #Aalsmeer recently, we had the opportunity to visit a cactus greenhouse. Never expected to find such beautiful patterns. @visitaalsmeer #visitaalsmeer
After visiting the flower art museum in #Aalsmeer which had the opening for a new exhibition by German photographer Richard Fischer, we biked along the Westereinderplassen to visit a Cactus grower. Had to stop to make use of the misty grey weather. #visitaalsmeer @visitaalsmeer
"The city of Heusden. Straight from a 15th century painting. 
Heusden is village in Noord-Brabant - because of it‚Äôs strategic location on the Maas, it has been destructed and rebuilt numerous times throughout history. The first mention of this city goes back to year 722! 
@ontmoetheusden #ontmoetheusden
@visitbrabant #visitbrabant"

I‚Äôm delighted to spend another weekend in @visitbrabant! Starting in Nuenen, a village where Vincent Van Gogh lived from 1883 till 1885, it‚Äôs pretty amazing to be able to walk in van Gogh‚Äôs footsteps right here in town. #ad

"TRUE LOVE‚†Ä
‚†Ä

I‚Äôve done my fair share of sitting @themarlboroughlodge but Marlborough is a treasure trove of food, wine and scenery waiting to be explored. Taste your way through the famous Marlborough wine region, explore the tranquil waterways of the Marlborough Sounds, or take advantage of the many onsite activities in this oasis of calm. I‚Äôm sad to go but had one of the best experiences ever here. Thanks for the wonderful stay. New Zealand, you‚Äôve been lovely.
I seldom give myself permission to relax and unwind but the idyllic setting @themarlboroughlodge is designed to make you stop and reflect. Surrounded by beautiful flower and vegetable gardens, orchards, and vineyards, the grounds of the lodge are the perfect place for a relaxing stroll between naps.
The Library‚Äîmy favorite room @themarlboroughlodge and perfect for cozying up in a cushy armchair with a good book and a glass of Pinot Noir.

"Earlier this month, I was commissioned to capture images of Jack Daniel‚Äôs Sinatra Select, shot on film. The brand has been part of my history, in a way, as my dad was a Jack Daniel's fan ‚Äî my parents even had an old JD barrel in the front porch of the house where I grew up. In the years since my dad‚Äôs passing, having a glass of this lovely 90-proof (45%) whiskey ‚Äî neat ‚Äî reminds me of when my dad and I would share a drink and catch up about my travels, music, life, and love.
‚†Ä
This Sinatra Select edition is my favorite to date, not least because I‚Äôve spent so many years of my life as a fan of Frank‚Äôs songs, performing many of them on stages around the U.S. This is a whiskey meant to be savored, just as anything that encourages us to slow down and enjoy the moment.
‚†Ä

"These 5 photographs are part of my ongoing body of work on our Atlantic  coastlines; ‚ÄúCome Hell or High Water‚Äù

These time museum quality prints are available for 5 days only for $150....benefits Friends of the Earth ...December 8 -12, 2019.See link in bio.

Print Details:
-Archival Pigment Print -6x9 image size on 8.5x11 paper
-Canson Infinity Rag Photographique.
-Signed en verso in pencil by David Alan Harvey 
FREE SHIPPING in the US, please use code FREESHIP upon checkout. Link in bio.

30% of the profits from this sale will go to @friends_earth and @magnumfoundation .

I grew up living in a beach town. Fell in love with photography in that town. Now I live very near my childhood beach home and it smells just like it here in the outer banks. Pine scents mixed with salt in the air. This is fragile territory. A sand bar. Classified officially as barrier islands moving around every 5 seconds for the last few million years. Add global warming to the natural ebb and flow and things are gonna change. So the outer banks and eastern seaboard in general will be where I will plant my tripod. Come hell or high water. A healthy percentage of  profits from my workshops and print/book sales will go to environmental charity. Seems like a no brainer. See link in bio.#fujix100f #rio #parkour"
Outer Banks. Dec. ‚Äò19. Wind and water will rip this island apart sink it move it re shape erode...barrier islands are literally a different shape every day and that‚Äôs the way it‚Äôs supposed to be. Still we want to slow the process. Save the road save the neighborhood....just for now. Get through one more cat 3 and a few nor‚Äôeasters. I am here for the storms the weather the precarious nature of the place. Temporary. Exhilarating. Not much else to do but take pictures.
WORKSHOP Old San Juan 2020üáµüá∑ This white cat was at my feet as I went to cross. And of course I only looked twice because she/he was white. My strobe was already on and I only prayed the autofocus wd work in the super low light and the white cat would be the only thing to catch my strobe set low.  For 2020 Feb 2-8 we will be producing another Puerto Rico WORKSHOP focused on your personal development. If you check my website you will see the work of my last class Feb ‚Äò19 forever bonded! See link in profile. 10 student limit. If you apply I will do a 30-45 minute FaceTime call and portfolio review with you to make sure we both want to make the investment. It takes a real commitment from thee and me. Workshops can be and should be life changers. My assumption is that you want to move to your next step today. Now. All good things take proper ‚Äúcooking‚Äù but the ingredients can be collected recognized organized. Clarity of thought is step #1. Get that and there are no limits. It‚Äôs just a white cat. See link in profile
Hannah dreaming. Her first baby is expected at Christmas. My lovely talented niece and her life love Tyler are part of the New England wing of my family. @hannahjoanneharvey draws masterpiece pictures of cats, lives cats ,knows cats. Many of my students will remember Hannah on my New York workshop team. While Hannah and I do share a few genes, we‚Äôd for sure be good friends even without a genetic matchup. A new person is coming into the family. So normal so not surprising yet so truly crazy unbelievable. I am finishing shooting for my ‚ÄúOff For A Family Drive‚Äù book and made this last week. Yet clearly there will be one more picture to take! Happy Thanksgiving !!
This morning Nags Head. Sweet spot.
"PUERTO RICO MENTORING WORKSHOP .. February 2-8, 2020. Link in bio.

February is cold as hell where I live so sunny palm trees in the breeze is part of the excuse to head for PR.. yet any of my former students will tell you I‚Äôm about actually moving you forward as a visual author which means I‚Äôm bound to honest critique ... my pitch is easy... forget MY bio.. it‚Äôs YOUR bio we are working on!!! Artist Reba Peck at home in Sugar Hollow. Reba defies any interpretation of style for her artwork that I‚Äôm qualified to make yet her period of coloring over her family snapshots is forever compelling. Reba is the most self effacing artist I‚Äôve ever met. Her life partner and father of their sons Ian and Eli is photographer/producer Michael ‚ÄúNick‚Äù Nichols. So Reba has been surrounded by a whole bunch of photo egos all along. Say that to her and she‚Äôd just chuckle. For Reba knows who she is.. Always has.  She‚Äôs somehow solid and soft simultaneous. Not conflictive yet standing tall. Check out Reba‚Äôs hand colored portraits. You may feel her Alabama roots and maybe you feel there is mystery here that‚Äôs gonna stay mystery ..good.. Dissecting the origins of personal art is guesswork.  The work reveals all that needs be...üéà#rebapeck @michaelnicknichols
Ritual. My brother Gary was one of my earliest photo subjects. He, my sister Patricia, mom and dad , plus assorted pets were my only subjects when I started shooting seriously at 13. I dreamed of being a pro and world travel yet around the house and our street were my real world. So my first hand made book in 1958 ‚ÄúOff For A Family Drive‚Äù is the basis for my next super eclectic book with same title new surprises coming spring 2020. I shot this picture yesterday visiting the New England branch of the Harvey clan. I want the last pictures in the book to be shot right up to press time .  A work in progress a kaleidoscope rather than a retrospective. I hate the thought of a retro. Somebody else can make that for me after I‚Äôm gone. In the meantime I keep shooting. For fun as always. It‚Äôs never been a ‚Äújob‚Äù for me. I knew at 13 I‚Äôd never have a job. Lots is happening with the family wing here in Massachusettes and I‚Äôm shooting it all as I did with the Colorado side of the family just last month. I‚Äôm blessed with a solid family. The other stuff seems irrelevant. Otter will swim through the frigid Atlantic to get that stick and bring it back tail wagging wet cold. Ritual the purest kind. Family.
Virginia cotton field early this morning. Retracing teenage motorcycle trip and last bits of snap shooting for ‚ÄúOff For A Family Drive‚Äù.
Ignacio, Colorado last month. Parking lot at the Southern Ute Tribal Rodeo.  I‚Äôve got strong family ties to Colorado and nearby Durango in particular. So when asked to test the XPro3, it was country roads take me home
"@erinharveypics #repost ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢@magnumphotos 
Both of these photographs just left our solar system on the spacecraft Voyager 2 and were taken by my dad, @davidalanharvey.  His long career continues to soar to new heights, and he has plenty of other shots that he prefers on an artistic level.  But I‚Äôve always thought that having two of his photographs chosen back in 1977 by a team led by Carl Sagan and NASA to represent the planet Earth to extraterrestrials in outer space (!!!) was particularly cool.  The first picture, a father holding his child, was taken as our whole family was on assignment with my dad in Malaysia (the first few weeks of kindergarten would have to wait). And the second picture, geese flying at sunset, was taken in Virginia, near where I live now.  These are two photographs of just over a hundred that were sent on Voyager 1, which already left our solar system in 2012, and Voyager 2, which has now broken free as well - interstellar messages in a bottle.  Both space probes carry my dad‚Äôs images on two specially made golden records along with sounds like crickets and a kiss, Mozart and Chuck Berry.  Hurtling through space for the past 42 years at 36,000 mph, they are now 16.58 light hours from the sun.  It was a Voyager probe that was at the center of the plot for the original ‚ÄúStar Trek: The Motion Picture‚Äù, and it was a Voyager probe that brought the alien Jeff Bridges (the Dude!) to Earth in ‚ÄúStarman‚Äù. Who knows whether the spacecraft and the photos will ever really be found by intelligent life out there, but it‚Äôs fun to dream.  And still as cool to me as it ever was."
We know all walls fall. 30 years ago I was commissioned at the last minute by @natgeo to cover THE FALL OF THE BERLIN WALL. Most of the press had already been there for days. I literally pulled up in a taxi from the airport and paid the driver to watch my gear (for 2 days) as I somehow covered the final moments of the wall. I finally got a hotel then stayed for days to shoot the flow of East Germans and West Berliners back and forth. See my link in profile.#berlinwall @magnumphotos

Today is #WorldAIDSDay and my friend @eltonjohn founded @ejaf 27 years ago to help people living with or at risk of HIV and he continues to shine a light on the HIV epidemic like no one else. His Foundation supports anyone, anywhere in hopes of an AIDS free future. I‚Äôm so proud to be a patron of this Foundation that has saved over 5 million lives and raised awareness of HIV/AIDS with over 100 million people all over the world from Thailand to Mozambique to the US or the UK. I‚Äôve met children living with HIV with @unicef and the 7 Fund in Swaziland and South Africa and I know how important it is that they have the love, care and treatment they need to live a healthy life. Follow @ejaf to learn more about their amazing work this World AIDS Day. X

Icebergs are one of my favorite things to photograph. This is actually a small iceberg called a bergybit and a temporary resting place for chinstrap and gentoo penguins near Danko Island, Antarctic Peninsula. Icebergs are a good metaphor for the sea: only a very small percentage visible to our  human eye. // #iceberg #penguin #moreocean #joy #antarctica // join us in #ParkCity #Utah Dec 14 for Coral Kingdoms and Empires of Ice at the Eccles Center Theater with #NatGeoLive
"Honored that the image ‚ÄúGarden Of Eels‚Äù
 from Dauin Philippines was awarded winner of the underwater category for the Wildlife Photographer of the Year Awards. The image was made on @natgeo assignment using remote cameras to capture these ultra shy creatures that vanish into the sand the moment they detect company. The best way to make an image of these magical creatures is to literally vanish as well. Every picture  is a team collaboration: photographer, guide, boat captain, surface support  and sponsors. Thank you to a great Philippine Team. Through collaboration we achieve. / #WPOTY2019 #Philippines #Ocean #KeepShooting #CollaborationAmplifiesConservation #Gratitude  for #MoreOcean follow @daviddoubilet"
Opal Reef on the Great Barrier Reef. The late largest most iconic coral reef system may be located in Queensland Australia but it really belongs to the world. When I was a kid the Great Barrier was the first reef on my radar of imagination. The worlds largest reef experienced sequential coral bleaching events in 2016 & 2017 affecting more than half of 1400 mile long structure. Thermal stress causes the coral polyp to lose its symbiotic algae that provide color and supplemental nutrients. Unprecedented back to back bleaching have left this great reef with little time to recover and struggling to survive. These images were photographed on assignment with @natgeo // #ocean #coralreef #greatbarrierreef #climatechange #climatesummit2019 #followme for #moreocean follow @daviddoubilet
Waves and wind sculpt a grounded iceberg in Blanley Bay in the Canadian Arctic. Icebergs are a good metaphor for the sea: a large percentage of an iceberg  is normally hidden from our human eye. We discovered a bay filled with grounded icebergs that resembled an Arctic art gallery. Sadly this beauty is too often generated by the rapid retreat of melting glaciers in a warming Arctic. When I can I try to make these types of half and half images because they make a connection between the surface and the secret world below. // with @natgeoexpeditions @natgeo @lindbladexp // #oceans #arctic #icebergs #climatechange #climatesummit #polar #ThisIsEarth #ExploreMore for #MoreOcean follow @daviddoubilet

Searching for a species of fish that has long thought to be extinct, today the U.S. Kazakh & Russian ichthyologists will fish the Keles River on the edge of the Kazakhstan village of Kyzylasker along the Uzbekistan border.
A Luciscus Aspius fish, is placed briefly in a tank by U.S. and Kazakh scientists to be catalogued, before its release back into the Syr River along the Kazakhstan/ Uzbekistan border. On assignment for @insidenatgeo @natgeo.
A Kazakh fish monger‚Äôs table, covered in scales, along a highway on the Kazakhstan/ Uzbekistan border. I‚Äôm here with US and Russian  ichthyologists, searching for a fish long thought to be extinct. On assignment for @insidenatgeo @natgeo
Clothes dry outside the room where we slept in this Uzbekistan / Kazakhstan border village. There were no hotels or guest houses around when we crossed over after dark last night, so Thanks to this generous Kazakh family for their hospitality, warm bedrooms and breakfast. On assignment @natgeo @insidenatgeo
From above, a patch quilt of solar arrays and farm fields near Lancaster, California. On assignment for @natgeo, looking at the future of energy #roadtripto2070
The Navajo Generating Station, the largest coal plant in the western USA, stands on the edge of Page, Arizona in October 2019. The plant, which emits tens of millions of tons of carbon dioxide each year, has been now been shut down by its private owners. It‚Äôs a big win for the planet. It‚Äôs also a major immediate challenge to the Native American communities that have relied on the jobs the plant has created, pointing to the need to support those impacted in the transition away from fossil fuels. Communities like Page, which were feeding the hunger for cheap electricity in far away Phoenix or LA, often lacked electricity for their own residents and suffered from some of the worst air quality in the country. On assignment for @natgeo, looking at the future of energy #roadtripto2070
Classic cars wind around a stretch of Route 66 towards Oatman, Arizona. I followed behind them in my electric car and, when we met, swapped stories about our very different road trips across the USA and wondered what sorts of travel and adventure will be practical or possible in our lifetimes. On assignment for @natgeo looking at the future of energy.  #roadtripto2070
"A view from above Three Mile Island Nuclear Generating Station near Middletown, Pennsylvania.
Four decades after the core of one of the facility‚Äôs reactors partially melted down in 1979, infamous Three Mile Island is officially shutting down.
Crossing the USA on assignment for @natgeo looking at the future of energy.  #roadtripto2070"
Rural Iowa‚Äôs Adair County (where my mom grew up) & my flying camera.  #roadtripto2070

"Despite having completed my final round of chemotherapy the adventure still isn‚Äôt over. Right before this very picture was taken I ate some spoiled pork meat and contracted a tropical parasite. This pesky little worm found its way to my brain and started eating at my visual cortex. It occasionally triggers vivid colour visuals and could lead to epileptic-seizures. ‚Å£
‚Å£
I must admit, that parasite is a fighter, how did it survive over a year with chemotherapy!? Luckily the parasite can easily be exterminated with simple antibiotics. ‚Å£
‚Å£
We fell to discover my malignant brain tumour, and I got the tumour to discover the parasite. This begs the question; what‚Äôs next? ‚Å£
‚Å£
Side notet: this parasite is called Cysticercosis and is the first case in West Norwegain historyü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è"

"I recently finished my 11th out of 12 chemotherapy rounds. It‚Äôs been a vivid and confusing emotional rollercoaster, where I felt a little lost ‚Äì the surgeons removed a golf ball sized tumour in my brain, where my personality was. I used this opportunity to discover new passions, one of them is meditation. After meditating regularly, I realised that pain and suffering is our reset button, similar to the ones on electronic devices. I concluded that it can only get better from now on, until the next tragedy strikes‚Ä¶ -

The lesson is 2/3 of all of us will get a life-threatening disease in our life time, 1/3 of these diseases will be chronic. If you‚Äôre lucky you‚Äôll escape, but this only increases the likelihood of a family member, or someone close to you will get a deadly disease."

"This photo was taken exactly one year ago around the same time when @olegbuller and I took part in the #OrangeTheWorld campaign as a result of Oleg‚Äôs work with the Foreign Ministry. Little did we know that a year later we would actually be working with @UNWOMEN on a global scale to help promote the #OrangeTheWorld campaign via our Foundation @Post.For.Change

This campaign that promotes the empowerment of women in general and stands up against gender-based violence is so close to our hearts that we ask you for your support! The #OrangeTheWorld is a 16 day campaign dedicated to fight gender-based violence by lighting up government buildings, landmarks, and coloring the world Orange, as the color orange symbolizes a brighter future, free of violence.

Violence comes in many shapes and forms. From domestic violence to rape, mental abuse, and legal disparities. We as a global community should not condone, allow or tolerate any form of violence and it needs to stop here! It is 2019 and #timesup.

We urge you to take to your Instagram stories and post about this issue by using our interactive Orange the world filter (which you can find in my profile), as well as the many GIFS that @Unwomen made to make your stories stand out. Small actions can make big impacts to stamp out rape culture and other forms of violence.

Encourage all your friends, colleagues, and family members who believe gender-based violence is wrong and should be eradicated to do the same. I will repost as many as I can so please tag me, tag @post.for.change, tag @unwomen and use the hashtag #OrangeTheWorld !!!"

Last nights Epcot's Candlelight Processional was amazing. For starters we saw guest speaker Whoopi Goldberg. The chorus,the live music, lights even the tree was sybcronized. While free with your Epcot entry this is a event that fills up fast so we went with the dinner package which guarantees us a seat and since @guildagarcia was taking her mom we wanted to be safe.(A event she has been waiting for 14 years) If you saw our stories yesterday  you saw we picked The Garden Grill. There are multiple shows a night which can be combined with various restaurants around Epcot during the day and night so check the My Disney Experience app for options. Both of us agree this is something well worth to do.

Fall is finally here. Just back from a quick assignment in the desert and drove home through the mountains. It was beautiful seeing the colors everywhere.  Love it when the mornings are hovering right around freezing.
Impact Theory: Lots of talk these days about climate change, especially with the climate strike on everyones mind.  With it, for me anyway comes mixed feelings.  To be honest, I think that we‚Äôve become lost in the ‚Äúawareness age‚Äù. Everyone knows about climate change (wether you support the idea or not), but for some reason we still seem to be relying on the government to solve the problem for us when they have consistently shown us that they won‚Äôt.  I believe that it will only be when the sum of individual actions out weigh the results of marginalized legislation that we‚Äôll start to see the improvements that we‚Äôre seeking.  The government has known about climate change since the 70‚Äôs (at least) with the birth of the modern environmental movement‚Ä¶‚Ä¶and it‚Äôs gotten worse not better.  I believe it‚Äôs because we have gotten lost in an ‚Äúawareness vacuum‚Äù. Now we are being taught that liking pictures or using hashtags may actually help somehow.  We have been divided by political parties in the name of power not well being.  Everyone talks about change but either don‚Äôt know what they can do or don‚Äôt care enough to take action.  We are caught in a trap of learned helplessness because we are relying on the government to make it better for us when the reality is only we can save ourselves.  With that I‚Äôll be presenting IMPACT THEORY here on the feed and permanently in my Highlights to give you little ideas on what YOU can do EVERYDAY.  Individual action on a global scale can save us from constant inaction from government or marginalized legislation that can and will change with each new  leadership structure.
"Repost from @thelynxproject So thankful to work with scientists on the ground doing unique and one of a kind research. They are starting to get some tremendous data coming back about the long distance movements of Lynx in the far north. They‚Äôve also been at the forefront of using new ways (social media) to promote, educate and inform the public about their work. Hats off to everyone involved with such a great project. üôå Repost from @thelynxproject using @RepostRegramApp - We capture and collar lynx during the short days and long nights of winter but some of the most interesting things we learn about lynx occur during late spring and throughout the summer and fall months.
.
.
The snowshoe hare population has crashed throughout much of interior Alaska and once the snow began to melt this spring many of our study animals nearly simultaneously began dispersing across much of northwestern North America moving hundreds even more than one thousand miles from where they were captured and collared last winter.
.
.
These cats are swimming across some of the largest rivers on the continent, climbing over massive mountain ranges, visiting the Arctic Ocean and seemingly acting as though nothing can stop them. .
.
There are very real risks to making such incredible movements. Some lynx survive them but others do not.
.
.
Over the course of the next few weeks we‚Äôll describe what we are learning from these truly mind blowing movements, what they may mean, and how what they are showing us can be used to conserve wild places and the many species that depend on these landscapes."

Years ago, one of my first stories was for @thisisflymagazine , about a backcountry fishing trip to the Bahamas.  The images coming from these areas currently are horrific, and the communities there devastated.  The communities that constantly welcome travelers from abroad with open arms can certainly use any help you can give.  Please click the link in my bio to check out a New York Times article on how you can help.
"Repost from @leonardodicaprio using @RepostRegramApp - #Regram #RG @rainforestalliance: 
The lungs of the Earth are in flames. üî• The Brazilian Amazon‚Äîhome to 1 million Indigenous people and 3 million species‚Äîhas been burning for more than two weeks straight. There have been 74,000 fires in the Brazilian Amazon since the beginning of this year‚Äîa staggering 84% increase over the same period last year (National Institute for Space Research, Brazil). Scientists and conservationists attribute the accelerating deforestation to President Jair Bolsonaro, who issued an open invitation to loggers and farmers to clear the land after taking office in January.‚Å£
‚Å£
The largest rainforest in the world is a critical piece of the global climate solution. Without the Amazon, we cannot keep the Earth‚Äôs warming in check. ‚Å£
‚Å£
The Amazon needs more than our prayers. So what can YOU do?‚Å£
‚Å£
‚úî As an emergency response, donate to frontline Amazon groups working to defend the forest. ‚Å£
‚úî Consider becoming a regular supporter of the Rainforest Alliance‚Äôs community forestry initiatives across the world‚Äôs most vulnerable tropical forests, including the Amazon; this approach is by far the most effective defense against deforestation and natural forest fires, but it requires deep, long-term collaboration between the communities and the public and private sectors. ‚úî Stay on top of this story and keep sharing posts, tagging news agencies and influencers. ‚Å£
‚úî Be a conscious consumer, taking care to support companies committed to responsible supply chains.‚Å£ Eliminate or reduce consumption of beef; cattle ranching is one of the primary drivers of Amazon deforestation.
‚úî When election time comes, VOTE for leaders who understand the urgency of our climate crisis and are willing to take bold action‚Äîincluding strong governance and forward-thinking policy.‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #SaveTheAmazon #PrayForAmazonia #AmazonRainforest #ActOnClimate #ForestsResist #ClimateCrisis üì∏: @mohsinkazmitakespictures / Windy.com"

"Photo by Ed Kashi | @edkashi
Shoppers in the fancy district of the Vieux Port in Marseille, France in 2011.

Today while the rest of Europe frets over immigration and its impacts, Marseille, France‚Äôs largest city, has built a peculiar cohesiveness out of diversity and difference. The population of nearly one million is the most ethnically diverse in France: a third claim roots in Italy; there are 80,000 Jews making it the third largest Jewish community in Europe; there are 200,000 Africans of which most are Muslim; it has the second largest Armenian population in France; and there are nearly 70,000 Comorians, as many as the capital of this island nation near Madagascar. This m√©lange of identities has created a distinct sense of belonging and pride though it has not been without its challenges. Still it remains strangely immune to ethnic violence. Once famous as being the hang out of the Mafia and a highway for heroin it is on the verge of becoming a hip destination with its broad beaches, world music and international cuisine. And perhaps even a lesson in tolerance for the rest of Europe. Made on assignment for NGM.

#women #muslim #europe #Marseille #France @viiphoto"

"Photo by Ed Kashi @edkashi/@viiphoto | Agricultural workers harvest black whole grain in the village of Uchapalli, India on Jan. 16, 2016. Thousands of laborers in this part of India are getting sick with #CKDu, chronic kidney disease of undetermined causes. Dehydration and severe heat exposure are believed to be the leading causes of CKDu. Rising temperatures and changing precipitation patterns in southern India are making working conditions for agricultural laborers even more perilous as CKDu wreaks havoc on individuals, families and communities.

#climatechange #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #climate #globalwarming #ECC #chronickidneydisease #healthcare #health #globalepidemic #globalhealth #labor #risingtemps"
"Photo by @williamalbertallard // Stan Kendall at the Miner's Club Bar - Mountain City, Nevada, 1979. This signed print is available until Nov. 25th as part of William's bi-annual flash sale. ‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
In his words, ""The picture of Stan Kendall was made in late afternoon and there was sunlight blasting through the door of the Miner‚Äôs Club and there was lots of red: Stan‚Äôs shirt, the bar‚Äôs curtains, the wainscoting of the bar, and the tops of the bar stools. It was if the entire room was bleeding. Stan is kind of slumped there on the stool, a faraway look on his face. He had what I called back then, that ‚Äúleaving look.‚Äù And he did so the next day, packing up his bedroll and saddle, picking up his pay, and heading to another job on another ranch somewhere down the road.""‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
.‚†Ä
#flashsale #printsale #williamalbertallard #billallard #cowboy #mountaincity #nevada #barscene #filmphotography #colorfilm #fromthearchives"
This image was made today while #onassignment in #Afghanistan @viiphoto @maawad517
"My image was featured in @natgeo's Best Travel Photos of 2019. This image was made at the Taj Mahal, in Agra, India. This had been my third time visiting this monument and it was the most inspiring visit yet. I was walking the perimeter of the structure, trying to avoid crowds and revel in the artistry and craftsmanship but also the spiritual mood of the place. As I was walking, I was also looking for unique angles or moments, given this is one of the most photographed places on earth. I got to this location as part of a @NatGeo Expeditions Tour that I was leading earlier this year. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
#natgeo #nationalgeographic #travel #india #agra #tajmahal #edkashi #expedition #abroad #earlymorninglight #quietmoment #indian #travelphotography #indiabyrail"
"Photo by Ed Kashi | @edkashi

The aftermath of Tavy, or burning of the forest to clear for planting, is illegal but local farmers continue to do this despite the massive reductions of their forests. This tavy is in Manindry Havia. In the distance is one of the few remaining native forests of the region. As the people cut and burn more of their forests, they must go further and further out from their villages to collect wood for their buildings and fires. These images hwere made for the 2010 Prix Pictet Commission, working in cooperation with the United Kingdom based NGO, Azafady, to show issues around land, forests and poverty in this region of Madagascar. The purpose of the images and stories collected here is to illustrate the lack of development and Azafady's efforts to promote sustainable development to improve the lives of the people and how the land is used.  This image was not made on assignment for NGP or NGS.

#madagascar #africa #forests #tavy #landscape"

"[ad] As you might have seen from my stories there is an unmissable festive experience for gin lovers in London - @tanqueraygin have taken over a three-storey house in Bloomsbury where you can relax in a library lounge bar with a delicious cocktail in hand, step into unique sensory experience in a secret bar, discover your flavour profile in the aura room and find personalised Christmas gifts for your family and friends in the gift shop. Open until the 14th December!üç∏üéâüéÑ
#unmistakablytanqueray"
It doesn‚Äôt get more Christmassy than thisüéâ‚ú®
"Thank you so much for all your lovely comments when I shared the first photo of my house. Here is another one with a different angle of the beautiful @snugshack sofa [gifted]. When we did the renovations we decided to paint all the walls white but I‚Äôm now thinking that maybe I should change the colour of the wall behind the sofa? What do you think? 
My Christmas tree is not up yet - I can‚Äôt wait to have it in this room!"
One of my favourite Christmas trees in London, but how is it December already?üéÑ
Finally made to it the gorgeous Woolwich Town Hall, first opened in the early 20th century‚ú®
"Every year around Christmas time (or a little earlier) I head to Piccadilly and St James area for some of the most beautiful Christmas displays. I went past @florislondon so many times but somehow have never been inside before. Did you know that it is the oldest English retailer of fragrance and toiletries and is still family owned and run today by the 8th and 9th generation of the family? 
Last week I had an opportunity to step inside this beautiful shop, to learn about its history (it was founded in 1730!) and to try some of my fragrances. There‚Äôs a little museum at the back of the shop where you can see some of the old bottle designs and other historical artefacts. 
I walked out of the shop with a bottle of Bergamotto di Positano perfume [gifted] that has bergamot, green tea and spices in it and would be equally perfect for both winter and summer. I‚Äôve only been wearing it for a few days but have already received a lot of compliments‚ò∫Ô∏è‚ú®"
"I was meant to be in Italy this week but am at home with a cold insteadüò¢
So I‚Äôm taking some time off to rest and hope to be fit again soon just in time for all the festive activities. Here‚Äôs a photo of a bookstore to cheer me and you up‚ò∫Ô∏è"
Breakfast up in the sky is perhaps my favourite kind of breakfast, and even better when it‚Äôs a festive one with a glass of Champagne. @searcysgherkin is now open for breakfast (just for the holiday period) and I was lucky to be one of the first ones to try it [invite].

"To Rest the Soul

Visiting these woods never fails to leave me breathing easier. üíö
I found this tree 5 years ago with a dear friend of mine, and we photographed this very similar scene - however at the time I was using an old camera that couldn't handle the dark lighting so well, so I've been meaning to re-create this image with better tools for 5 years since. I wasn't expecting to finally get this photo yesterday, but as I was driving past this section of the forest I noticed the fog was rolling through in short waves (it's quite elusive right at this spot!) - so Pepper and I parked down the road and hiked into the woods back to this tree. 5 years of waiting down to this moment - I set up the camera, threw on the dress and waited for the next wave of fog, which conveniently rolled in 10 minutes later. So happy it worked out better than I imagined. üòä
.
. 
Shot on Sony a7R III with 24-70mm f/2.8 GM
#alphacollective #alphafemale #BeAlpha @sonyalpha

P.S.  Offer is still on for any FIVE 8x12 prints of your choice for $150 USD (+free shipping worldwide). These prints normally sell for $75 each, so now's your chance for a whole set of images. Thank you everyone for your support, it means a lot! ‚ù§Ô∏è Link to browse / choose prints is in my profile."
"Hello my friends!
I'd like to let you know about a special little deal on my prints right now - I'm currently offering sets of any FIVE 8x12 prints of your choice, for the discounted price of $150 total (normally selling on my website for $75 each). Free shipping worldwide is included. üòä Ahhh! The catch is, if you want them by Christmas, they must be ordered by this weekend... So if anyone happens to be interested, you can browse / choose your favourite prints from my website! The link is in my profile. üòä
I can't thank you all enough for your support no matter how you choose to show it (through prints, messages, comments, etc.) - every bit of love is so encouraging lately, and I'm endlessly grateful to everyone following along here as I continue to share my art. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ò∫Ô∏è So much love to you all this coming holiday season!!!"
"Life has a funny way of being unlike anything you imagine it will be.

After years of dreaming, this year I was finally able to visit my #1 bucket list location - Tombstone Territorial Park.  I was able to reserve permits months in advance, and when August came I drove 45+ hours north into Yukon territory, joined by two of my best friends, ready to hike into the backcountry to spend a week basking in the awe-inspiring, towering presence of the Tombstones and creating a new series of personal photos.

This ended up being the only photo I got. On the second day we were overtaken by a whiteout blizzard, and as we were crossing a boulder field, only half a km from our next tentsite, one of my friends slipped and fell head first several feet down into the sharp boulders, splitting his head open.  Looking back gives me chills to imagine how our situation could have ended much worse - to make a long story short, our radio wouldn't turn on (even though it was fully charged the previous day) and it was immediately apparent we didn't have enough supplies for the medical attention needed. Somehow the adrenaline carried us calmly through - I ran ahead to the tentsite and found a team of park rangers (who were only in the backcountry to re-build part of the trail, thank goodness for their timing!), and with their help we were able to get a helicopter evacuation 3 hours later (major props to the pilot for flying in a blizzard as night fell - apparently the only reason he did was because he had just practiced landing there the night before to prepare for emergencies). We got so lucky in what was an unlucky situation. And yes, 3 months later my friend is still recovering and doing well. üòä

People keep asking if I'm disappointed this dream trip didn't go according to plan - The weird thing is, I'm not. Not in the least.  I've seen up close the dark possibilities of what could have been, with people I care about deeply, and I've come away with a heightened sense of gratitude and much deeper respect. And a reason to someday return and finish what we started. üß°"
"Here silence speaks
Leaving words rendered useless
So be still, my tongue

For the month of November I set myself a little personal challenge of writing one or two haikus with my morning coffee every day... And I've fallen in love with the routine! It surprises me how creating something so short, sweet and simple each morning can really help get my creative brain rolling with inspiration and ideas - and then even if no ideas come to further fruition, I'm at least left with something I created each day that leaves me feeling rewarded. üòä
And I've realized that sometimes it's our smallest creative expressions that can say the most. üß°"
"""We must risk delight. We must have
the stubbornness to accept our gladness in the ruthless
furnace of this world.""
- wise words from Jack Gilbert I read this morning.

These last 6 months have been a whirlwind of travels and happenings that have chewed me up and spit me out exhausted, elated, broke, more introspective, thankful, alive, and greatly looking forward to the future. I spent much of this time neglecting emails, messages, social media and basically all the online world -  sorry guys, living really takes it outta me. üòÖ

But now, I'm finally at home again for more than a 3-day stint between travels. I'm finally making time for myself. My introverted spirit is withdrawing into my own quiet, creative world for the rest of November and December.  And I'm so excited to catch up and share it with you all. üòä ‚ù§Ô∏è"
üíï

"Into the golden sunrise.
Forever one of my favourite backcountry moments (and 4 years ago already?!), waking up to this fresh winter wonderland encompassed by fog, only to be split by the rising sun, revealing our surroundings for the first time in two days. üß°"
7 year throwback, and to this day still endlessly captivated by these misty mountains of home. üòçüíô

"LOWER BODY & SHOULDERS üí™üçë
.
Three movements using just a pair of dumbbells, and you have yourself a sweaty sesh in under 30 minutes. .
Here‚Äôs how I did this one: .
1. Punches x10 + squat x3 - repeat for 90 seconds. 
2. Lunge x2 + lateral raise x2 - repeat for 90 seconds.
3. Lateral step x4 + overhead press x4 - repeat for 90 seconds. .
Rest for 60 seconds between each movement, and repeat all 2-3 more times üëèüî•"
"Throwback to when I could jump around without vomiting üòÇüëèüôÑ
.

CARDIO LEGS üíÄüí¶ AT HOME!
.

This one is a COMPLETE WORKOUT to torch your legs and make you sweat like crazy. Word of warning; lots of jumping and your heart is going to be pumping! 
Perform these in intervals, with equal work to rest.
.
TOP TIP: remove the jump from all exercisesfor a much more low impact or preggo version! .

1. 40s on 40s off x4
2. 30s per leg with 60s off x3
3. 40s on 40s off x4
4. 30s on 30s off x3 .

Note: this is NOT how I‚Äôm training right now! This body is taking things a lot more easy as it grows, so I‚Äôve been mainly walking, doing body weight low impact movements and doing lighter weights in the gym. .

Filming fresh videos tomorrow, yay! Oh, and I‚Äôll be sporting a new accessory.... ü§∞üôäüòõ"

"FULL BODY TIME!! ü§úü§õ
.
Grab some hand weights and let‚Äôs get moving! .
TOP TIP: All of these movements are very compound, meaning they use multiple muscle groups. Control every rep and squeeze every muscle! You‚Äôll get a lot more out of this if you think about what you‚Äôre doing and actually USE those muscles! üëçüî•
.

1. 60 seconds on / 60 seconds off x4 sets 
2. 60 seconds on / 60 seconds off x4 sets 
3. 45 seconds on / 45 seconds off x4 sets
4. 30 seconds per leg / 60 seconds off x3 sets
.
Custom workout plans available at FITWITHEL.COM üëä"

.

"STRENGTHEN YOUR CORE üëèüî•
.

"LEGS AND GLUTES üçëüí™
.
This one can be done from HOME OR GYM depending on what you need!

.

.
1. Hip Thrusts (use a couch or chair from home) x15
2. Split squats x12 per leg 
3. Courtsey Leg lift x12 per leg 
4. Straight leg glute kicks x20 per leg

Repeat each x3-4 times! Remember to keep your core braced and BREATHE! ‚ò∫Ô∏è
.

.

"We spent the final 2 nights of our month long honeymoon at the most beautiful place, @bambuindah .
Nestled in the jungle just outside the hustle of Ubud, Bali, this slice of heaven welcomed us with stellar service, and the most enchanted view.
-
With sustainability and organic design at the heart of their mission, every detail was considered. It was a playful and delightful place to soak up the final two nights in Bali together. For our one month wedding anniversary, which falls on the new moon, we designed a flower pool to represent our wedding. The mandala in the center represented the mandala of flowers that @bestdayeverfloraldesign designed for us for our ceremony, and the double rainbow that appeared right after our vows. The feeling of the flowers on my skin was so delightful, it fulfilled a childlike fantasy. üå∏ and sharing it with my love, my husband, as he recounted his experience praying with a local priest, brought tears to my eyes and cracked my heart wide open. #porterkatzhoneymoon photos by @goldenruledesign

"Do you always find an excuse as to why you can‚Äôt do something? Excuses will always be there ready to be found.
There will always be people who have it ‚Äúeasier‚Äù than you & on the contrary there will always be people who have it ‚Äúharder‚Äù. We all have our own battles in life - mentally, physically & externally. We all have different priorities, tastes & opinions...
