Comparison is the thief of joy! üòò

I‚Äôm proud of myself & what I‚Äôve achieved in life (I have a hard time being proud of myself but I‚Äôm learning üòâ). I have fought many of my own battles & I‚Äôm currently trying to get my gut health better. I have parasites, SIBO, leaky gut, some nutrient deficiencies & a slow thyroid. - all of this doesn‚Äôt help with my training, mental health & energy BUT I do the best I can. I have body fat & cellulite that won‚Äôt budge & back in the day that would have really got to me but my priorities have changed the older I get & since becoming a mum. Plus I‚Äôm blown away by how strong I am now - physically AND mentally. üí™üèº
.
I know there are millions of people who have it ‚Äúharder‚Äù & have more struggles than me & there are people who have it ‚Äúeasier‚Äù but none of that makes a difference to my journey & my life so I try not to think about that & just focus on getting better, healthier & stronger and being the absolute best I can be. üòäüëäüèº

"I KNOW WHAT HAS BEEN CAUSING MY GUT BLOATING/PAIN! - sorry I felt the need to write that in bold! üòù Haha!
In case you didn‚Äôt see my story, I have parasites & SIBO (Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth) & also have been sick from being run down. It‚Äôs a great feeling to know I‚Äôm on the right track to getting my gut healthy again. It may take a long time though (could take a year or so) which is hard since I am a bit impatient, especially about my health. üôà I‚Äôm working on getting rid of the parasites & balancing my good & bad bacteria in my belly. Did you know that you can even have too much of a ‚Äúgood‚Äù strain of bacteria!! I have way too much of the Lactobacillus strains! So I‚Äôve switched my probiotics to one without them! It‚Äôs funny but I‚Äôm so in tune with my body that I had a feeling that was the case! It‚Äôs so good to know for sure. ‚ò∫Ô∏è Your gut microbiota is the name given to the microbe population living in our intestine (we used to call it gut flora).
It consists of trillions of microorganisms and their genetic material that live in our intestinal tract mainly comprising bacteria - or what we commonly refer to as ‚Äúgood & bad bacteria‚Äù. Our microbiome is like an ecosystem which needs diversity. Having good quality probiotics will help ensure you have a diverse blend of the right strains of bacteria so you can have a happy & healthy gut & feel happier & healthier all over.¬†When a specific species in your gut ecosystem are missing your entire system is compromised. That‚Äôs why I believe in changing up your probiotics!
An imbalance of gut bacteria can affect almost everything in your body - even your mood & mental health!

Anyway I could go on and on about this as I find it all so interesting. 
I want to do a podcast episode on ‚Äúgut health‚Äù with a gut health specialist! Would you be interested? .
#guthealth #microbiota #microbiome #gutbacteria #gutbloating #bloating #tummybloat #bloatedbelly #beatthebloat #gutproblems #probiotics #parasites #sibo"

Saka & Mama üñ§
Weekend well spent. @liverpoolfc are 8 points clear, life‚Äôs good. Bring on Monday ü§ôüèº
As the days of this decade count down, can we collectively ask, ‚ÄúWhere did time go?‚Äù Those endless summer days of childhood seemed to last forever, yet the older we grow, the busier we become and the quicker the days, weeks, and months seem to fly by. Time is a constant, but our perception of time evolves with age. Why does it seem to pass so quickly for many of us as we get older? More importantly, how do you come to this realization and take steps to become more present and slow it down? One thing that‚Äôs motivated me is thinking of life on a timeline. When you‚Äôre young, traveling and seeing the world isn‚Äôt realistic and when you‚Äôre old, it‚Äôs just not quite the same. We all have a window of our lives to push boundaries, test your limits, and start checking boxes off your bucket list. This past decade was full of self-discovery, challenges, love, and some moments I‚Äôll never forget with friends and family. Can‚Äôt wait to see what the future brings.
It‚Äôs funny how a few nights can alter the course of your life. I remember when I was starting to get into photography, I‚Äôd run to the edge of these cliffs after work almost every day. I grew up in San Diego, but I didn‚Äôt really discover this spot until after college and it always felt so different than every other coastal lookout. It had sweeping views to the south and north, hang gliders soaring through the sky, and surfers running up and down the edges of the cliffs trying to get to one of the best waves in California. I remember that rush each and every day, driving and trying to make sunset, not knowing what it was going to look like of what I could capture. I was hooked. That feeling was the push I needed to change careers and chase that feeling I loved.
I‚Äôve always felt lost with a paintbrush but on nights like tonight, Mother Nature is the best artist anyway.¬†The clouds lit up like brushstrokes, the colors were radiant, and the ocean carried the golden light across each cascading wave.¬†A camera has always been my form of art. Something about thinking through the numbers, settings, and improvising in a fleeting moment has always come across as a challenge. Even though I‚Äôm far removed from my engineering past, it‚Äôs the one time where I feel like world‚Äôs collide and that gives me a unique approach. It‚Äôs a nice reminder to chase things you love and appreciate where your journey has led. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you study one thing yet fall into another path, your journey is what makes you unique and an unmatchable force. Never forget that. Your highs, lows, struggles, triumphs, and everything in between give you something that no one else can match, being you.
This. Morning. Was. Unreal. I rolled over in bed about an hour before sunrise, saw some crazy clouds and thought there might be a chance it would be half this beautiful. Honestly, most the time I go out for sunrise I come home with nothing more than a cup of coffee and a bit let down that I rolled out of bed that early. Mornings like this make up for all the other ones and also make me more appreciative of every day, regardless of the sunrise. Not every morning is gonna light up like this, but each day is a chance to spend with loved ones and work on making yourself the best version of you. That‚Äôs the best treasure of them all üî•
Thankful. For a life of discovering. Most importantly, for a life full of special moments with friends and family. You discover a lot about yourself when you‚Äôre young. You make mistakes. Maybe you pick a career path that might not lead where you expected. You second guess yourself often. Over time though, you start discovering who your true friends are. Maybe they‚Äôve been around since the start, or maybe you find them later in life. Regardless, at some point you realize time is precious and it needs to be spent on those who deserve it. As I‚Äôve gotten older, the one thing I‚Äôve learned most is the memories that stand out aren‚Äôt the experiences I‚Äôve had alone. In the moment they may seem vivid, but their impact fades over time. My favorite memories in life are ones I get to experience with others. Honestly, at the end of the day that‚Äôs all that matters. It‚Äôs being able to look back and laugh at a trip or talk about that one meal that was the best you ever shared. So on this day, I‚Äôm thankful for @kayrubes1, @grahamrubens, and for pictures like these. Because each of these represents a moment shared and a trip I‚Äôll always look back on fondly ‚ô•Ô∏è
Exploring the crystal blue sea caves along the Adriatic coast. It‚Äôs overwhelming planning a vacation with so many beautiful places in this world. I didn‚Äôt even know places like this existed when I was growing up üòÇ Croatia, South Africa, Jordan, French Polynesia...honestly you can‚Äôt go wrong with any choice. Whats the top spot on your bucket list??
"My story starts off the same as many others. I was a kid with a dream of being a professional athlete. I played tennis for almost 20 years, literally until the day I realized I wasn‚Äôt good enough to make it on the pro tour. I always had doubts in the back of my head though, which was the main reason why I studied engineering while playing college sports. Having a back up plan was something I was always taught. As valuable as that ended up being, I sometimes wonder if that was the reason I didn‚Äôt make it. I think having no back up plan can be the spark that ignites a drive beyond what you think you‚Äôre capable of. 
As I began my engineering career, I was once again drawn towards learning things outside my career path. Whether it was finance, entrepreneurship, or creative tasks, it seemed like I was falling into the same pattern. My current chapter is where most of you likely crossed paths with me. Photos, videos, travel, and this whole path Instagram has paved is my present journey, but I can‚Äôt stop the burning desire to pursue things outside of the platform. Maybe it‚Äôll slow down one day and I‚Äôll find my one true calling. For now though, it‚Äôs full speed ahead hitching this ride into the sunset and catching ever detour along the way üòé"
Back in the Middle East, learning about the history of Diriyah Gate and eating as many dates as possible üòç I‚Äôve visited quite a few UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and you can‚Äôt help but appreciate each one‚Äôs uniqueness, history and cultural importance. Being able to attend the #diriyahroyalinauguration is always an honor and the desert landscapes never fail to captivate the imagination. @dgda_sa #dgda
I‚Äôve watched many sunrises in my life, but the view overlooking Guanabara Bay at Mirante Dona Marta has to be one of the most fascinating. It‚Äôs the perfect blend between nature and city, as @kayrubes1 and I watched the twinkle of the lights in the favela below fade off and the mountains catch their first light. What an inspiring spot to start the day on any trip to Rio de Janeiro! I‚Äôve been to Brazil twice these past 12 months and can‚Äôt wait to start getting to other spots of the country üáßüá∑
Some places are beyond words and trying to describe the magic of Iguazu Falls just doesn‚Äôt do this wonder of the world justice. It‚Äôs captivating, powerful, inspiring, and hard to capture the sheer scale and beauty in pictures (but sure fun to try!) Swipe through to the last video to try to count the waterfalls and rainbows that seemingly never end üåà

There's one place that's different, though, and has always felt like a home-away-from-home since the beginning. @Villa_sancta_maria is my special little slice of heaven, perched atop a hilltop in western Croatia, and it's where I close my eyes and imagine myself whenever I'm stressed or overwhelmed. üïä
.
This beautiful old stone farmhouse has seen so many incredible women pass through it over the past 5 years of hosting retreats there. So many different conversations gathered around @tournantpdx's fire in the hearth of the kitchen, stomachs full with their delicious food, laughter echoing through the living room. üçá
.
From sitting by the pool soaking up the view, to relaxing on the balcony with some local Istrian wine, there's no place I'd rather be at any given moment. The house just has this warm welcoming feeling that instantly puts me at ease...it feels like an emotional hug right when you walk through the door. üíö
.

"Today I want to focus on one my favorite world heritage sites: The V√∂lklingen Ironworks in Saarland, Germany. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
The site is a decommissioned ironworks which was in operation from 1881 to 1986. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
This site is really impressive. It is right out of central casting for how an old factory should look and feel. It looks like something out of the last scene of Robocop. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
Supposedly, it was declared a World Heritage Site because it was cheaper to make it a world heritage site than it was to tear it down. It is good that they didn‚Äôt tear it down, because there are so few facilities like there where you can get a real visceral feel for what late 19th and early 20th century ironworking was like.‚Ä®‚†Ä‚†Ä‚Ä®The V√∂lklingen Ironworks was the very first industrial world heritage site.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The area around it is still used to create iron and steel. I saw railcars carrying molten iron from one facility to another while I was there.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
If you are at all interested in industrial history, I‚Äôd HIGHLY recommend a visit. It is a fascinating place and there are few other environments like in the world. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #unesco #visitgermany #germanytourism #worldheritage #unescoworldheritage #worldheritagesite #v√∂lklingen"
"I‚Äôm going to feature something this week which might not be that popular, but something I think is both important and interesting.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Industrial History.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
We people visit historic sites, they are usually visiting ancient ruins, cathedrals or temples, or city centers that are several hundred years old. All of those are fine things and I‚Äôve certainly visited my fair share of them.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
One thing I always like visiting are the overlooked sites which help us understand how our modern world came about. Everything isn‚Äôt churches and museums. Ore had to be mined and processed to make metals. Techniques had to be developed to create machines. Roads and railways had to be laid down.‚Ä®‚†Ä‚†Ä‚Ä®One reason people don‚Äôt visit these places is because they usually aren‚Äôt preserved. Few people thought to preserve a factory from the 19th or early 20th century. That isn‚Äôt old enough to be ‚Äúhistory‚Äù.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The first site I‚Äôm going to feature is the copper mine in Falun, Sweden. The mine operated for almost 1,000 years, only ceasing production in 1992.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
In the 17th century, the mine was responsible for the vast majority of copper in Europe, and was the single biggest revenue source for the Kingdom of Sweden.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Working in the mine hundreds of years ago was horrific. Large fires were lit inside to crack the rock so it could be extracted. Miners would often go months without seeing daylight. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
The mine tour is fascinating and gives you a look into how mining was conducted centuries ago. The area around the mine was originally built for mine workers, but today it is just regular housing for people in the city. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #unesco #sweden #worldheritage #unescoworldheritage #worldheritagesite #falun"
"Today I‚Äôm heading back to North America to talk about another park which few people are aware of. It has been called the Galapagos of North America, and it is one of the most wild, unique ecosystems on the planet.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Gwaii Haanas National Park.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Gwaii Haanas is the southern third of the Haida Gwaii Islands (aka the Queen Charlotte Islands) off the coast of British Columbia. (The last image shows where the park is on a map.)
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The park can only be visited by boat or by float plane. There no roads to the park, and it wouldn‚Äôt really even be possible given that the park is a collection of islands.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
In the park you will see sea lions and sea otters, as well as black bears, deer, and lion jellyfish. The landscape is also stunning with mountains meeting the sea.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
As amazing as the natural beauty of the park is, the cultural significance of the park might even be greater.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The park has several Haida villages which were abandoned in the early 20th Century during an outbreak of smallpox. The sites of the villages have been allowed to return to nature, and most of them are now just hollowed out sections of forests, with some potlatch poles.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The most significant village is SGÃ±ang Gwaay, which has the last, original standing pre-European totem poles in the world. The Haida people believe that totem poles have a life like people, so they are being allowed to decay naturally. They clear brush around the poles, but other than that they are being allowed to decay.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Given the cold waters of the area, even if you visit in the middle of the summer, the boat trips to the park can be quite cold.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The launching point for visiting the park are the towns of Masset and Port Clements, and the airport on the island is Sandspit (YZP).
‚†Ä‚†Ä
#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #hellobc #explorebc #parkscanada #explorecanada #unescoworldheritage #unesco #worldheritage #worldheritagesite"
"I‚Äôm sure everyone who is reading this is familiar with Uluru, aka Ayer‚Äôs Rock, in Australia.
‚†Ä
What you might not know is that the official name of the park it is located in is Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park.
‚Ä®So what is with the Kata Tjuta part? That is focus on today‚Äôs post. 
There are actually TWO massive rocks out in the middle of the Australian outback. Uluru I‚Äôm not going to focus on too much because it is well known. The other is called Kata Tjuta. (To be technical, Kata Tjuta isn‚Äôt one rock. It is a collection of them.) The two rocks are not far apart from each other. Kata Tjuta is visible from Uluru and vice versa. Unlike Uluru, it isn‚Äôt quite one massive rock. It has large cracks and crevices that you can walk in.

The highest point of Kata Tjuta is actually higher than Uluru. 
Most visitors to the park visit Uluru and nothing else. The number of people who take the time to visit Kata Tjuta is significantly less than the number that go to Uluru. During my first trip to the park in 2008 we didn‚Äôt visit Kata Tjuta and no one even mentioned it.

On my second trip there in 2013, we visited during one of our days and it was a great experience, with very few people. Uluru can be incredibly crowded at sunrise and sunset, where as Kata Tjuta is pretty much empty.

If you are going to travel all the way to the middle of Australia, you owe it to yourself to see both parts of the park. 
FYI, the last image in this set is a public domain photo taken from the International Space Station in 2010. I added it just do you can get a better idea of what the area is like. 
#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #australia #KataTjuta #uluru #unesco #worldheritage #woldheritagesites #unescoworldheritage"
"My overlooked destination today is found in Japan. One of the reason few people outside of Japan know about it is that it is well off the typical tourist route. You can‚Äôt get there by train, and in fact it isn‚Äôt even connected to the main four islands in Japan. It is a place ‚†Ä
I‚Äôm am talking about Yakushima. ‚†Ä
Yakushima is an island about 140km (80mi) south of Kagoshima, Japan, which is the southernmost major city in the main Japanese island group.
‚†Ä
What makes Yakushima so special? The center of the island, on the top of the volcanic peak, is an old growth cedar forest. Due to its island location, there is no recorded history of logging ever in this part of the island. The elevation on the mountain means it is often in the clouds, and all of the trees are surrounded by mist.
‚†Ä
The forests are stunningly beautiful. The only other place I‚Äôve found similar to this would be Olympic National Park in Washington State, or some coastal areas of British Columbia. ‚†Ä‚Ä®When I visited Yakushima back in 2007, I did not encounter another non-Japanese person during my entire visit. In fact, despite not a single person at my hotel on the island knowing English, I had one of the best meals in my life in Yakushima. ‚†Ä
The island was the inspiration for Hayao Miyazaki's animated film Princess Mononoke.
‚†Ä
Most people who visit Japan have a set list of sites they visit which include Kyoto, Nara, Tokyo, and some places in-between. They might go a bit beyond this, but most visitors aren‚Äôt going to go further south than Fukuoka. ‚†Ä
You can get to Yakushima via direct flights from Osaka or Fukuoka, or you can take the ferry from Kagoshima which takes about 2-3 hours. There are also car ferries which go to Yakushima as well if you are driving.
‚†Ä
While on the island, you can get around via rental car (what I did) or via bus, which will take you to the major forest groves on the island.
‚†Ä
Yakushima was the highlight of my time in Japan, and a place which few people I have met since have visited or even heard of.
‚†Ä
#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #Japan #yakushima #unesco #worldheritage #worldheritagesite #unescoworldheritage"
"I was thinking of which lesser known destinations to feature. The truth is, there are a LOT of them. The planet is littered with amazing places few people bother to visit.

This week I really want to feature places that evoke a response of ‚ÄúWHY DIDN‚ÄôT I KNOW ABOUT THIS??‚Äù One of those places is again in Italy. Most of the attractions in Italy either date back to the Roman period, or to the Renaissance. This place dates back to the 18th Century, which isn‚Äôt one of the best known periods in Italian history.

Back then, most royals in Europe had Versailles envy. The palace of the King of France was the standard by which palaces were judged. Many other monarchs created palaces which emulated Versailles. Sch√∂nbrunn Palace in Vienna is probably one of the best examples of this.

The King of Naples didn‚Äôt want to be outdone, so they created the Italian version of Versailles. 
The Royal Palace of Caserta.

When I visited, I was on a group tour of Italy, and only one other person on the tour bothered to come with me. When I got there, there were almost no non-Italian tourists.

In terms of total volume, it is the largest royal palace in the world.  The palace is five stories tall, has over 1,200 rooms, and has over 1,700 windows. 
The gardens are what is really amazing. There is an aqueduct running through the garden which is a total of 38km long! From the back of the palace it extends out to the horizon.

Getting to Caseata is actually really easy. The train station is literally outside the palace.

#everythingeverywhere #curiositynow #italy #caserta #unesco #unescoworldheritage #worldheritage #worldheritagesite"
"Today I want to feature a place which most of you have probably heard of, but I‚Äôm guessing only a few of you have actually visited.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Unlike yesterday‚Äôs destination, this one is very easy to reach, however, it happens to be overshadowed by a much more popular neighbor, Venice.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
I‚Äôm talking about the city of Padua (or Padova in Italian).
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Padua is only a 20 minute train ride from Venice. Of the 20,000,000 people who visit Venice every year, only a small faction ever bother to make the short trip to Padua. The cost of a ticket from Venice to Padua can be had for as little as ‚Ç¨3.55 ($4), and trains leave at least once or twice and hour all day long.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Why take the time to visit Padua?
‚†Ä‚†Ä
1. Padua has the largest city square in Europe. The Prato della Valle is a 90,000¬†m2¬†square in the shape of an oval, which is surrounded by 78 statues of famous citizens. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
2. It has the world‚Äôs oldest botanical garden. The Orto Botanico di Padova was found in 1545 and today is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The garden is small by today‚Äôs standards, but it is open to the public. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
3. One of the finest decorated churches in Europe. The Scrovegni Chapel has an interior which is covered in frescos by the artist Giotto. Completed in 1305, the number of visitors allowed to enter daily is limited. Visitors must first enter a climate controlled, airlock room to prevent temperature fluctuations in the church. During the temperature acclamation period, you watch a video about the history of the church. Make sure to book your tickets in advance.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
4. One of the most significant churches in Italy. The Basilica of Saint Anthony of Padua is the resting place of the saint, and is one of only eight national shrines in the world recognized by the Vatican.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
5. One of the best Astronomical clocks in Europe. You might be familiar with the famous clock in Prague. Pauda has one of their own in the Piazza dei Signori.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
6. One of the oldest universities in the world. The University of Padua is the 5th oldest surviving university in the world. Noted faculty have included Galileo and noted alumni include Copernicus.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Yes, Venice is very beautiful, but it is also extremely crowded. Try Padua"
"This week I want to do the exact opposite of what I did last week. Last week I focused on popular tourist destinations around the world. This week I want to focus on lesser known places that most people aren‚Äôt aware of.
‚†Ä
I want to start with a place which I‚Äôve featured on Instagram before, but I don‚Äôt know if many people are really aware of just how amazing this place is.
‚†Ä
That place is Nahanni National Park.‚Ä®‚†Ä‚Ä®Nahanni might be the greatest national park in the world. Please re-read the last sentence again. I don‚Äôt make that claim lightly as I‚Äôve been to many parks all over the world.
‚†Ä
Despite being one of the world‚Äôs greatest national parks, it gets very few visitors. In an average year fewer than 1,000 people will enter the park. Most Canadians I‚Äôve spoken with have never heard of the park.
‚†Ä
The lack of visitors and awareness of the park is mostly due to its location. It is in the Northwest Territories of Canada and there are no roads connecting the park to the rest of the world. The only way to visit is via float plane or to hike in. It also has a very short season for visitors given its location. It is accessible for only about 3 months per year.
‚†Ä
The park is the location of one of the largest waterfalls in the world; Virginia Falls. The World Waterfall Database lists it as the 7th highest rated waterfall in the world!
‚†Ä
But wait, there‚Äôs more!
‚†Ä
There park is so much more than just a big waterfall. It has canyons, specular mountains, a huge river, and tons of wildlife. Its remoteness means that if you visit, you get an experience which is totally different than what you will have if you go to Banff, Yosemite, or Yellowstone. ‚†Ä
#EverythingEverywhere #curiositynow #SpectacularNWT #nwt #parkscanada #explorecanada"
"Sydney is always ranked as one of the best cities in the world in terms of standard of living. I can‚Äôt really argue with that.

In addition to being a great place to live, it is also a great place to visit. For most visitors to Australia, Sydney will be the first stop in their visit as it has the largest airport in the country.

Any visit to Sydney will start in the harbor, where you can find two of the most well known attractions in Australia: The Sydney Opera House and the Harbor Bridge.

Despite being built less than 50 years ago, the Opera House is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and has become the symbol for the city. ‚Ä®Not far from the opera house is the Sydney Harbor Bridge. It is one of the largest steel arch bridges in the world and it is possible to do a bridge walk that takes you to the top of the bridge. 
Another great attraction that few people know about is Cockatoo Island, which is located in the harbor. It is a former prison and shipyard, which today is one of the only places you can camp in the middle of Sydney. You can easily get there by ferry. ‚Ä®Manly beach is one of the most best beaches in Sydney and is a popular surfing location. 
Sydney is also the location of the biggest fireworks show in the world every New Year‚Äôs Eve. I was there for it in 2014 and I had to wait for most of the day to get a good seat.
‚†Ä
#EverythingEverywhere #curiositynow #Paris #france #unseco #worldheritage"
"Paris. This will be hard to fit into 2,200 characters.
‚†Ä
The Paris that most people visit today is largely a 19th Century creation. In 1853 Emperor Napoleon III commissioned Georges-Eug√®ne Haussmann to head a project which radically changed the city. Avenues were widened, neighborhoods were demolished, and the layout of what is Paris today is largely the result of this effort.
‚†Ä
Many of the most iconic buildings in Paris were built during this time, including the Haussmann apartment buildings which are everywhere in Paris, lining most of the streets. The iconic octagonal kiosks were also introduced during this time.
‚†Ä
The Louvre is a major exception to this of course. It was originally built as a palace for the King of France in the 12th and 13th Centuries, but when Louis XIV moved to Versailles, the palace became mostly a place for the royal collection of art. It officially became a museum open to the public during the French Revolution in 1793.
‚†Ä
The Arc de Triomphe was commissioned in 1806 after the Battle of Austerlitz by Napoleon Bonaparte, but it wasn‚Äôt completed until 1836. It has since been used to honor the French war dead from WWI and is the location of the French Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
‚†Ä
The Eiffel Tower was originally built for the 1889 World‚Äôs Fair was intended to be taken down after the fair was over. It was so popular, it remained and has become the symbol of the city.
‚†Ä
The Cathedral of Notre Dame was completed in the 13th century and was seriously damaged by fire this past April. The French parliament passed a law in July requiring that the cathedral be repaired to look exactly like it did before. ‚†Ä
Paris is currently the second most visited city in the world with 19 million annual visitors (Bangkok is now #1). It was the most visited city in the world for several decades.
‚†Ä
#EverythingEverywhere #curiositynow #Paris #france #unseco #worldheritage"
"Venice is one of the most popular, and perhaps overvisited, tourist destinations in the world.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The location of Venice on a series of islands in a lagoon was selected as people sought protection from invading Germanic tribes in the late Roman Empire.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The location turned out to be a great base for the creation of a maritime trading empire. As Venice grew rich in the 9th to 13th centuries, they expanded controlling many cities along the Adriatic and Mediterranean coasts. In the 13th Century, it was the richest city in Europe.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
St. Mark‚Äôs Cathedral and St. Mark‚Äôs Square are named after the St. Mark, one of the authors of the New Testament gospels, which is buried in the cathedral. His body was taken from Alexandria, Egypt in 828. The relics were supposedly smuggled out of Alexandria underneath ‚†Ä‚†Ä
The leader of Venice was called the Doge. The Doge was elected for live in one of the most complicated election systems ever devised, where random names where chosen, who were randomly reduced, who then elected people, who then were randomly reduced, who then elected people, who were randomly reduced, who then elected the Doge.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
The system was designed such that no powerful family could possibly control the outcome given the random nature of selecting the electors. The system worked for over 500 years.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Venice lasted as an independent republic until 1797 when it was conquered by Napoleon in the War of the First Coalition.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
Today you can see evidence of the Venetian Empire all along the coast in places such as Croatia, Montenegro, and Greece. ‚†Ä‚†Ä
#EverythingEverywhere #curiositynow #venice #italy #unesco #worldheritage #italy"
"This week I'm not going to have a theme, but rather give you some interesting facts about some of the best-known tourist destinations in the world.

The Vatican is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Rome, and it has a really interesting history which most visitors are probably totally unaware of. 
1) The St. Peter's Basilica is located where is it because it is believed to be the burial spot of St. Peter. 
2) The original building, now known as Old St. Peter's, existed from the 4th to 16th century. It was originally commissioned by the Roman Emperor Constantine the Great.

3) The Egyptian obelisk in the middle of St. Peter's Square is there because it supposedly was present at the crucifixion of St. Peter in the Circus of Nero. The obelisk is the oldest standing obelisk in Rome and has only been moved once, during the creation of St. Peter's Square. It was quarried approximately 4,000 years ago near Heliopolis, Egypt.

4) An excavation under St. Peter's conducted in 1942 found the remains of a Roman cemetery directly under the altar, which is also where the altar of the original basilica was. There were etchings on the walls which pointed to the gravesite of ""Petrus"". There were several bone fragments found which are believed to be the remains of St. Peter.

5) Much of the marble which clad the Colosseum was used in the creation of St. Peter's Basilica. Many Roman ruins in the city were used as an easy source of marble.

6) Despite being over 400 years old, St. Peter's Basilica is still the largest church in the world by total interior area.

7) Vatican City is an independent country. This unique status was created as a compromise with Italy in 1929. Prior to the Lateran Treaty which created Vatican City, for almost 60 years, popes refused to leave the walls of the Vatican in protest of the dissolution of the Papal States.

8) The Vatican has about 800 citizens, however, none of them are natives and the country has a birth rate of zero.

9) The Vatican controls many buildings in Rome. Many major churches such as St. Paul's and St. Mary's are controlled by the Vatican and have the same legal status as an embassy.

10) The Vatican isn't part of the"

"FEATURED PHOTO OF THE WEEK: This has to be the most amazing photo I have ever seen of volcanic lightning discharged from an erupting volcano, also known as a ‚ÄúDirty Thunderstorm‚Äù. The Calbuco volcano erupted on April 22, 2015 (Earth Day) in southern Chile. Volcanic lightning occurs when fragmented particles collide in the volcanic plume and generate static electricity.

PHOTO CREDIT: @francisconegroni_fotografia ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
AMG G65 Final Edition ""The Unique Big Daddy with my DNA"".
State of the art engine.

Its design: ageless. Its technology: state-of-the-art. AMG engineers have implanted one of the most powerful engines into the Mercedes-AMG G65: the AMG M279 6.0Liter V12 Biturbo engine. The result is the most powerful G-Class of all time! With a maximum output of 463kW (630hp) and a maximum torque of 1000 Newton meters, the top-level model offers unparalleled driving dynamics. But brute force is just one side of the Mercedes-AMG G65 of course, the car also meets the highest standards of driving refinement and safety. The AMG SPEEDSHIFT PLUS 7G-TRONIC automatic transmission provides individual driving dynamics, efficient power transfer and high gear-switching comfort. The powerful dimensions of the AMG high-performance braking system always bring the Mercedes-AMG G65 to a reliable and safe stop.

"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
AMG GT R Roadster ""The Beast of The Green Hell"".
AMG. Driven By The Inner Force.

Next Level of Driving Performance.

The AMG M178 4.0L biturbo engine in the AMG GT R has an output of 585hp and the peak torque of 700Nm is available between 1,900 and 5,500rpm. The AMG 4.0L V8 engine features the tried and tested twin turbochargers, which are not mounted on the outside of the cylinder banks but rather inside the V¬†configuration ‚Äì experts call it a ‚Äúhot inside V‚Äù. This basic principle of the new AMG V8 family has been further optimised for the AMG GT R. The seven-speed dual-clutch transmission configured in a transaxle layout at the rear axle has likewise been extensively revised by the AMG developers to make the transmission even more suitable for the racetrack. Drivers can tailor the AMG GT R to their personal preferences using the AMG DYNAMIC SELECT controller. Various modes are available: ‚ÄúC‚Äù (Comfort), ‚ÄúS‚Äù (Sport), ‚ÄúS+‚Äù (Sport Plus) and ‚ÄúI‚Äù (Individual). The ‚ÄúRACE‚Äù mode optimally adjusts the shift strategy of the dual clutch transmission to the needs of racetrack usage.

"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
The new AMG CLA45 S 4MATIC+ Shooting Brake ‚ÄûThe Design Rocket in Style‚Äú.
Affalterbach. Outstanding performance, the ultimate driving dynamics, expressive design ‚Äë the new Mercedes-AMG CLA45 4MATIC+ Shooting Brake/ CLA45 S 4MATIC+ Shooting Brake (combined fuel consumption 8.3-8.1 l/100 km; combined CO2 emissions 189-185 g/km)[1] and the compact A45 4MATIC+/ A45 S 4MATIC+ sports cars (combined fuel consumption 8.4-8.3 l/100 km; combined CO2 emissions 192-189 g/km)[1] reassert their leading positions in their segments. They seamlessly continue the success story of their predecessors, while setting numerous new standards. Available in two output and torque variants, the completely newly developed 2.0-litre engine is the world's most powerful turbocharged four-cylinder engine in manufactured for series production.
With an output of up to 310 kW (421 hp), the completely newly developed M139 2.0-litre engine is the world's most powerful turbocharged four-cylinder manufactured for series production. Mercedes-AMG has bettered the output of the preceding engine by 30 kW(40 hp). Maximum torque has also increased from 475 to up to 500 newton metres.

With an output per litre of up to 155 kW (211 hp), the new Mercedes-AMG high-performance turbo engine even ranks ahead of many well-known super-sports car engines. The new, highly efficient powerpack is produced on an innovative production line in Affalterbach, on the ""One Man, One Engine"" principle.

"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
The new AMG GLC63 ""The Performance SUV"".
For the first time, a mid-size SUV is now also available with the powerful eight-cylinder biturbo in two output variants. The basis for this is provided by the M177 AMG 4.0‚Äëlitre V8 engine with 350kW (476hp) or 375kW (510hp) in the GLC63¬†S and GLC63¬†S Coup√© variants. Acceleration from 0‚Äë100¬†km/h in just 3.8¬†seconds also impressively demonstrates: the new SUVs hold a special position in their market segment.

The Performance SUVs also feature air spring suspension with adaptive adjustable damping, AMG Performance 4MATIC+ all-wheel drive with fully variable torque distribution, a rear-axle limited-slip differential and a high-performance braking system. As a visual indication of their links with Mercedes-AMG sports cars, the new models sport the AMG Panamericana grille, which was previously reserved for the AMG GT family. In addition, the new models offer all the advantages of a Mercedes-SUV: ample room for passengers and luggage, comprehensive array of safety equipment and superior traction, also in the wet or in wintry road conditions.

Amazing shot by: @capitolsunset"
"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
AMG GT R Pro ""The Monster of The Green Hell""
The new limited-edition top-of-the-range model AMG GT R PRO is characterised by yet further improved driving dynamics, in particular on the racetrack. The experience from the AMG GT3 and AMG GT4 racing cars entered into the development. The measures from motorsport can be clustered in four areas: suspension, lightweight construction, aerodynamics and looks.
Suspension: the optimal set-up

The new AMG coil-over suspension offers even more choices for tailoring the set-up to the particular circuit. As in professional motorsport, the driver is not only able to set the spring preload length mechanically, but can now also adjust the compression and rebound of the dampers. This is done quickly and precisely without tools via a click system with an integral adjustment dial on the damper. The compression rate is adjusted separately for high-speed and low-speed movements. This means that the settings can be dialled-in for slow and fast compression movements as is common practice in motorsport. This allows influencing the body dive and roll as the well as the traction of the AMG GT R PRO even more selectively.
The front axle is fitted with an adjustable torsion bar made of lightweight carbon fibre. Its counterpart at the rear is made of steel, is likewise adjustable and also saves weight due to its hollow tube design.
The AMG GT R is already fitted with Uniball spherical bearings at the lower wishbones of the rear axle. The AMG GT R PRO now gets these bearings also for the upper wishbones. They are significantly more wear-resistant than conventional wishbone bearings and due to their design have no play, which means toe-in and camber do not change even under high loads.

Mercedes-AMG One man, one engine Handcrafted by Michael K√ºbler @f1mike28 in Germany Affalterbach. Driving Performance is our Passion!
Mercedes-AMG the Performance and Sports Car Brand from Mercedes-Benz.
Mercedes-AMG Handcrafted by Racers.
Fuel consumption combined: 12,5 - 11,4 l/100 km | CO2-Emissions combined: 284 - 261g/km.
Amazing shot by: @justinleightonphoto"

"Produktplatzierung / Product Placement
The new AMG CLA45 S 4MATIC+ ‚ÄûThe Design Rocket‚Äú.
Affalterbach. Outstanding performance, the ultimate driving dynamics, expressive design ‚Äë the new Mercedes-AMG CLA45 4MATIC+/ CLA45 S 4MATIC+ (combined fuel consumption 8.3-8.1 l/100 km; combined CO2 emissions 189-185 g/km)[1] and the compact A45 4MATIC+/ A45 S 4MATIC+ sports cars (combined fuel consumption 8.4-8.3 l/100 km; combined CO2 emissions 192-189 g/km)[1] reassert their leading positions in their segments. They seamlessly continue the success story of their predecessors, while setting numerous new standards. Available in two output and torque variants, the completely newly developed 2.0-litre engine is the world's most powerful turbocharged four-cylinder engine in manufactured for series production.
With an output of up to 310 kW (421 hp), the completely newly developed M139 2.0-litre engine is the world's most powerful turbocharged four-cylinder manufactured for series production. Mercedes-AMG has bettered the output of the preceding engine by 30 kW(40 hp). Maximum torque has also increased from 475 to up to 500 newton metres. With an output per litre of up to 155 kW (211 hp), the new Mercedes-AMG high-performance turbo engine even ranks ahead of many well-known super-sports car engines. The new, highly efficient powerpack is produced on an innovative production line in Affalterbach, on the ""One Man, One Engine"" principle.

Mercedes-AMG Handcrafted by Racers."

Photographer Laura Pierangeli (@laurapierangeli) captured this candid moment in Trieste, Italy. ""The woman in red was smoking in front of the sea, and her face attracted my attention,"" the artist remembers. ""I was in front of her waiting for the moment to take a picture when the couple behind her started to approach in a scenographic way, so I chose that moment to shoot."" // #streetleaks #streetphotography #storyofthestreet #challengerstreets #ourstreets #capturestreets #fromstreetswithlove #everybodystreet #streetlife_award #life_is_street #streetphotographerscommunity #streetweekly #streetclassics #contemporaryphotography #streetphotography #streetphotographers #everybodystreet #streetphoto #streetscene #streetportrait #photostreet #ig_street #lensonstreets #streetsgrammer #streets_storytelling #streetshared #zonestreet #timeless_streets #documentary #documentaryphotography"
"""This is a photo from my series 'The Doukhobors' Land,'"" documentary photographer Natela Grigalashvili (@natela_grigalashvili) tells us. ""It's taken in the Javakheti region, Georgia, where the Doukhobors community [has lived] for approximately two centuries now after being exiled from Russia. Doukhobors are a Christian religious minority that believe that that god is in everyone and there is no need [for] priests or churches because every person can communicate to god without them. They are pacifists and hard-working people, who have always respected females and often had female community leaders. They had one of the richest communities throughout the whole soviet republic. But last 30 years have been very hard for them, and they started leaving the country. Most of them migrated to Russia and Canada. There is no opportunities and poverty for youth. Nowadays, there are very few of them left. That's what my project is all about--about the beauty, importance and problems of this community. That it will soon disappear. In this photo, Dukhobour women pick flowers on holy blue Kurgan mountain after prayer""
.
We're currently accepting submissions for Feature Shoot. Photographers are welcome to submit their work for consideration at the link in our bio. .

""Girls as young as 3 have pierced earrings, full facial makeup, false tans, long nails and high heels or pumps to wear for weddings, holy communions, confirmations, christenings, birthdays and other special occasions. "Guardian Of The Earth

Semalem di @masjidrayakebayoranresidences, bareng temen-temen santri @barisan_bangunnegeri, kembali bahas #lesswaste, dengan tema Guardian Of The Earth

Karena kalau Guardian Of The Galaxy udah mainstream, kita bahasnya bumi aja, menjadi penjaga bumi, a.k.a Khalifah fil ardhi, kalau bahasa Al-Qur'annya

Intinya sih, kita seringkali nggak adil pada perintah Allah. Bahwa kita memandang bahwa ketaatan itu hanya masalah ibadah ritual, tapi menjaga lingkungan kita abaikan

Padahal menjaga lingkungan itu disebut sebagai tugasnya manusia, sama seperti memelihara kehidupan antar manusia. Artinya sama-sama bagian tugas dari Allah

Tapi soal kini, orang nggak shalat kita sedih, tapi kita nggak sedih ketika ada pengrusakan hutan. Orang pacaran kita nasihati, tapi yang buang sampah sembarang kita biarin

Ini nasihat kepada diri saya sendiri, bahwa menjaga alam itu sama seperti menjaga manusia. Sebaliknya juga, menjaga manusia itu juga pada akhirntya menjaga alam

Siapa yang hadir dan inget materi semalem? Saya harap nggak terlalu mumet yaa.. Dan masih bersambung kok, jadi akan ada bahasan selanjutnya, siap-siap deh

Buat yang nggak dateng, nanti bakal ada videonya di YouTube, jadi pantentin aja, semoga ada manfaatnya bagi yang nggak kesempatan hadir, tapi tetep mau mantau

Tetep semangat buat #LessWaste dari #MasjidPeradaban, bareng guru-guru kita di #BarisanBangunNegeri, @hanan_attaki @ustadzabdulsomad_official @oemar_mita @binanies @luqmanulhakimashabul @salimafillah @felixsiauw @adihidayatofficial"
"Pre-Order Komik Al-Fatih 1453 by @felixsiauw @myodauz

Alhamdulillah, nggak ada kata lebih tepat selain puji syukur pada Allah. Sebab buku ini dikerjain lebih dari 1 tahun lamanya, niatnya sih 6 bulan, kenyataannya dobel hehe

Seperti yang sudah temen-temen tau, saya barengan sama @alfatihstudios menganggap bahwa salah satu yang harus difokuskan itu membangun generasi muda

Karenanya dalam beberapa tahun terakhir ini, saya dan @alfatihstudios lebih banyak produksi bacaan dan referensi buat anak-anak, supaya orangtua punya pilihan

Beda dengan komik Al-Fatih 1453 yang dulu pernah saya garap. Buku @komikalfatih1453 ini saya garap bareng @myodauz sebagai ilustrator, supaya lebih child-ish

Jadi buku ini lebih menitikberatkan pada perkembangan mental Al-Fatih kecil, bagaimana keluarga dan ulama mendidik karakter ksatria pada Al-Fatih

Karena sebagai orangtua, tentu saya sangat memahami sulitnya ayah-bunda lain dalam memilih referensi terbaik buat anak-anaknya, yang fun dan islami tentunya

Dan insyaAllah dalam pekan depan sudah bisa dinikmati. Sekarang Pre-Order sudah dibuka, bisa ke link yang sudah disediakan di bawah ini atau WA ke no: +62 852-8309-9873

"Lisan (Tulisan) Kita Pada Nabi Muhammad

Lisan hanyalah proyeksi dari pemikiran dan hati. Maka apa yang tampak dari lisan, seperti itulah kiranya isi pikir dan hati. Mungkin bisa direkayasa, tapi tak selamanya

Maka kita bisa tahu apa gambaran akal dan hati para penyair yang menggubah kisah Rasulullah dengan rangkaian bahasa yang penuh makna, seberapa cinta di dalamnya

Begitu pula dengan mereka yang lisannya penuh cela, penuh kata kasar, penuh hinaan, memaki dan merendahkan orang, maka pikiran dan hatinya pun sudah bisa ditera

Yang perlu kita tahu, bahwa apa yang dilisankan, atau di masa sosial media saat ini, yang dituliskan, itu tak bisa menyamai apa yang tersimpan dalam pikir dan hatinya

Berkaitan itu Allah tegaskan, ""Telah nyata kebencian dari mulut mereka, dan apa yang disembunyikan oleh hati mereka adalah lebih besar lagi"" dalam QS 3: 118

Seperti seorang penyair takkan bisa mewakili perasaan dalam akal dan hati dengan kata-katanya, begitu juga para pembenci takkan puas dengan caci maki dan cela mereka

Itulah mengapa, mereka yang memikirkan dan merasakan sesuatu secara terus-menerus, takkan bisa menahan itu selamanya. Tanya saja pada yang jatuh cinta

Mereka yang jatuh cinta selalu menemukan cara untuk bisa mengutarakan rasa. Bahkan tanpa suara, seperti cinta dalam diam, yang dihela dalam sujud dan doa

Ia akan ungkapkan pikir dan rasa dalam cara yang paling indah, kata-kata yang paling tepat, kalimat yang paling pas, serta kesempatan yang paling sempurna

Sampai pada kita, bagaimana cinta Imam Malik pada Nabi, membuatnya mandi, bersiwak, memakai baju indah dan parfum terbaik, bersurban, tiap membaca haditsnya

Tak hanya itu, Imam Malik akan naik ke mimbar, mewangikan ruangan dengan bukhur, menunggu hadirin tenang dan khusyu, baru membacakan sabda Nabi yang mulia

Sekarang kita pahami, mengapa kita mungkin sering tak sopan, atau berkata yang tak sepantasnya tentang Nabi, mungkin pikir dan rasa kita yang perlu diperiksa

#Nabi #Muhammad #Rasulullah"

"These are the people I'm most thankful for and that make my world go round. I don't slow down enough to reflect and be thankful for what I have and this life I get to live. I get caught up in the grind and always  pushing forward to the next thing.

Don't get me wrong, I get to enjoy time with my family almost every day unless I'm travelling. But it's great to actually slow down and take a minute to reflect on where I've been and where I am now.

After 17 years of working unfulfilling jobs, now I work for myself and get to spend so much more time with my family. I work with my wife and we get to eat lunch together every day and laugh and joke about silly things as we grow our business together. "Photos by @FransLanting Today is Wildlife Conservation Day and I‚Äôd like to pay tribute to Jane Goodall who has done so much to open our eyes and minds to the world of animals and their needs. I am honored to join her for a series of events in the Netherlands meant to increase support for her work. Jane‚Äôs Roots and Shoots programs empower young people around the world to engage with environmental causes. She is nurturing a next generation of conservation champions. We desperately need a new wave of youthful energy to help break logjams of inaction when it comes to creating a better balance between people and planet. We hope that you and your families will join us. Go to the link in my Instagram profile for event details and ticket info. Follow us @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more images and stories about the natural world and the people working to ensure there is a future for all of us. 
@janegoodall.nl @janegoodallinst @humbertotan #janegoodall #drjanegoodall #janegoodall85 #jane85 #chimpanzee #bonobo #hope #conservation #nederland"
photo by @FransLanting Only the bravest surfers dare to ride the gigantic waves at Nazare in Portugal, but @Kalanilattanzi takes it further. He practices bodysurfing! Unlike other surfers who pick up speed behind by jet skis to catch a wave, he has to create his own momentum to surf down a huge barrel of wild water, using only his flippers and a tiny hand board‚Äîand he gets wiped out at the end of every ride, yet he is totally cheerful about the experience. Amazing to see him in action. In case you wonder, he covers his head in bright colored sunscreen so that he can be spotted better by his own security support and by other surfers. Follow us @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more wild rides around the world. @Kalanilattanzi @leodomingox #surfing #bodysurfing #wave #bigwave #Nazare
"Photos by @FransLanting and friends. I‚Äôm giving thanks to the talented photographers who joined us for workshops at our studio in Santa Cruz, California, this past year. I love teaching photography and I am always amazed by the images our workshop participants create. Here are some highlights by Mark Diekhans, Thomas Vogelsang, Lisa Alvarez, Jon Bertoni, Michael Simoni, and Thomas Edwardson. We are hosting three new photography workshops in the first half of 2020, and I invite you to join us to unleash your own creativity and improve your technical skills. You can learn more at lanting.com/workshops-travel. Or go to the link in my Instagram bio. Follow me @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more encounters with the natural world.
#Photography #Naturephotography #Photoworkshop #Workshop #Creativity #MontereyBay #Naturelovers #Nature"
"We were hoping for mercy after Jane Goodall‚Äôs passionate plea, but unfortunately harsh verdicts have been issued against eight Iranian cheetah conservationists. Our friends Morad and Niloufar were sentenced to 10 years in prison; Houman and Taher to 8 years and Amir and Sepideh to 6 years. It is not known yet what the outcome is for Sam and Abdolreza. The charges have not been made public yet either. Because of the recent unrest in Iran it is difficult to know what is going on. The internet was shut down for almost a week. It is unclear what we can do at the moment, but we are not giving up and we will keep you informed. Thanks to you all for your heartfelt comments. @NatGeo published an online story the other day that explains the political background for this tragedy. Go to the link in my Instagram bio to learn more. And follow us @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom to stay engaged.

@hope4nature @JaneGoodallInst @hrouhani @jzarif_ir @hediyehtehrany @mitra.hajjar @raisi_org #NiloufarBayani #SamRadjabi #MoradTahbaz #HoumanJowkar #SepidehKashani #AmirHosseinKhaleghi #AbdolrezaKouhpayeh #TaherGhadirian #anyhopefornature #FreeIranianConservationists"

It will be an honor to join her on stage for a joint presentation and conversation moderated by @HumbertoTan on Dec. 7 in Den Bosch. "Photo by @FransLanting Baobabs glow against a night sky in western Madagascar. These ‚Äúupside-down trees‚Äù are associated with Africa, but while that entire continent has only one species, Madagascar is home to six species of baobabs, all of them unique to that wondrous island. Locally they‚Äôre called ‚ÄúReniala‚Äù, meaning mother of the forest. This image was included in my recent exhibition at Xposure 2019 in Sharjah, UAE. Follow me @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more encounters with amazing trees. 
@Natgeo @Natgeotravel @thephotosociety @xposurepf #Madagascar #baobab #naturephotography #nightphotography #nature #lookingup #night #mother #forest #trees"
Last week I was in The United Arab Emirates where His Highness Sheikh Dr Sultan bin Mohammed Al Qasimi, the Ruler of Sharjah and His Excellency Sheikh Sultan bin Ahmed Al Qasimi, the Chairman of Sharjah‚Äôs Media Council, honored me by visiting my exhibition during the Xposure 2019 Opening Ceremony in Sharjah, United Arab Emirates. Go to the link in my profile if you want to see some of the images that were on display. In just a few years time Xposure has become one of the great international photography festivals thanks to the support of the Sharjah government. It was a fabulous event and I thank everyone involved for their hospitality and hard work. It was great to spend some time with my friends @amivitale @stephenwilkes there as well. Follow me @FransLanting for more photographic experiences from around the world. @xposurepf @saqshj @christineeckstrom @thephotosociety #photography
"Photo by @FransLanting Every iceberg tells a story. Each one is a snapshot of water frozen in time. I photographed this blue diamond along the Antarctic Peninsula in early summer knowing it would be gone in a few months. Ninety percent of all ice on Earth is contained by Antarctica, and as our planet warms, ice shelves and glaciers dislodge an ever-larger portion of it each year into the Southern Ocean, where most icebergs melt away in a single season‚Äîadding to sea level rise. That‚Äôs how the life cycle of ice far away affects everyone living along a sea coast anywhere. 
A global #ClimateStrike will take place tomorrow, Friday, September 20, in advance of the UN Climate Action Summit, demanding action to address the climate crisis we are facing. The September 20 strike will kick off a week of actions capped by another strike on September 27. We urge you to take a stand with us. Together, let‚Äôs show our politicians we are serious about the fight against climate change. Join us, @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom, in this effort, and check the link in my bio to find out about events in your community and how you can join the strike.

@thephotosociety @leonardodicaprio @gretathunberg #Antarctica #Iceberg #ClimateStrike #ClimateCrisis #naturenow #strikewithus #globalwarming #savetheplanet #gretathunberg"
"Photo by @FransLanting The Eastern side of California‚Äôs Sierra Nevada mountains is a wonderland for photography with places like Yosemite, Mono Lake and the White Mountains within an hours drive if you start out at Mammoth Lakes‚Äì which is not a bad place in its own right. Here are two images from previous field trips in the area. The first one shows a hiker coming upon an ancient bristlecone pine. These trees are among the oldest living things on the planet. Some of them are known to be almost 5000 years old. The second shows a Photographer on an alpine lake shore in the Ansel Adams Wilderness. 
I am excited to go back there soon when I speak at the Mammoth Photo Fest in Mammoth Lakes, California October 10-13 along with my colleagues @cristinamittermeier, @pedromcbride, and @coreyrichproductions. I will do a presentation about my three decades of experience with wildlife around the world. Check out the link in my bio to explore the program or purchase tickets. Follow me @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more images of our living planet. @Mammothphotofest #photography #photofestival #bristleconepine #Mammoth #SierraNevada #easternsierras #outdoors #nature #optoutside"
"Photo by @FransLanting A radio story by PRI‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe World‚Äù program about Iran‚Äôs jailed cheetah conservationists for which I was interviewed is airing today on NPR stations nationwide. Tune in to your local station or click on the link in my Instagram profile to hear it. Our friends have been in prison now for more than a year and a half. Their trials in Tehran are in a critical stage and It is important that they are not forgotten. They are patriots dedicated to saving one of Iran‚Äôs most powerful natural symbols from extinction and their arrest is a tragedy for them and their families as well as for the future survival of Iran‚Äôs cheetahs. Please, help spread word about this injustice.

@hrouhani @jzarif_ir @hediyehtehrany @Reza_Kianian_Official @mitra.hajjar @raisi_org @richardbranson @leonardodicaprio @hope4nature @ChristineEckstrom #ConservationIsNotaCrime #Free_Iran_Conservationists #anyhopefornature #hope4nature‚Å©‚Å© #ConservationNeedsCameratraps #cheetahs #bigcats ÿßŸÖŸäÿØ_ÿ®ÿ±ÿßŸâ_ÿ∑ÿ®Ÿäÿπÿ™  #ÿßŸÖ€åÿØ_ÿ®ÿ±ÿß€å_ÿ∑ÿ®€åÿπÿ™  #ŸÅÿπÿßŸÑÿßŸÜ_ŸÖÿ≠€åÿ∑_ÿ≤€åÿ≥ÿ™  #ŸÅÿπÿßŸÑÿßŸÜ_ŸÖÿ≠€åÿ∑_ÿ≤€åÿ≥ÿ™€å  #ÿßŸÖ€åÿ±ÿ≠ÿ≥€åŸÜ_ÿÆÿßŸÑŸÇ€å  #ŸáŸàŸÖŸÜ_ÿ¨Ÿà⁄©ÿßÿ±  #ÿ∑ÿßŸáÿ±_ŸÇÿØ€åÿ±€åÿßŸÜ #ŸÜ€åŸÑŸàŸÅÿ±_ÿ®€åÿßŸÜ€å #ÿ≥ÿßŸÖ_ÿ±ÿ¨ÿ®€å  #ÿ≥Ÿæ€åÿØŸá_⁄©ÿßÿ¥ÿßŸÜ€å  #ŸÖÿ±ÿßÿØ_ÿ∑ÿßŸáÿ®ÿßÿ≤  #ÿπÿ®ÿØÿßŸÑÿ±ÿ∂ÿß_⁄©ŸàŸáŸæÿß€åŸá  #⁄©ÿßŸàŸàÿ≥_ÿ≥€åÿØÿßŸÖÿßŸÖ€å  #ÿßŸÖŸäÿØ_ÿ®ÿ±ÿßŸâ_ÿ∑ÿ®Ÿäÿπÿ™  #ŸÅÿπÿßŸÑÿßŸÜ_ŸÖÿ≠Ÿäÿ∑_ÿ≤Ÿäÿ≥ÿ™  #ÿßŸÖŸäÿ±ÿ≠ÿ≥ŸäŸÜ_ÿÆÿßŸÑŸÇŸä  #ÿ≥ŸæŸäÿØŸá_ŸÉÿßÿ¥ÿßŸÜŸâ  #ÿßŸÖŸäÿ±ÿ≠ÿ≥ŸäŸÜ_ÿÆÿßŸÑŸÇŸä  #ŸáŸàŸÖŸÜ_ÿ¨ŸàŸÉÿßÿ±  #ÿ≥ŸæŸäÿØŸá_ŸÉÿßÿ¥ÿßŸÜŸâ  #ÿ≥ÿßŸÖ_ÿ±ÿ¨ÿ®Ÿâ  #ÿ∑ÿßŸáÿ±_ŸÇÿØŸäÿ±ŸäÿßŸÜ  #ŸÖÿ±ÿßÿØ_ÿ∑ÿßŸáÿ®ÿß  #ÿπÿ®ÿØÿßŸÑÿ±ÿ∂ÿß_ŸÉŸàŸáŸæÿßŸäŸá  #ÿßŸÖŸäÿØ_ÿ®ÿ±ÿßŸâ  #ÿßŸÖŸäÿØ_ÿ®ÿ±ÿßŸâ_ÿ∑ÿ®Ÿäÿπÿ™"
"Photo by @FransLanting Two orphaned orangutans cling to each other at a rehab center in northern Borneo. Like humans, they need affection and care from their mothers in order to become healthy adults. Orangutans are the last great apes that survive outside of Africa. They live only on the islands of Borneo and Sumatra, and they are endangered due to the massive destruction of their forest habitat. Baby orangs are also victims of the illegal pet trade‚Äîcaptured by poachers who kill their mothers to reach them. It is imperative that we protect the forests orangutans depend on to insure that our next of kin on the family tree of life will be with us beyond our own lifetime. I welcome you to support the organizations that are in the front lines of protecting them, such as the World Wildlife Fund and Wild Aid. I share this image in honor of World Orangutan Day. Follow me @FransLanting and @ChristineEckstrom for more images of endangered animals around the world. 
@wildaid @worldwildlifefund @leonardodicaprio @thephotosociety #WorldOrangutanDay #InternationalOrangutanDay #Borneo #Family #Love #Twins #Orphans"

"Last night was such an amazing¬†night!
I LOVE Coldplay, their music¬†has been with me in most of the meaningful crossroads in my life.
Last night I was invited to see their sound check before the amazing show at the Natural History Museum.
and for a moment it was just us, and them, under a giant 100-year-old skeleton of a blue whale.
All those incredible elements¬†-¬†¬†art, music, nature, people and time - came together and created the most magical night.

The past 10 days I haven‚Äôt been very active over here, and you might wonder why. I had a wisdom tooth extraction with surgery which developed into a dry socket. In an attempt to speed up the recovery, I was given an iodine aid but I developed a strong reaction to it. Turns out I‚Äôm extremely allergic to Iodine. My whole mouth broke down into painful ulcers, making me lose all taste and haven‚Äôt been able to properly eat for a while now. On top of that, due to suffering from very low blood pressure all my life [ this is a condition I‚Äôve been born with and makes me feel tired most of the time ] all strong painkillers are out of the question because they tend to make me feel worse than the actual pain itself giving me nauseas and making me sick. However, this whole thing haven‚Äôt stopped me from having work meetings and waking up at 5 am everyday to prepare the launch of @amlul drop 2 in a few days. And if I‚Äôm sharing this with you is not to make you feel pity for me, but to share how much I appreciate every minute I‚Äôve felt in good healthy and strong, now more than ever. We only have one body to love and we need to look after it more than we actually do ‚ù£Ô∏è .

"Love the absolute simplicity and warmth of this home. .
.
.

"Most people will tell you this : if you let it, LA will make you quite a healthy person. You start eating better & going out in nature & to the gym. I exercise everyday and I don‚Äôt ever think about it. It‚Äôs part of my life. I run, I do yoga, Pilates. I love it, it‚Äôs not even an effort anymore (I can‚Äôt believe it myself)
.
But I‚Äôve always missed something more. I like the idea of being a student - not just aim to feel and look better - but making the practice an art.
.
It‚Äôs quite impossible today to find a yoga class where you can build up on your knowledge year after year, you know what I mean? Yoga has become automated in order to be accessible to most, teachers kind of come and go - even more in hot yoga which I practice & LOVE nonetheless.
.
Anyway. I‚Äôve always been attracted to martial arts - I had done Aikido a long time ago and loved everything from the philosophy to the sense of respect, perseverance and inner calm. I liked looking forward to a new belt. And also, I liked to feel like I could defend myself.
.
So I‚Äôd been looking for a club in LA for a while and honestly, they can feel a little intimidating. So when I met the wonderful @sophkupersmith 6 months ago and she told me that Jiu Jitsu had changed her life, I told her I wanted in. Thing is she lives in Newport. Took a while to make it happen - but yesterday I finally did.
.
I came early to watch a class, then had a private with the amazing @gustavofonseca_jj + @alexisfonseca_jj (there are a lot of champions there) where I learned to fall on my back & basically how to break someone‚Äôs shoulder. Important skills, no? All this of course in full Martial Art respectful, beautiful spirit. .

I LOVED it. .

Ok doesn‚Äôt hurt that the aesthetic of @artofjiujitsu is incredible and that Jj students come to the mat from every walks of life, making it a place where you get out of your social bubble. Which I need so much. .
Okay, enough talking, I am going to put more photos in my stories.
.
And I now I am looking for a club in West LA if any of you know any. .

Thank you @sophkupersmith for opening the doors and thank you @artofjiujitsu + the students for letting me take photos üôèüèº thank you @timothylayaban !!!
."

."
"Hi!!! Yeah! From bed. .
.
Em and I found the secret to life when it comes to flying towards Europe and it‚Äôs the bloody day flight!!! .

You know how usually you leave in the evening after a full day and then you get traffic on the way to the airport and then you spend a weird 4h night sleeping amongst snoring strangers and then you hit the morning traffic on the way to town and then you try to take a shower and pretend like you‚Äôre alive for the rest of the day, which you‚Äôre not, let‚Äôs be honest you‚Äôre total return of the walking dead üßü‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è and then no matter how much melatonin and caffeine you pump in your system it takes you a week to adjust and recuperate?
.
I know, probably one of the worst of the first world problems.
.
Well we solved it. .

For some reason we booked a day flight, knowing very well we would lose an entire day (we left at 8am and arrived at 8pm) and that I‚Äôd tell myself I‚Äôd work but would end up watching Animal Kingdom - Em pretended the WiFi wasn‚Äôt working in order to justify her laziness which totally wasn‚Äôt true since I was using it but hey we all find our own excuses (I didn‚Äôt have one, I‚Äôm just lazy and I wanna what shady stuff Smurf will do next).
.
Anyway so we booked a day flight, did absolutely nothing the whole time, and arrived in London, no traffic, straight into our beds for a long night, and since then, we‚Äôve been on fire.
.
No return of the walking dead for us. No jet lag, just a tiny yawn around 3pm.
.
Anyway I thought it was a very important health message üòÇ - I stopped doing the awful LA - NYC red eye a while back (this one is the worstest) but now I know my plan for Europe.
.
.
.
Sleep + rest = mental health, and mental health is everything. 
And I joke about it, but I‚Äôm actually super serious about it. So that‚Äôs it! Let‚Äôs go to bed. Let‚Äôs lose a day when necessary, so we can live the ones after, fully."
On the way to London, a softer moment to breathe, dream, get lost above the clouds.
"Thank you @harvard @harvardlaw for having me!
.
Thank you to Reina and all the lovely students. .

It‚Äôs nice to come and be a ‚Äúteacher‚Äù but it was funny to realize that even though there is probably no more glorious place to study than an Ivy League school, I would never go back to these years. Oh how I hated being a student!!! I couldn‚Äôt see it at the time because that was all I knew - and I was terrified I had no life skills. There was probably some good sides to it and a few great teachers.
.

But - big sense of dread when I reminisce about it. 
I think the best day of my student life was the one where I decided to stop my studies. 
And most of what I do today I learned outside of school.
.
Not telling you to quit school ü§ì just that we all have different learning styles, and that maybe I would have been kinder to myself had I known that before.
.
Did you love studying? Would you go back? Like, if I told you you were admitted at Harvard?"
"For so many years I tried to think my way through life. Take the right course of action, plan, own my mistakes, try again. .

I also tried to control my way through my healing. I tried to understand why I was who I was and how I could be a better person. My mom, my dad, my childhood, bla, bla.
.
I tried to do what‚Äôs right in every aspect of my life. .

Until recently, life threw me a few curveballs. Some good, some bad, but the floor under my feet suddenly didn‚Äôt feel that stable anymore.
.
And maybe it‚Äôs because of all the work that I did on myself - so, I am not discarding it - or maybe it‚Äôs maturity, or maybe we just change, but all of a sudden I didn‚Äôt want to think it through.
.
Instead just let go and and accept and adapt and trust. Do what I feel, instead of what I think is ‚Äúthe right thing to do‚Äù.
.
It‚Äôs been good. 
And profound - and I know it‚Äôs just the start.
It‚Äôs like I used to be at war with life and suddenly put my weapons gently on the floor and realized it was okay to just be me. .

It‚Äôs not easy because my old ways are endlessly trying to make a come back. I‚Äôd be the type of person to overthink on how to not overthink.
.
.
.
There is so much there that can‚Äôt be covered in only a few words but I wanted to write this because I feel like with the wellness trend something is happening where we get caught up in our ‚Äúhealing‚Äù like it‚Äôs a job. I hear people telling me : ‚ÄúI am working on my mother wound‚Äù or ‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm good, I‚Äôm fixed! 15 years of therapy!‚Äù. I recently went to a sort of ayahuasca gathering (I personally haven‚Äôt tried, I‚Äôm not against it) and it literally felt like a competition of who was the most woke and healed, and because I hadn‚Äôt done it, pffff, I couldn‚Äôt know. Maybe that‚Äôs true. Or maybe humans are humans and they need to compete even in spirituality. .

But what I truly think is, relax, no one is ever fixed. It‚Äôs time to chill. We‚Äôre all pretty much messes underneath. And it‚Äôs really  okay.
.
.
.
Recently I have also really loved pristine skies like this one. Not the sunset, but right after - when the tension of the day is gone, and the colors peacefully fill the sky in all its spaciousness. That moment, the let go."
"This week and the next one are going to be fun. I‚Äôll be speaking with @nililotan , then go up to Boston to give a talk at @harvard , then host an event with @lamer and @nordstrom , then do a keynote at @bof Voices and host another event in London I‚Äôll tell you about soon*. .

I love this type of work because it‚Äôs all about connecting with others and telling stories. .

I was thinking of the outfits I‚Äôll pack, and the only thing I can think about is good jeans and tee-shirts. Or sweater because it‚Äôs getting cold apparently on the other side of the planet. Awesome shoes. Simple. Because when I look back, that‚Äôs always how I feel the most myself and when you‚Äôre doing public speaking, all you want to feel is ease and confidence.
.
I started wondering what I could get away with, and I still haven‚Äôt really answered the question. Maybe I‚Äôll change my mind and freak out at the last minute and go on a shopping hunt and it could be fun, stressful and pricey. Or maybe I‚Äôll just trust myself, do me, and see how it works.
.
.
.
And yes @imranamed I promise I‚Äôll bring a dress for the gala! I‚Äôm not a savage! (Yet üòú)
.
. .
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî .
* more infos in my stories soon!"

"‚Å£‚ú®NEW RECIPE‚ú® Nectarine & Roasted Walnut Salad üåøüçä recipe belowüëáüèª this delicious salad is fresh & light, full of flavour & texture, & super easy to throw together - the perfect salad for entertaining this holiday season ü§ó you can also easily make this salad vegan by using a vegan cheese substitute üßÄ i know you're going to love this one! i've copied the recipe below + also linked it in my BIO‚úåüèª hope you all enjoy! x‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
INGREDIENTS‚†Ä
‚†Ä
¬æ cup walnuts‚†Ä
4 large handfuls of mixed lettuce leaves‚†Ä
1 small bunch fresh basil leaves‚†Ä
1 small bunch fresh mint leaves‚†Ä
1 small bunch fresh chives, roughly chopped‚†Ä
6 fresh nectarines, pitted & sliced into eighths‚†Ä
120g goats cheese - you could also use feta cheese or fresh mozzarella Aleppo pepper flakes or chili flakes‚†Ä
Extra virgin olive oil‚†Ä
Balsamic vinegar‚†Ä
Sea salt‚†Ä
Freshly cracked black pepper‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
METHOD‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Place a fry pan onto medium heat, add the walnuts, a little drizzle of olive oil, a sprinkle of sea salt, and toast until golden, stirring regularly so they don't burn.‚†Ä
Remove the walnuts from the heat and set aside to cool.‚†Ä
In a large serving bowl, add the lettuce leaves, basil, mint, and chives, then toss to combine. NOTE: Keep aside some small basil and mint leaves to garnish the top of the salad.‚†Ä
Arrange the nectarines on top and crumble the goats cheese.‚†Ä
Sprinkle over half of the toasted walnuts.‚†Ä
Roughly chop the remaining walnuts and sprinkle over the top along with the small basil and mint leaves.‚†Ä
Just before serving drizzle with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar.‚†Ä
Sprinkle with Aleppo pepper or chili flakes and some freshly cracked pepper.‚†Ä
Serve immediately and enjoy! #gatherandfeast"
üåøüçä working on a few NEW delicious salad recipes for the holidays - including this Nectarine & Roasted Walnut Salad ‚ú® coming very soon! Ash x
‚ú®HELLO mango, raspberry, & passionfruit curd PAVLOVA üòçü•≠ one of the many PAV variations I made over the holidays last year! ü§ó it's now only 5 weeks until Christmas üò±üéÑ so I thought i'd highlight this bowl of deliciousness again - you can find the RECIPE + a step-by-step VIDEO on my IGTV or website (LINK in BIO)‚úåüèª feel free to use any fruit you have in season üçÅ hope you all enjoy! Ash x
MAPLE PECAN PIE with cinnamon spelt crust üçÅü•ß for those prepping for Thanksgiving OR for anyone that loves PIE üôãüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è here's the recipe for my delicious pecan pie with cinnamon spelt crustüëåüèª LINKED in my BIO‚úåüèª we don‚Äôt celebrate Thanksgiving here in Australia but I thought i'd join in the festivities anyway ü§ó hope you enjoy! TAG someone to bake this with over the holiday season!! Ash x
"‚Å£CHIIIPSS!! üòã‚ú®üëâüèª baked potato + sweet potato chips with roasted sesame salt & KEWPIE Mayonnaise Sriracha Flavour üòç so easy, SO yum!üëåüèª i've copied in the recipe belowüëáüèª the roasted sesame salt also keeps well in a jar - perfect to sprinkle over saut√©ed greens, salads, eggs, & todays crispy baked potato chips ü§ó hope you enjoy! Ash x‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
INGREDIENTS‚†Ä
‚†Ä
--Baked Chips--‚†Ä
6 medium-sized white potatoes - skin on ‚†Ä
1 large sweet potato - skin on‚†Ä
Olive oil‚†Ä
Sea salt‚†Ä
KEWPIE Mayonnaise Sriracha Flavour‚†Ä
‚†Ä
--Roasted Sesame Salt-- ‚†Ä
¬æ cup sesame seeds ‚†Ä
2 tbs flaked sea salt‚†Ä
1 tsp aleppo pepper flakes OR mild chili flakes ‚†Ä
Freshly ground black pepper‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
METHOD‚†Ä
‚†Ä
--Roasted Sesame Salt--‚†Ä
Place a frying pan on medium heat, add the sesame seeds (no oil needed) and fry until golden.‚†Ä
Remove the sesame seeds from the pan and place into a bowl.‚†Ä
To the same bowl, add the sea salt, aleppo pepper or chili flakes, and a generous amount of freshly cracked black pepper, stir to combine.‚†Ä
Set the mixture aside.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
--Baked Chips--‚†Ä
Slice the white potatoes into 6-9 pieces.‚†Ä
Slice the sweet potato into roughly 12 pieces.‚†Ä
Steam the combined potato slices for 20 minutes.‚†Ä
Set the steamed potatoes aside to cool.‚†Ä
Preheat your oven to 180C/350F (fan-forced oven).‚†Ä
Coat the potatoes with a little olive oil and place onto 1-2 baking trays.‚†Ä
Ensure the potatoes are well spaced so they have room to crisp up in the oven.‚†Ä
Sprinkle with a little sea salt. ‚†Ä
Bake the chips for 60 minutes, turning them halfway through baking time. ‚†Ä
Once crispy and golden brown, remove from the oven, sprinkle with roasted sesame salt, and serve with the mayonnaise.‚†Ä
NOTE: Store the leftover roasted sesame salt in an airtight jar or container in the fridge.‚†Ä
Enjoy! x #gatherandfeast #kewpiemayo #kp_partner #kewpiemayonnaise #kewpiemayomadebetter #kewpiemayosriracha #japanesemayonnaise"
"‚Å£we're well into the HOLIDAY SEASON!‚ú®üéÉü¶ÉüéÑ so i just collated & grouped all the recipes i think that are perfect for this festive season üòã here's just a few highlighted above (SWIPE acrossüëâüèª) including this chai soaked fruit with mascarpone oat tart üòç you can find a LINK to all these + more in my BIOüëåüèª hope you enjoy! Ash x‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
RECIPES Featured:‚†Ä
‚†Ä
- Chai Soaked Fruit with Mascarpone Oat Tart‚†Ä
‚†Ä

"‚Å£üçìü••üçû french toast for the weekend?! üëâüèª sourdough coconut french toast with fresh strawberries & pure maple ‚ú® here is my rough recipe... happy weekend!! ü§ó x‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
INGREDIENTS‚†Ä
‚†Ä
2 eggs‚†Ä
1/2 cup coconut milk (from a can or drinking coconut milk)‚†Ä
3 tbs desiccated coconut‚†Ä
1/2 tsp vanilla‚†Ä
4 large slices sourdough bread (I used spelt sourdough)‚†Ä
Coconut oil for frying‚†Ä
‚†Ä
GARNISH‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Pure maple, coconut yoghurt, fresh strawberries, & flaked or shredded coconut‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
METHOD‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Whisk the eggs, coconut milk, desiccated coconut, and vanilla together in a bowl.‚†Ä
Add the bread slices and soak for 1-2 minutes ensuring the bread is completely coated and soaked in the mixture.‚†Ä
Add a teaspoon of coconut oil to a fry pan on medium to high heat - then add the soaked slices and cook for roughly 2 minutes on each side or until golden.‚†Ä
Serve with coconut yoghurt, pure maple, fresh strawberries, and coconut flakes.‚†Ä
Serves 2-4 people ü§ó‚†Ä
Enjoy! üòò Ash¬†¬†#gatherandfeast"
