Main ferry terminal of the Buriganga River, Bangladesh, 2017.  With a rapidly growing population and decaying infrastructure, the river remains the one of the most important modes of transportation for Dhaka.  As an American, it was a suggestion of what it could have been like to see the human spectacle of New Orleans, St. Louis, or New York from the air in the mid 19th Century.
Terraced rice fields just south of the Red River, Yunnan, China.  These terraces are 2,500 years old, and are worked with the help of water buffalo.  The Chinese name for this area is Ti Tian or "ladder to heaven". The vertical relief of some terraces exceeds 2,000 ft. making them the biggest contiguous section of rice terraces in the world.
Twisted folds of wind eroded rocks and sand dunes fill the Chaidamu Basin in Quinghai, China.  Sometimes people ask me what‚Äôs so interesting about deserts, like, they‚Äôre just wastelands.  To me the deserts are the last great class of wilderness left on this planet. #DesertAirBook #paramotor
Philae Temple was built on an island near the first cataract on the Nile during the Ptolemaic period.  After construction of the first Aswan dam, it was seasonally flooded, before being relocated by @UNESCO to this higher site on an adjacent islet.  In ancient times it was a site for religion as well as commerce, as trade goods had to be off-loaded here to pass the rapids.
Octopus boats clog Nouadhibou Harbor in Mauritania at the end of the fishing season. In Mauritania some 70% of the local boats are used to catch octopus for the Japanese market. #onassignment for an upcoming story in @natgeo
Calvary Cemetery in Queens, New York City after the first Nor‚Äôeaster of the season laid down a fresh blanket of white.  With over 3 million interments, it has the most graves of any cemetery in the USA, and is also one of the oldest.  To see more of Gotham from above, check out @NewYorkAirBook, a portrait of NYC by üöÅ in one calendar year, 2014
Salt works of the lowest point in Asia, Lake Ayding, in Xinjiang, China, some 500 ft.. below sea level.  The summer temps in the Turpan Depression are over 125¬∞F in summer and below zero in winter, when the mine is closed. #DesertAirBook #paramotor
Low tide on the most seaward island in the flood-prone delta of the Brahmaputra/Jamuna River in Bangladesh.  The rice crop here is just inches above the high tide line, and even the smallest storm surge causes significant damage. Sea surface temperatures in the Bay of Bengal have been increasing significantly, leading to stronger monsoon flooding. Scientists say Bangladesh has suffered some of the fastest sea-level rises in the world, and project at least a five-foot rise by 2100, displacing 50 million people.
Top of the Rock, arguably the finest view of Manhattan, unless you are leaning out the open door of Dennis‚Äô little helicopter‚Ä¶. #NewYorkAirBook
Delta of the R√≠o Ramis as it meanders into the Peruvian side of Lake Titicaca at 12,500 ft.. The well-drained fertile soil is shared among many farmers in narrow strips perpendicular to the riverbank.  Increasing demand in El Norte has made quinoa the prized cash crop of the Altiplano.
Spiderman working his way down Central Park West, New York City.  #NewYorkAirBook
"At 1:23 am on April 26, 1986, Reactor No. 4 at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant blew up. The radioactive fallout spread over thousands of square kilometers, driving more than a quarter of a million people permanently from their homes. More than 100,000 people may have succumbed to Chernobyl-related illnesses. It remains the worst nuclear accident to date.

While the accident itself created chaos of apocalyptic magnitude, more than three decades later, tourists and guides are creating another bewildering disturbance even as they (naively) seek to articulate a deeper comprehension. Today, the most riveting attraction, the ghost town of Pripyat, bears less-than-honest witness to the disaster, as tourists hastily rearrange items‚Äîabandoned dolls, gas masks, furniture and more‚Äîin an attempt to form a haunting scene for the next tour group, or just to photograph themselves.

@thephotosociety @natgeoimagecollection #Pripyat #Chernobyl #Ukraine #disastertourism"
"Inside the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, Ludmila is overcome by memories as she silently pauses on the edge of the bed in a small room where she used to rest between shifts while working in Pripyat‚Äôs Polissya Hotel.

Ludmila was one of the quarter million people who were evacuated and relocated in 1986 after the world‚Äôs worst nuclear disaster to date. Former residents of Pripyat are only allowed to revisit the Zone once each year‚Äîin the spring on Parents‚Äô Day. As an alternative, residents can return as tourists, since tourism was legalized in the Zone in 2011.  Due to the attention received by the incredible HBO miniseries, ‚ÄúChernobyl,‚Äù there has been renewed interest in my project and book, ‚ÄúThe Long Shadow of Chernobyl.‚Äù The recent exhibit of my Chernobyl images in Saint Petersburg, Russia, received remarkable coverage in the Russian media (including six television reports). @thephotosociety #Chernobyl #ExclusionZone #Pripyat #Ukraine #TheLongShadowofChernobyl"
"Tourists are questionably playful as they pose for a photograph near the historic Bernauer Strasse site at the Berlin Wall Memorial. When the Berlin Wall was erected, this area became famous for window escapes from apartment blocks lining the streets. Several people died here when the Wall was first enforced. 
The Berlin Wall Memorial is the central memorial site of German division, located in the middle of the capital. The memorial contains the last piece of Berlin Wall with the preserved grounds behind it and is thus able to convey an impression of how the border fortifications developed until the end of the 1980s. The events that took place here, together with the preserved historical remnants and traces of border obstacles on display help to make the history of Germany's division comprehensible to visitors, although some tourists may not fully grasp the tragedy that took place.
Today, November 9th marks the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the barrier that separated East and West Berlin from 1961 to 1989. The wall completely encircled West Berlin, and a ‚Äúdeath strip‚Äù was added on the East German side in the years following initial construction. Officially, 138 people died trying to escape from East to West. 
@thephotosociety @natgeoimagecollection #BerlinWall #BerlinerStrasse #Germany"
"Photo by @williamalbertallard // IL Buckaroo Ricky Morris Wrangling Horses - Nevada, 1979. 
As part of his bi-annual flash sale, my dear friend and @natgeo colleague, @williamalbertallard (Bill Allard) is offering this signed print for $100 for a three week period beginning November 4th and ending on November 25th at 11:59 pm (EST). This flash sale print is a 6‚Äù x 9‚Äù image on a 9‚Äù x 11‚Äù paper. It is an archival ink jet print on archival watercolor paper.  It is signed IDed in graphite pencil on the front border. Link in Bill‚Äôs bio to purchase. 
Here is what Bill writes about the image: 
Every morning and late afternoon, each buckaroo on the IL cow crew picked one of the five or six horses in their group to ride.  Ricky Morris was one of the buckaroos at the IL Ranch, in Nevada.  The working cowboy has never made much money but he has had a certain independence.  The skills, like wrangling, don‚Äôt come with the hat. They have to be acquired and learned. 
I took this shot in early morning light.  The dust acts as kind of a scrim over the picture. But the key to the image is the rope. The line of that rope cutting the diagonal at the back of Ricky‚Äôs hand, then the sharp vertical descending to the coil of ropes, which is just off-center of the picture ‚Ä¶.that‚Äôs the handle for the photograph. Right there. 
@thephotosociety #BillAllard"
"While going through my archives, I came across this image from the early 1990s, showing a Ukrainian coal miner scrubbing down after a day in the pits. Though they were relatively well paid, miners faced equipment breakdowns and gas explosions as they extracted Ukraine‚Äôs high-grade coal. According to estimates at that time, every million tons of coal cost the life of one miner. After spending a day with the miners in such a harsh and challenging environment, I brought my camera along and continued photographing, even as we cleaned ourselves up. 
@thephotosociety @natgeo #coal #Ukraine #Donbass"
"It‚Äôs Oktoberfest season across the globe. Several years back, dressed appropriately in Bavarian garb, a couple celebrates by making out and loading up on beer during a festival in Bremen, Germany. Cheers‚Äîor Prost, as they say in Germany! 
@thephotosociety #Oktoberfest #Germany #bremen"
"The nuclear accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Chernobyl on April 26, 1986, contaminated thousands of square miles, forcing 150 thousand inhabitants to hastily abandon their homes. Posters of disgraced Politburo members, most likely preparations for upcoming May Day celebrations, litter the floor of an abandoned storage facility in Pripyat, once the largest town in the area with 49 thousand inhabitants. Decades later, the Politburo posters remain a haunting reminder of a tragedy worsened by the initial denial of the Soviet political class. 
My exhibit, ‚ÄúThe Long Shadow of Chernobyl,‚Äù at the ROSPHOTO State Photo Museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia, will be closing September 22. 
The amazing HBO miniseries, ‚ÄúChernobyl‚Äù has been widely viewed in Russia. Due to its success, some in the Russian media announced they would follow up with their own version of the story, in which the CIA is portrayed as one of the culprits of the disaster. Even Russians, however, were making fun of this take. The trailer, which had already premiered on YouTube, has now disappeared. 
@natgeo @thephotosociety @rosphoto.museum #Chernobyl #ukraine"
"Scientists monitor the radiation along the remnants of the Red Forest, one of the most contaminated areas after the explosion of the Chernobyl Nuclear Reactor No.4. The forest‚Äôs name comes from the ginger color of the trees after they died, having absorbed high levels of radiation after the accident. Much of the Red Forest burnt and was buried in ‚Äúwaste graveyards.‚Äù The photograph, which was taken in 1993, is part of my current exhibit ‚ÄúThe Long Shadow of Chernobyl‚Äù at the ROSPHOTO State Photo Museum in St. Petersburg, where 100 of my images chronicling the aftermath of the disaster are on display until September 27. I just returned from the opening and was overwhelmed by the magnitude of coverage it received from the Russian media‚Äîfrom online articles to many television, radio and newspaper interviews. 
@thephotosociety @rosphoto.museum @natgeo #Chernobyl #RedForest #Ukraine"
"Inside the belly of the beast. In my time documenting the aftermath of Chernobyl, I have gone further into the destroyed Reactor No. 4 than any other Western still photographer, each time for only 15-30 minutes. This spot, however, was so contaminated that, despite wearing protective gear, I only had about one minute to shoot. 
This weekend, I am heading off to the opening of my exhibit, ‚ÄúThe Long Shadow of Chernobyl‚Äù at the ROSPHOTO state photo museum in Saint Petersburg, which will show over 100 of my photographs from the aftermath of the Chernobyl disaster. The opening coincides with much renewed interest in the accident after the Chernobyl miniseries on HBO, which was noticed in Russia as well. 
The opening of the exhibit will be on Tuesday, August 6 at 6pm at the ROSPHOTO state photo museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia. 
@thephotosociety @natgeo #Chernobyl #ReactorNumber4 #nuclear #Ukraine #thelongshadowofchernobyl"
"In the 15th and 16th centuries, the silver mines of Schwaz in Tirol, Austria were considered to be the largest in the world. Today, visitors to the mines can watch how strenuous the process used to be.  The miner in the foreground of the image is real and pictured next to a statue of a miner in the background. 
This image, shot a few years ago, was part of a story on the Fuggers‚Äîthe German equivalent of the Medici in Italy, a prosperous merchant family situated in Augsburg, a town in Southern Germany and a commercial center of its time. The silver mines were one of the main sources of the Fugger‚Äôs wealth. Their name stands not only for wealth and clever business management, but also for a far-reaching influence on the political events of that time which shaped the fates of both Germany and Europe. 
@thephotosociety #silvermines #Fuggers #Austria #Tirol"
"Happy Independence Day! July 4 marks the 243rd anniversary of the United States‚Äô independence from Britain. I captured this image years ago, but I believe the feeling of it still resonates today‚Äîhope, questioning, longing‚Äîespecially in the current political climate. 
@thephotosociety #IndependenceDay #July4th #USA"

"Every year around runny-nose-season we make turmeric and ginger spiked honey. It takes maybe 4 minutes and the health properties of these ingredients aren‚Äôt even the most important thing to me - it just tastes so damn good. Sweet and sinus-clearingly fresh. Like a delicious little turmeric and ginger bomb hitting your body.
You make it with a small jar of honey, 2-3 tbsp freshly grated ginger (not dried), 2 tsp turmeric (freshly grated or dried), lemon zest and black pepper. Can be stored at room temp for a few weeks. Use in tea, on yogurt, porridge or eat it by the spoonful. It‚Äôs that good! üèÖüçØ"
"Hands up if you like Caponata ü§öüèªü§öüèªü§öüèªü§öüèªü§öüèª It‚Äôs a classic Sicilian side dish that bursts of flavor. It‚Äôs all made in one pan and tastes epic piled onto a piece of bread.
You make it by cooking cubed aubergine/eggplant, bell pepper, dried oregano and chili flakes in an oiled pan with onion and garlic. After a few minutes you add apple cider vinegar, olives, capers and some fresh tomatoes and let it cook for 20 minutes or until the aubergine is very soft and tender. And then you finish by stirring in a good handful fresh mint üëåüèª a little parsley and some extra olive oil.
It‚Äôs a killer dish and tastes great with pasta as well. Although the kids refuse to eat it because they think üçÜ is the üëø. You can find the full recipe in Green Kitchen Travels but you don‚Äôt really need a recipe for this as you can adapt the amounts pretty much to your liking."

"What is hiding in the sand? üò≤
Tilsandede Kirke, the sanded church of Skagen!
Abandoned in 1792 due to the destruction of sandstorms, today only the partially sanded bell tower remains.
We discover it after a short trek.
‚ùó A tip: enter and climb the steep stairs, from its last window you can enjoy a splendid view!
Thanks @govisitdenmark! üá©üá∞üòâ #visitdenmarkstories"
"Wandering in Aalborg üß°üíõüíöüíôüíú
The historic center of Aalborg is a marvel to be discovered, with old houses, even 17th century, with classic Danish architecture, colorful facades and sloping roofs.
Some of these streets are populated by small art galleries and lead into artistic gardens with a welcoming atmosphere. Don‚Äôt desist from exploring them, it‚Äôs worth losing yourself in these streets and letting time go by, with the sun the colors are turned on and they lend themselves to suggestive pics, like this.

"Sometimes God allows us to walk through things to strengthen and refine us. Stay faithful.
‚Äî
Just a quick thought here: It‚Äôs our tendency to want to fix things in our lives before issues/situations occur (I know it‚Äôs mine as a husband for sure and who wouldn‚Äôt want to?). But maybe sometimes we aren‚Äôt meant to fix them, because a lot of the times (too often than we‚Äôd like), we can‚Äôt. Maybe in these times we are meant to walk through it, be stretched, be uncomfortable, but yet, grow from it. Maybe the Lord is teaching us through them and making sure we rely on and trust Him. Just maybe. Or He definitely is. Thoughts? Feedback? -Mark #goodnewsfeed"

Tonight‚Äôs prayer.
"üôåüí™ From @hertrueworth
„Éª„Éª„Éª
Because in our weakness, HE is made strong. The key is surrender.

If you are feeling overwhelmed like your back might buckle, it could be because you are trying to carry the weight all on your own.

The good news? You don‚Äôt have to carry the weight alone.

Yes, He can carry this burden. Yes, He can take the load off. However, He won‚Äôt grab it from you. You have to let it go from your grip and hand it to Him. Trust Him and depend on Him. He is worthy of your trust. Has He failed you yet?
.
‚ÄúCome to me, all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn from me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.""‚Äù Matthew‚Ä¨ ‚Ä≠11:28-30‚Ä¨ ‚Ä≠ESV‚Ä¨‚Ä¨
.
ü§çfor the woman who is feeling heavy and burdened, pray this prayer with meü§çüôèüèΩ
.
Heavenly Father,

Oh God, my heart is heavy right now, but I trust You with it. I do not have a lot to offer right now, but Lord I give You my whole heart, and I no longer want to lean on my own knowledge and understanding because this is what has caused me to feel burdened. I know that in all things You work for the good of those who love You, who have been called according to Your purpose. I give all praise and thanks to You, Father. For You are the One who makes me strong. I surrender every burden and weight to Your careful hands.

In Jesus‚Äô name, amen."

"Not gonna lie, I‚Äôm kinda bummed Instagram is up again.

It was bliss, while it lasted.
I didn‚Äôt know it was back until I just went to the store, and as I was waiting in line, the people ahead of me, faces buried in their phones, were oblivious to the cashiers saying ‚Äúnext customer please‚Äù.
I thought to myself, ‚ÄúInstagram must be back.‚Äù
Then I stood on my tiptoes to see the screens of those ahead of me, and sure enough... all scrolling on Instagram.
Oh well, it was good while it lasted.
This has got me thinking: Why not go ahead and pretend it‚Äôs still down, and enjoy this holiday as much as I used to enjoy holidays before social media was a thing.
Yep. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôll be doing.
Tuning into my gratitude for my life and the people in it, and tuning out of Instagram.
Happy holidays and see you tomorrow! üòÉ"

"You spend most of your life in your head, so make it a nice place to be. üí•
Lately I‚Äôve been putting focused energy into the practice of talking to myself the way I‚Äôd talk to a friend: with love, understanding, and encouragement.
When my inner voice gets mean‚Äî which is way more often than I even realized before becoming more present to it‚Äî I stop, rewind, and take control of that voice, rather than letting it control me. Then I make it apologize and rephrase its original statement. üôå
I am actively retraining the crappy voice in my head, and I‚Äôm starting to feel the positive impact of this work throughout my day... and THAT makes me want to be even more diligent in this practice.
After all, I would never be as harsh, judgmental, discouraging, and unforgiving to a friend, as I am to myself... and I‚Äôm ready to change that now. For good.
I‚Äôm ready to be my own best friend. Who‚Äôs with me?üí•

ùê¶ùêÆùê¨ùê≠ ùê°ùêöùêØùêû ùê©ùê´ùêû ùê•ùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ùêûùêßùêûùêù ùê°ùêöùê¢ùê´) & ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêùùêöùê≤ ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùêüùê¢ùêßùê¢ùê¨ùê° ùêÆùê© ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin. 92 year old Ivy Heath has vascular dementia. Sarah, a Senior Support Worker at Belong Limited (a charitable organization specializing in supporting people with dementia in north west England) told me about her: ‚ÄúShe has memory loss, she does get confused sometimes, she does get angry sometimes, she does get sad, upset. She‚Äôs a worrier, she worries, and wants to make sure everyone else is happy.‚Äù Sarah was clearly fond of Ivy. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs so cute, so loving, she‚Äôs adorable. She‚Äôs just sweet. She‚Äôs just like your grandma. You‚Äôd love her like you‚Äôd love your grandma." You can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin. 76 year-old Tom didn‚Äôt speak much in our interview. Going through the transcript now I see myself asking: ‚ÄúWhat about growing older Tom? What are your thoughts on that?‚Äù Tom replies, ‚ÄúHopefully, yes.‚Äù I think he was being funny, but his sense of humour was so dry it was hard to tell. I asked him what his hopes for the future were. He says: ‚Äúeveryone hopes for the future just have to hope that it carries on.‚Äù Tom reminds me of my own father. Unlike Tom, my father doesn‚Äôt have dementia, but at 80, everything‚Äôs slowing down. But like my dad, Tom seems to just take it as it comes. He doesn‚Äôt dwell on getting older or the difficulties that have come with it. I, on the other hand, at nearly half their age, worry all the time about much smaller things... A lot of us, when we‚Äôre young, don‚Äôt place a lot of value in seniors. This work I‚Äôve been doing on dementia has helped me to understand the wisdom of age and the arrogance of youth. I wish I understood that earlier in my life. Let the seniors in your life know they‚Äôre valued, before they‚Äôre gone. You can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin ‚ÄúYes, I was diagnosed with that,‚Äù says 86 year-old Mary Griffiths when I asked her about dementia. But she wasn‚Äôt convinced: ‚ÄúSomebody said I was forgetting things - I don‚Äôt feel any different! I can remember quite well‚Ä¶ I haven‚Äôt gone quite crackers yet!‚Äù She lives in a care home specialising in supporting people with dementia in north west England. ‚ÄúI try not to think about dementia, ‚Äú she says. ‚ÄúI just think, well, if I don‚Äôt think about it, it might go away.‚Äù The @Guardian published this work. You can read the article by following the link in my bio and you can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld. And thank you to everyone sharing their own experience of friends and family living with dementia. It‚Äôs been deeply moving.
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin ‚ÄúSometimes I don‚Äôt know, sometimes I do know.‚Äù This is 77 year-old July Hopkins describing her life with dementia. ‚ÄúI just, I just want to know what I was knowing. You understand? But sometimes it‚Äôs just okay.‚Äù I met July through a storytelling project on dementia made with my not for profit organisation @WitnessChange. I was deeply moved by the stories told by the individuals I met. They are just a few among millions. This chapter of the work was produced in northern England. #Dementia kills more people than any other disease in England and Wales. In 2017 it affected 50 million people globally. It will increase to over 150 million people by 2050. These shocking statistics are our parents and grandparents. Very soon they may be you and me. With no cure in sight, we can‚Äôt just think about how we avoid dying from dementia. We have to consider how to live with it. The @Guardian published this work. You can read the article by following the link in my bio and you can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld
"Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin. ‚ÄúI feel like, ‚Äòwhat about me, I have a voice, I have a brain, I can hear you,‚Äô but they think you don‚Äôt know, there‚Äôs something wrong with you, you can‚Äôt understand."" Fred is funny. He‚Äôs smart. But Dementia and Parkinson‚Äôs disease can make it difficult for the 78 year-old to express himself. Give him a chance though and he has a lot to say. He talks about dementia: ‚ÄúMy short term memory is gone. So you ask me about my last time, I can't remember, but you ask me about what happened on some day, I remember that.‚Äù One of the things that really upsets him the most is how he is treated: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs frustrating, really frustrating, especially when people treat you like an idiot, in a wheel chair, like your brain is gone‚Ä¶ what I also find frustrating is that they don‚Äôt talk to you.‚Äù ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
There‚Äôs a lot online about how to communicate with people with dementia. I found this list helpful. It can help to:
* speak clearly and slowly, using short sentences * make eye contact with the person when they're talking or asking questions *give them time to respond, because they may feel pressured if you try to speed up their answers *encourage them to join in conversations with others, where possible *let them speak for themselves during discussions about their welfare or health issues *try not to patronise them, or ridicule what they say *acknowledge what they have said, even if they don't answer your question, or what they say seems out of context ‚Äì show that you've heard them and encourage them to say more about their answer *give them simple choices ‚Äì avoid creating complicated choices or options for them *use other ways to communicate ‚Äì such as rephrasing questions because they can't answer in the way they used to

In my bio is a link to the article where these photos were published and you can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld"
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_Robin ‚ÄúThe thing that gives me joy, to a degree, is just being able to sit, be with her, hold her hand and just tell her I love her,‚Äù says Allan Bishop. ‚ÄúI get joy just that she‚Äôs still here.‚Äù Allan‚Äôs wife Kathleen (in this photo) was not able to answer my questions so Allan stepped in. They agreed to participate in this series I‚Äôve been making on #dementia, which continues work I‚Äôve been doing on mental health issues and neurological disorders for the last eight years - @onedayinmyworld. Amplifying the voices of people living at the heart of the issues we document is a central pillar of the work we do at @Witnesschange. In order to extend the reach of these voices we always try to find media partners to share the stories we‚Äôre helping to be told. The Guardian published this work. You can read the article published in The @Guardian by following the link in my bio and you can see more stories from this series by following @onedayinmyworld
"A few days ago folks at @witness_change hung some posters in Valencia. We thought it important to remind people that Refugees have lived through extreme difficulties - it‚Äôs why they fled their homes. And that life only becomes more difficult when they find themselves isolated after reaching safety. We told them (on the poster) that it doesn‚Äôt have to be this way. #WelcomeRefugees. Here‚Äôs the post in the @onedayinmyworld account:
//
@WitnessChange created an outdoor¬†exhibition¬†featuring images of refugees standing in The Mediterranean waiting for a European country to accept them. We posted these on walls in Valencia, the first European city many refugees see. Despite the toxic language of some politicians, @onedayinmyworld, along with many in European host communities, want to say #refugeeswelcome"
‚ÄòDreams of Life.‚Äô In The Guardian Weekend magazine today from work I‚Äôve been making about dementia. Will be sharing more in the coming days on @onedayinmyworld
Photo @Hammond_Robin. Zimbabwe‚Äôs former president Robert Mugabe is dead. I worked in Zimbabwe during what was arguably the country's most difficult years. I documented those at the front lines of Mugabe‚Äôs war against his own people and the decline of a beautiful and once promising nation. I grew a great affection for Zimbabwe and its embattled people which only made me more angry at those who stole their futures - people like President Mugabe. There was a lot of hope when Emmerson Mnangagwa wrestled power from Mugabe in 2017. I didn‚Äôt share it. The corrupt structures remained and taking charge of them was the man responsible for the massacre of thousands of Zimbabweans and the architect of the repression that defined Mugabe‚Äôs rule. No tears here for Robert Mugabe - only for a beautiful country that deserves better leaders.
Photo @hammond_robin for @Witness_Change. ‚ÄúSince Donald Trump was elected in 2016, things have changed quite a bit for me. I've felt a lot less secure. I've felt a lot more threatened.‚Äù I met Joann at her home in Titusville, Florida while working on the US chapter of @WhereLoveIsIllegal. I‚Äôm personally no fan of guns but given the very real threats many trans people face, I can understand why Joann keeps one. We spoke about many things other than politics. Joann told me, for example, about her transition which for her truly started when she had a breakdown and was hospitalised: ‚ÄúI did the boy things that people wanted me to do, and I kept pushing my feelings inward. On the outside, I did the things that boys and men were supposed to do. This continued for 30 years until July of 1989. That first day in a hospital, all my thoughts and actions of wanting to be a woman came rushing out. Now that is old history but it was the day that I felt that I let my feelings out. It was a day that my new life began.‚Äù I‚Äôm grateful to @thecenterorlando for introducing me to Joann. To see more of this US chapter of Where Love Is Illegal follow @whereloveisillegal
Photo @hammond_robin for @Witness_Change. Another hero falls. I met Marc in Cameroon in 2014, the country of his birth, the country that persecuted him, the country he chose to stay in rather than flee, because he knew his fight was a virtuous one. In 2005 Marc spent 12 months in prison ‚Äì charged with ‚Äòcommitting homosexuality‚Äô. He told me, ‚ÄúIt was a nightmare for me, but I transformed this nightmare into an opportunity ‚Äì it gave me the chance to denounce to the international community the situation of discrimination against people in my country for their sexual orientation or gender identity. Thanks to that a LGBT movement was born in Cameroon‚Äù. Marc may be gone, but his courage continues to inspire all of us who believe in equality. To see Marc‚Äôs story and others from the project please follow @whereloveisillegal
Photo @hammond_robin ‚ÄúAfter all the excitement I then got my top surgery and It was a memorable moment for me because I wouldn‚Äôt have to layer up my clothing anymore and I was able to wear my shirt off and feel more comfortable in my skin.‚Äù Terry is a transgender man living in New York City. Until recently, Terry lived with his father and grandmother in Long Island. They (along with his aunt) were unique in Terry‚Äôs family for supporting him. After they both passed, Terry was homeless. He briefly lived with a friend from school while transitioning, but now lives in Trinity Place Shelter @tp_shelter, a transitional shelter for LGBTQI+ young people. ‚ÄúI didn't stay with my family because they don't accept me. They mis-gendered me ever since I was 11. They knew that I'm trans for about 10 years now. They called me my dead name. They call me a female still.‚Äù Some estimates put the number of homeless youth in The US who identify as LGBTQI+ as high as 40%. Many are homeless because of the stark choice given to them by their parents - either they deny their identity and stay home or live their truth and be homeless. For many, like Terry, this feels like no choice at all when hiding who they are  to make parents feel better can lead to severe mental health issues. To see more of this US chapter of Where Love Is Illegal follow @whereloveisillegal
"syafakallah guruku tersayang

30 tahun lalu, seorang guru ngaji kampung yg sangat sederhana sedang melintasi jalan setapak menuju ke surau

ga sengaja, ia mendengar suara anak kecil lagi azan. Suara azan itu bukan dari surau, tapi dari sebuah gubuk kecil. ternyata anak itu sedang latihan azan bersama emaknya di rumah. Sang guru langsung menghampiri mereka ‚ÄúIbu, biar saya ajak anak ibu ini ke surau, agar dia bisa belajar ngaji di sana. Anak ini memiliki bakat suara yg bagus,‚Äù kata sang guru

Sejak saat itu, sang guru melatih si anak kecil di suraunya. Dan kelak, anak itu beberapa kali menjuarai lomba baca Quran tingkat nasional dan internasional

Setelah kuliah di Mesir, anak itu menjadi guru ngaji seperti gurunya. Alhamdulillah lewat dakwah anak itu, banyak anak muda yg kembali kepada Allah, bertaubat dan berhijrah

Semoga setiap kebaikan yg dilakukan  anak itu, menjadi pahala jariyah untuk sang guru
_______________

Bang Uin, itu panggilan akrab saya untuk guru yg telah membimbing saya dari nol ini ‚†Ä
‚ÄúSaya akan pulang Bang Uin, guruku...‚Äù
‚†Ä
syafakallah, wa kataballahu ajraka
___________

slide kedua itu anak beliau yg kecil. Dulu saya spt itu, mengaji di surau setiap magrib. Pake pengeras suara. Kalo pulang ke rumah, almarhumah Emak saya suka evaluasi bacaan saya. Saya tanya, emak dengar dr mana? dari pengeras suara di surau yg terdengar sampe ke ujung kampung, katanyaüòä

duh, waktu cepat banget berlalu..."
"Report hasil #sedekahsampah bulan November 2019

Kegiatan:
‚Ä¢ mengkampanyekan penggunaan #kajianstarterkit saat taklim, dimana peserta membawa tumbler sendiri dan bisa refill minuman gratis yg disediakan #pemudahijrah di depan masjid
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ melakukan sedekah sampah. Mengumpulkan sampah kardus dan plastik dari jamaah kajian rabu dan sabtu setiap pekan nya
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ menyerahkan sedekah sampah kepada partner, yaitu bank sampah resik. Dan menkonversi sampah menjadi uang untuk program beasiswa anak pemulung, atau bantuan sosial lainnya
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ membuat program re-use sampah bersama anak2, di #lesswastekid saat kajian #ladiesday di masjid Allatif

Teman2, yuk ikutan, biar makin banyak sampah yg kita sedekahkah, jadi makin banyak anak pemulung yg bisa kita bantu

Buat jamaah yg mau support wakaf mobil bak, atau triseda.. mangga japri ke Aji 081395365242

Program #sedekahsampah #masjidlesswaste & #masjidperadaban ini dibina oleh guru2 kita #barisanbangunnegeri kolabs sama kang @gungunsaptari founder @kangpisman 
#hananattaki #pemudahijrah @lesswasteshift @shiftmedia.id"
"Merampungkan konsep lesswaste movement utk #masjidperadaban ... bersama dengan founder gagasan @kangpisman kota Bandung

InsyaAllah jadi berita baik untuk warga Bandung, karena sedikit demi sedikit masalah sampah ini akan kita beresin bersama2 sampai ke sumbernya

Berawal dari masjid, kita tampilkan Islam yg rahmatan lil Indonesia
. .#barisanbangunnegeri #lesswaste #sedekahsampah #santribangunnegeri #hananattaki #shift #pemudahijrah"
"Alhamdulillah kemarin event kajian #barisanbangunnegeri dan #sedekahsampah di masjid MRKR Bintaro bersama gurunda Ustadz @oemar_mita berjalan lancar dan seru
________________
Uang hasil sedekah sampah ini akan kita kumpulin utk membiayai project sosial lain nya, seperti beasiswa enterpreneurship buat anak pemulung, atau kursus bengkel, jahit, dll... agar anak2 jalanan bisa punya skill utk berkarya dan mandiri

Doain ya, mudah2an makin banyak yg join bareng para guru mengisi #masjidperadaban .
_______________
Foto dan kegiatan oleh sahabat2ku #santribangunnegeri chapter Bintaro"
"Dari sejak 2015, sebagian besar kegiatan dakwah saya dihabiskan di meja diskusi...bukan di mimbar

Kita berusaha menjadikan dakwah ini bukan sekedar ceramah, tapi harokah (movement) utk memprogram perubahan di tengah2 umat ke arah yg lebih baik

Tanpa kita sadari, di meja2 diskusi inilah lahir trend hijrah, crowd taklim, konten2 dakwah di sosmed, fenomena positif ttg pemuda, dll

Bukan hanya sendiri, tapi meja ini sering diramaikan oleh teman2 guru #barisanbangunnegeri dan para murid #santribangunnegeri 
Masih banyak yg perlu kita diskusikan. Masih banyak yg harus kita kerjakan secara kongkrit. Untuk membangun Indonesia bersama2. Jadi, kita ga boleh cepat lelah. Ga boleh gampang bosan

Tetap semangat sampai berhasil memanggungkan kembali Islam di muka bumi menjadi ""Rahmatan lil alamin""
.
."

It‚Äôs @BotoxCosmetic Day! Make sure to head to the link in my bio, swipe up in my stories or visit bit.ly/2Qqc5k5 to get it before it‚Äôs gone! üôåüèº .
BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic is FDA approved to temporarily make moderate to severe frown lines, crow‚Äôs feet, and forehead lines look better in adults. .
Talk to your doctor about BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic and whether it‚Äôs right for you. There are risks with this product - The effects of BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic may spread hours to weeks after injection causing serious symptoms. Alert your doctor right away as difficulty swallowing, speaking, breathing, eye problems or muscle weakness can be a sign of a life-threatening condition. Patients with these conditions before injection are at the highest risk. Side effects may include allergic reactions, neck and injection-site pain, fatigue and headache. Allergic reactions can include rash, welts, asthma symptoms, and dizziness. Don‚Äôt receive BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic if there‚Äôs a skin infection. Tell your doctor your medical history, muscle or nerve conditions (including ALS/Lou Gehrig's disease, myasthenia gravis, or Lambert-Eaton syndrome), and medications, including botulinum toxins, as these may increase the risk of serious side effects. .
BOTOX¬Æ Cosmetic is available by prescription only."

Multonomah falls, one of the many natural wonders on the west coast‚ú® I‚Äôm often asked how I edit my photos and I want to show you lighting process most of my photos go through. If you swipe all the way to the last one you can see the original colors. It‚Äôs crazy to me how dark and desaturated it looks when in real life it was so much more vibrant. I use @adobecreativecloud and my first step was to put it in @Adobe @Lightroom where I was able to bring the yellows and oranges forward more like I remember it. The next step is adding a filter for a sightly more vintage feel. I then brightened it further and fine tuned some details like bringing the blue of my pants to a more natural tone. I hope this helps some of you!! More photos and details for the look plus a surprise proposal story (not mine lol) on www.hapatime.com now ü•∞ Link in profile P.S @photoshop for iPad is now available and I think I might just have to get one! It makes it super easy to edit (especially on the go!) üôåüèº #adobepartner #adobemax

It'll forever be very special to me. I'm so glad to see we kept going despite all the prejudice we encountered especially in the beginning, that we kept doing what we know best, with love, without fear. Farewell Bizim Hikaye! "Wandering through the ancient forest of Yakushima...‚ú®üåøüôàüå≥ Surrounded by ocean on the southern point of Kyushu, this beautiful little island is known for its unique ecosystem ‚Äî Being a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site the island is covered with extensive cedar forests which contain some of Japan's oldest living trees. A mystical little paradise with local roaming monkeys, deer, peaceful forests, moss covered rocks & waterfalls.

@visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed

"When magic fills the sky... ‚ú®üéàüåà This special event only happens once a year in Japan on the island of Kyushu, where hundreds of hot-air balloons float through the sky at The Saga Balloon Festival. It‚Äôs been so refreshing to explore new places which reignite your sense of discovery ‚Äî places you never knew existed, places which allowed you to see the world in a whole new light...‚ú®@visitjapanau ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

"The Sakurai Futamigaura of Meoto-iwa‚Ä¶‚ú®üáØüáµ‚õ© Along the coastline of Futamigaura you can find this magical white Tori gate ‚Äì White is the colour traditionally used for sacredness & are known to symbolise the boundary between the spirit and our human world. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I loved learning the story behind this sacred place and the standing rocks in the ocean. It is believed that the Ise Futamigaura of the sunrise is married to the Sakurai Futamigaura of the sunset‚Äî together, these two rocks form a symbol of happy marriage. Every year in May during springs low tide period, a sacred rope is used to tie the rocks together & the sun sets exactly between the two rocks. ‚ù§Ô∏è @visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä"
"A place to dream... Floating four-thousand feet high above Japan. ‚ú®üéàüíú I‚Äôve always been fascinated by Japan, travelling here can at times feel I have transported into another world ‚Äì one filled with in-depth culture, rituals, and a way of life which inspires me to understand more.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
This series was captured during The Saga Balloon Festival ‚Äì¬†a very special morning where you can see hundreds of balloons float over Japan‚Äôs island of Kyushu. @visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä"
"Hello Japan + fields of cosmos flowers in full bloom... ‚ú®üå∏‚ú®üå∏ Last month I had the chance to explore @visitjapanau & I am so excited to finally share the beauty found throughout this incredibly diverse country. Exploring the more hidden & off the beaten track parts of Japan ‚Äî We travelled throughout the southwestern island of Kyushu, a beautiful region known for its active volcanoes, waterfalls, lush ancient forests and semitropical coastlines ‚Äî There are so many places here I never knew existed & have left me so inspired to discover more. ‚úß

"If you don't like the meats....look away now.

‚ÄúI just feel like I should be doing better.  I‚Äôm nowhere near retirement.  I‚Äôm working two jobs: I‚Äôm a licensed tour guide, and I make videos for businesses.  But even that‚Äôs not enough, so recently I‚Äôve started working for the census.  I don‚Äôt want to run down the census: it‚Äôs fine, it‚Äôs great, it‚Äôs important work.  But I‚Äôm ashamed of it.  Because I‚Äôm sixty-five years old, I'm a college graduate, and I‚Äôm supposed to be done by now.  I'm supposed to be coasting.  But I‚Äôm not even close.  I feel like I still don‚Äôt even have a grip on the basics: how to make a living, how to keep my house in order, how to take care of myself.  And it feels shameful.  I feel not grown up.  Like I should have learned all of this so long ago.  And I‚Äôm afraid people will think it‚Äôs pathetic.  Worse than that.  They‚Äôll think I‚Äôm incapable.  So I‚Äôve been keeping a lot hidden.  I haven‚Äôt even told my colleagues about the census.  And that‚Äôs one thing I‚Äôm trying to work on‚Äî not keeping things hidden.  Because I know this shame isn‚Äôt healthy.  It isn‚Äôt right.  I‚Äôm luckier than 99 percent of people.  I‚Äôve been sober for 39 years.  I have the greatest wife of 32 years.  I don't have any crippling debt.  I'm doing OK.  I shouldn‚Äôt have to hide my situation.  And being more open has helped.  Because once I start telling people, and I see they‚Äôre not judging me, and that they‚Äôre still loving me-- the shame tends to disappear.‚Äù
‚ÄúI vividly remember watching cartoons as a kid and seeing Bugs Bunny standing on a lily pad, playing ‚ÄòHello My Darling,‚Äô with a banjo in his hand and a drum on his back.  I‚Äôve always wanted to play music myself.  But it‚Äôs so hard to make a living at it.  For awhile I was playing the banjo in restaurants.  But I couldn‚Äôt make it work.  So I thought I‚Äôd try the Bugs Bunny thing.‚Äù
‚ÄúI moved from Texas three years ago.  I was way too nice at first.  I was out here in New York trying to exemplify Christ, and people were taking advantage of me.  I was getting run over.  So I had to get more stern.  Don't get me wrong-- I‚Äôm the same nice person, just more firm in my actions. Especially in the work environment.  My first job was working as a recruiter for a retail company.  And one day I‚Äôm on the computer, you know, recruiting people, which is my job-- when my boss comes in and says: ‚ÄòYou need to get to the floor, now!‚Äô I was in shock, so I just did what I was told.  But I knew the next time I‚Äôd have to say something.  My job was important to me, but respect was even more important. Because if I allowed him to treat me that way, it was just going to happen over and over.  And sure enough it happened again the next week.  I was in the middle of an important task, and he gave me a command.  There was no question mark on the end of the sentence.  There was no use of my name.  So I told him: ‚ÄòIf you want me to do something, you‚Äôll have to ask me the proper way.‚Äô He was shocked.  He looked at me like: ‚ÄòI know you‚Äôre not talking to me!‚Äô But then he asked me the proper way.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe started early in school.  Seven guys from my church got together and started practicing in a basement.  Michael Armstrong on drums.  Robert Burton on lead guitar.  James Cloud on bass.  Charles Easton on the piano.  Then we had our three singers: Wilbur Simmons, Dennis Austin Ray, and me.  At first we just sang on the sidewalk.  Or even just walking down the street.  But eventually we were getting real invitations to perform: parties, barbeques, little shows here and there.  Then we got bigger and bigger.  Until one night in 1969 we‚Äôre backing up Bobby Darin in front of 5,000 people at a college in New Jersey.  I was only fourteen at the time.  It was ecstasy.  The next ten years we toured up and down the east coast.  From Montreal to Pompano Beach, Florida.  We peaked in 1976.  That was the year we were booked forty weeks in advance.  There were signed contracts everywhere.  Even Frankie Valli wanted one of our songs.  But things fell apart.  Our rhythm guitarist died.  Some of the instrumentalists got married.  And Dennis went off on his own.  I was heartbroken.  Truly heartbroken. For ten years I‚Äôd done nothing but sing and party.  I hadn‚Äôt gone to school.  I hadn‚Äôt worked a job.  So I came to New York and did what I could to survive.  I‚Äôve worked as a super.  A maintenance man.  A baker at Kripsy Kreme.  But for the last eight years I‚Äôve been homeless.  Right now I‚Äôm sleeping in the hallway of a building where I collect the trash.  But I was in a great band once.  We were called ‚ÄòThe Uniques.‚Äô And I‚Äôve told you everyone‚Äôs name but mine: Vaughnterrol Lockette, lead tenor.‚Äù
‚ÄúAll of the young people are leaving.  You have to say ‚Äògoodbye,‚Äô over and over again.  One of my best friends went to Chile.  Another went to Spain.  Another went to Argentina to earn money for her mother‚Äôs cancer treatment.  My brother left five years ago.  And now I‚Äôm gone too.  Before I came to New York, I went to pick up some paperwork at my university.  We used to have ten classrooms full of people.  Now half of them are empty.  There are some people who choose to stay.  I have a cousin that swears he‚Äôll never leave.  He says that there‚Äôs a chance things will work out.  But that‚Äôs very rare for someone our age.  The grown-ups stay because they have their whole lives in Venezuela: maybe not their jobs anymore, but their houses and their cars.  But the young people want opportunities.  I want to be a designer.  But since there aren‚Äôt any design jobs, I‚Äôd have to be a freelancer.  But that‚Äôs also silly.  Because nobody has money for art or design.  Everyone needs their money for necessities.  So I‚Äôd be forced to take a job outside my career.  Anything I could get.  And that‚Äôs why I left.  Either you stay in Venezuela and make the decisions you have to.  Or you leave and make the decisions you want to.‚Äù
‚ÄúI grew up pretty well honestly.  I didn‚Äôt have bad parents‚Äîa little ‚Äòhelicoptery‚Äô maybe, but doing the best they could.  I was just a bad kid.  I don‚Äôt even remember a lot of my teenage years.  I was always popping pills.  Just a ‚Äòfuck you, parents‚Äô kind of thing.  When I wasn‚Äôt alone in my room, I was picking fights with them.  I hurt my mother the most because she cared the most.  Dad cared.  But Mom really cared.  Throwing me out wasn‚Äôt easy for her.  But one night I had a really bad Xanax high.  I blacked out.  Messed up the house.  They won‚Äôt even tell me exactly what I did-- but it must have been violent.  Because the cops came.  The court put an order of protection against me.  The last thing I said to my parents in the courtroom was: ‚ÄòI never want to see or hear from you again.‚Äô Then a few months later I called and begged to come home.  But it was too late.  My dad just kept saying: ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt.‚Äô There were long pauses.  And hesitation.  But he stuck to it.  It‚Äôs been eighteen months now.  I got clean.  Mainly because I‚Äôve been living in a shelter on Staten Island, and I just didn‚Äôt have the access.  Right now I‚Äôm trying to get into a longer term shelter.  Trying to find a job.  NY State has some scholarships that I‚Äôm looking at.  Dad‚Äôs coming to pick me up in an hour.  They‚Äôve invited me home for Thanksgiving.  I‚Äôm scared shitless.  It‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve been home in over a year, and I‚Äôm spending three days with them.  I‚Äôm just hoping it‚Äôs like a normal Thanksgiving-- before I was a shit.‚Äù
‚ÄúThere was this interesting piece in The Times a couple weeks ago about people in solitary confinement.  And one of the guys said the worst thing is having all that time to think.  And that‚Äôs my problem too. When I‚Äôm alone in my apartment, I just start ruminating.  About my finances.  About my medical conditions.  About not taking good enough care of my mom.  But as long as I can find my bar, I‚Äôm fine.  It‚Äôs just a couple blocks from my house.  And when I open the door, and look in, I see the place is full of people like me: people with health problems, retirees with nothing to do, a lot of us are unkempt, unshaven.  And everyone has a weakness for alcohol.  I get a warm welcome every time I walk in.  It‚Äôs the only place I don‚Äôt berate myself for being a dirt bag.‚Äù
‚ÄúNobody would give us a chance.  We were in our early twenties.  We had two young kids.  We were working, but living check to check.  At the time we were staying in the projects with my mother-in-law, but my kids were growing up, so we needed our own place.  But all the rental brokers wanted to see our bank statements.  And we had no savings.  We didn‚Äôt even have accounts.  Then one day I was walking down the avenue, and I saw a super fixing up an empty apartment.  I told him I needed to speak to the landlord directly.  No brokers.  And I guess he liked my vibe, because he gave me the name: Ronald Petrowski.  When I called Mr. Petrowski, I explained everything.  I told him we needed a chance.  He agreed to meet me and my husband at Lenny‚Äôs Pizzeria.  He bought us a plain pie and listened to our story.  He‚Äôd grown up poor himself, so he knew the struggle.  And he gave us a chance.  We‚Äôve been in that apartment for 35 years now, and I‚Äôve paid him every cent.  We‚Äôve fallen on hard times.  At one point I owed him an entire year of rent.  But he was so gracious.  He never sent us an eviction notice.  Every time he came to collect, he‚Äôd sit at our kitchen table, have a cup of coffee, and listen to our situation.  Mr. Petrowski is my hero.  He sold the building a couple years ago, but we still keep in touch.  That man gave me a home to raise my children.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe scene was different back then.  All the adult clubs were mob controlled.  It all flowed up to some guy named Matty The Horse.  Honestly the mob guys never bothered me.  They were cool, and I liked how they dressed.  They wore custom made suits.  And they went to hair stylists, not barbers.  These guys wouldn‚Äôt even let you touch their hair when you were fucking them.  Not that I ever fucked them.  Because I never turned tricks.  Well, except for one time.  I took a job from this woman named Madame Blanche.  She controlled all the high dollar prostitutes back then.  She was like the Internet-- could get you anything you wanted.  And all the powerful men came to her because she never talked.  She set me up with a department store magnate who wanted a black girl dressed like a maid.  I thought I could do it.  But when I got to his hotel room, he wanted to spank me with a real belt.  So that was it for me.  I was done.  But Madame Blanche set my best friend Vicki up with The President every time he came to New York.  And don‚Äôt you dare write his name cause I can‚Äôt afford the lawyers. But he‚Äôd always spend an hour with her.  He‚Äôd send a car to pick her up, bring her to his hotel room, put a Secret Service agent in front of the door, and get this: all he ever did was eat her pussy!‚Äù
‚ÄúMy stripper name was Tanqueray.  Back in the seventies I was the only black girl making white girl money.  I danced in so many mob clubs that I learned Italian.  Black girls weren‚Äôt even allowed in some of these places.  Nothing but guidos with their pinky rings and the one long fingernail they used for cocaine.  I even did a full twenty minutes in the place they filmed Saturday Night Fever.  But I made my real money on the road.  Three grand on some trips.  Every time Fort Dix had their pay day, they‚Äôd bring me in as a feature and call me ‚ÄòMs. Black Universe‚Äô or some shit like that.  I had this magic trick where I‚Äôd put baby bottle tops on my nipples and squirt real milk, then I‚Äôd pull a cherry out of my G-string and feed it to the guy in the front row.  But I never used dildos on stage or any shit like that.  Never fucked the booking agents.  Never fucked the clients.  In fact, one night after a show, I caught another dancer sneaking off to the Tate Hotel with our biggest tipper.  Not allowed.  So the next night we put a little itching powder in her G-string.  Boy did she put on a show that night.  Didn‚Äôt see her again until ‚ÄòThe Longest Yard‚Äô with Burt Reynolds.  So I guess she finally fucked the right one.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy mom threw me out of the house at seventeen for getting pregnant, then had me arrested when I tried to get my clothes. Then she fucked the head of parole to try to keep me in jail. She was some prime pussy back then. But the warden did some tests on me and found out I was smart, so I got a scholarship to go anywhere in New York. I chose the Fashion Institute of Technology, which I hated. But by that time I was already getting work making costumes for the strippers and porn stars in Times Square. All my friends were gay people, because they never judged me. All I did was gay bars: drag queen contests, Crisco Disco, I loved the whole scene. And I couldn‚Äôt get enough of the costumes. My friend Paris used to sit at the bar and sell stolen clothes from Bergdorf and Lord and Taylors, back before they had sensor tags. So I had the best wardrobe: mink coats, 5 inch heels, stockings with seams up the back. I looked like a drag queen, honey. One night a Hasidic rabbi tried to pick me up because he thought I was a tranny. I had to tell him: ‚ÄòBaby, this is real fish!‚Äù

Is it the weekend yet? Tayto wants to know...
Sustainability is something that always felt really overwhelming for me, so a few years ago, I started thinking about changes I could make in small, doable steps. The first and most noticeable was changing my relationship with shopping. I've now adopted a slow fashion approach that feels good for me. My spending habits have changed too. I used to be focused on accumulating things, but now I prefer investing in experiences that will enrich my creativity. When I do buy things, I know the deeper why. When it comes to beauty, I use up products completely and am mindful about what I will realistically use on a regular basis. I've been using this @eosproducts hand cream every. single. day. since I got it and I love it even more because it's made with sustainably sourced shea butter. When I started this journey of exploring sustainability, I was scared because I thought I'd be losing things I loved like the fun of putting together a new outfit and the comforting pleasure of a beauty routine. Turns out, I didn't lose those things ‚Äì they expanded and shifted to change with me. Whenever I start feeling overwhelmed, I look back at my trail of small steps I've taken over the years knowing that they all added up to get me where I am now. Tbh I gotta say, I like it here! All I have to do today is focus on the next small step right in front of me, knowing if I follow that simple rule, I'll like where I land in the future. #eoshandcream #eossheabetter #eosawesome #sponsored
Spent the holiday weekend in the Midwest and it was even better having this little FLOOF with us! ‚ù§Ô∏èSide note: please look at the last photo because OMG THOSE LIL EARS PEEKIN‚Äô OUT!! üò≠ü•∞
What #slowfashion means to me: 1) shopping less and creating outfits with things I already have in my closet. 2) when I do shop, shopping more secondhand. 3) if I buy something new, asking myself ‚Äúis this something I can wear for years to come?‚Äù With the holidays coming up, shopping is definitely on my mind. I‚Äôve made a short list of purchases to help keep me on a focused and mindful path this year. What about you? Have your shopping habits changed? How are you approaching holiday shopping this year? I‚Äôd love to know ‚ù§Ô∏è Outfit details: everything I‚Äôm wearing is at least 2-3 years old, except for jewelry which was gifted to me.
See the heart in the right corner? That‚Äôs the @CVS_Beauty Mark and it means this photo hasn‚Äôt been retouched. #ad (Fun fact: I‚Äôve never retouched my own IG photos!) Last year¬†CVS¬†announced its commitment to healthy standards and transparency in their beauty imagery by introducing this¬†CVS¬†Beauty Mark to highlight images that haven‚Äôt been materially altered. Now, they‚Äôre taking another step and making ingredient transparency more accessible too. If you‚Äôre choosing to move away from certain ingredients in your personal care products,¬†CVS¬†now has thousands (!!!) of Clean Beauty products. You can also look for the little green ‚ÄúParaben and Pthalate Free‚Äù sticker on their¬†CVS¬†Health and Beauty 360 packaging. Click the link in my bio to check out some of my favorite products! Oh, and don‚Äôt forget: you can get money back and earn rewards when you buy beauty products by joining the¬†CVS¬†Beauty Club! #BeautyUnaltered

"Thank you to everyone who shared your tips for fighting stress on my IGTV giveaway! Here are the 5 winners who will receive the entire @cledepeaubeaute Key Radiance Care range that I‚Äôve been talking about recently. I love these small, doable steps for dissolving stress ‚Äì I'm definitely taking notes!
@ariellebc13 ‚ÄúI really enjoy writing letters to my friends in other places when I‚Äôm feeling stressed or sad!‚Äù
@maggie.onthemove ‚ÄúI manage stress by walking my dog everyday. I leave the phone at home and connect with nature instead. It really clears my mind!‚Äù
@quinnsculthorpe ‚ÄúI try to get ahead of my stress by writing my daily intentions in my journal as soon as I wake up in the morning.‚Äù
@mtmt.ttt ‚ÄúüåüI stay away from social media. This is the new easy way to go ‚Äúmindless‚Äù. I also have a space where I can sit and take deep breaths when I am overwhelmed. Its either in my bed or a chair where I can sit up and go through my 4-7-8 breathing.‚Äù
@luxminimalist ‚ÄúSwimming is how i manage my stress. It‚Äôs good exercise and allows me to concentrate on my breathing.‚Äù
#MyRadiantLife #Cledepeaubeaute #sponsored"
2019 vs. 2009. Today marks 10 years since posting the first video that‚Äôs up on my YouTube channel. It feels like a lifetime ago. From my earliest memories I have always been creative ‚Äì drawing, writing, building things, experimenting in the kitchen with no purpose other than to play. When my dad died in 2006, I stopped playing. I didn‚Äôt make anything for three years. That‚Äôs a long time in my creative world. It‚Äôs hard for me now to go a week without making something let alone three years. My dad was my creative support growing up ‚Äì there was always room for creativity, no matter how much physical space it took up or how messy it got. When the outside world didn‚Äôt believe in my vision, my dad always did. His encouragement quieted the voices of harsh critics (my own included) and my instincts were allowed to shine. When he died, all of that went away. Suddenly, being creative felt like a painful memory of what I‚Äôd lost. I was depressed, angry, devastated and confused. I dreaded mornings because getting out of bed felt impossible, yet at night, I couldn‚Äôt fall asleep because my world felt so lonely. Discovering YouTube changed everything. I starting creating again, energized by my ideas and feeling challenged as I brought them to life. My confidence wasn‚Äôt discovered in this process but uncovered. It was there all along, it was just a little dusty. My creativity came back in a new form and it has carried me to so many places over the last decade ‚Äì my first apartment on my own, my career, coming out, friendships that I‚Äôll treasure forever (@eileeneveryday + @carrierad, this one‚Äôs for you), The White House and New York City. Remarkably, it has also brought me into your lives. It is the greatest gift to have touched just one other life and it‚Äôs an even greater gift knowing how much you‚Äôve touched mine. Life has expanded immensely beyond those four blue walls from my childhood bedroom, but there are two things that haven‚Äôt changed ‚Äì 1. my love for an inner corner highlight and red lip and 2. my deep faith in creativity as survival. Creativity led me here, planting the seeds for the roots I feel grounded in today. Thank you for growing with me.‚ù§Ô∏è
Growing up I always thought ‚ÄúI for sure want to be a mom!‚Äù but lots of things have changed since then. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs what I want anymore. Being 30, queer and unsure about whether or not I want to have kids has been difficult. Especially when it seems like everyone else is so certain about where they stand (I know the reality is, lots of people are unsure). When @NorthwellHealth reached out to see if I wanted to come to their event tonight, it was an enthusiastic YES for me because 1. this is something that‚Äôs on my mind daily and 2. I saw that LGBTQIA+ family planning was front and center on their fertility page. This immediately made me feel seen. I have a million and one questions about options, the process, and well‚Ä¶ ALL OF IT. I‚Äôve been avoiding this for a while because tbh I‚Äôm scared. What if  l wait too long? What if I‚Äôm infertile? What if I don‚Äôt want to carry? What if I do? Years ago, I was given some great advice: avoidance is not a strategy. Honestly, this popped into my inbox at the perfect time because as of tonight, I‚Äôm officially not avoiding this conversation with myself anymore. I‚Äôm learning, gathering information and taking notes ‚Äì all in a safe and fun environment. (There were games! Hence the tickets in my hands üòé) I genuinely have no idea where I‚Äôll land in the future, but what I do know for sure is that for right now, it‚Äôs okay to not be sure. Thank you #NorthwellHealthFertility for bringing us all together tonight.‚ù§Ô∏è#IlluminateYourOptions #ad
We have been calling Tayto ‚Äúbaby Simba‚Äù and I think he‚Äôs lukewarm about it... but he got to go to his favorite place (the beach!) so I think he‚Äôs willing to endure the new nickname üòèüê∂üíï
Hope @richo_kyle doesn‚Äôt mind.

#HelloFrom Cappadocia, Turkey, a surreal landscape of rock formations ‚Äî sometimes called fairy chimneys ‚Äî that have been sculpted by volcanoes, wind, rain and ice over many millions of years. ‚ÄúSince I had already seen hundreds of photos of hot air balloons in Cappadocia before, my eyes automatically searched for something different,‚Äù says photographer and content creator Helin Bereket (@helinbereket), who took this photo from a hot air balloon. ‚ÄúThen, there it was: vintage cars in an almost otherworldly landscape. It looked like a scene from a movie.‚Äù Photo by @helinbereket
"Natalie Glaze and Zanna van Dijk met because of Instagram. Today, they‚Äôre the #founders of Stay Wild Swim (@staywildswim), a sustainable swimwear brand designed and stitched in London.
üíï

The pair‚Äôs deep connection to sustainability and the ocean inspired them to start the company together. But neither had a formal background in fashion. ‚ÄúFor us, there was so much bliss in the naivet√© of just beginning our business,‚Äù explains Zanna. ‚ÄúWe started out not really knowing what we were getting ourselves into and gave it a go ‚Äî and the next thing you know, we‚Äôre in up to our necks.‚Äù üåä‚ú® In our limited series #founders, we‚Äôre sharing the stories of amazing small business owners from all over the world. A new episode will be available every Saturday until Christmas. To see even more #founders stories, check out @instagramforbusiness"
"Victoria Garrick (@victoriagarrick) is no stranger to finding balance in the face of pressure. As a public speaker, content creator and former student athlete, she speaks openly about the real pressures of social comparison. ‚ÄúThe pressure to be perfect stems from a societal belief that perfection is the only way to be good enough,‚Äù says Victoria. ‚ÄúI tried to attain these unrealistic standards of beauty, get straight As in school, become a star athlete and constantly seem happy. ‚Å£

Photo  by  @williamalbertallard // Stan  Kendall at  the  Miner's  Club  Bar -  Mountain  City,  Nevada,  1979 The  buckaroo  crew  and  I  went  in  one  day  to  get  supplies  at  the  tiny  hamlet  of  Mountain  City,  Nevada. Far from  being  a  city,  the  community  consisted  then,  as  I  recall,  of  a couple  of bars  and  a grocery  store.  There  may  have  been  more,  I  think  there  may  have  been  a brothel.  Brothels  are  legal in  Nevada;  it‚Äôs been  a  long time  and  it‚Äôs  hard  to  remember.  The  picture  of  Stan  Kendall  was  made  in  late  afternoon  and  there  was  sunlight  blasting  through  the  door of the  Miner‚Äôs  Club  and  there  was  lots  of red:  Stan‚Äôs  shirt,  the  bar‚Äôs  curtains,  the  wainscoting  of  the  bar, and  the  tops  of the  bar stools.  It  was  if the  entire  room  was  bleeding.  Stan  is  kind  of slumped  there  on the  stool,  a  faraway  look  on  his  face.  He  had  what  I  called  back  then,  that ‚Äúleaving look.‚Äù And  he  did  so the  next  day,  packing up  his  bedroll  and  saddle,  picking up  his  pay,  and  heading  to  another  job  on another  ranch  somewhere  down  the  road."

A man handles coca leaves during a ritual on Domingo de Tentaciones, a fiesta that closes the celebration of carnival in Soracachi, Bolivia. "Images from my years in Greenland are part of this years print sale. Today is last day at www.jacobauesobol.com
Living and working with the hunters and their families I always felt close to life and death. I learned that Nature is not only something we move around in - but something we are.
2nd hand copies of my book ""Sabine"" from Greenland are also on sale today only."
"I have a twin brother. His name is Thomas. He is 3 minutes
younger than me, 3 cm taller and weighs 3 kilos less.
When we were born the story goes that Thomas send me out in the world to check if everything was OK. Being alone for a few minutes I panicked, and I lured him to come out as well.
We were called A & B. In the years to come we were rarely called by our separate names. Just ""The Twins"". We were impossible to split. We created our own world together. A language that only we understood. We shared everything. First our dreams and later our secrets.
One day our father was killed. Together we had to
tell our mother. From that day Thomas and I lost the world
we had created together. We were no longer able to be close. Still it is when I'm near him that I feel most safe.
Images of twins from Russia, Denmark and America are a part of this years print sale ending tomorrow. Take a look at www.jacobauesobol.com"
"‚ÄúTo me the camera has always been a tool to find and depict love. How close can I get to a love that feels true in my images?‚Äù
All images are part of this years print sale at www.jacobauesobol.com"
Many new images of mine are part of this years print sale. Visit www.jacobauesobol.com to see all of them:)
"From my book ""By the River of Kings"". 2016.

All images available this week as part of our Winter Print Sale. 100 euro for a signed museum quality print (Hahnem√ºhle Baryta 320g) framed or in a cloth-bound box. 24x24cm - visit our store at www.jacobauesobol.com

The Chao Phraya River is the lifeblood of Thailand. It is born as the Ping and Nan rivers become one. From there its waters flow south to Bangkok. These pictures are a recording of what I saw and the people I met along The River of Kings in Bangkok."
"I lived with The Gomez Brito family in a remote, mountainous area of Guatemala for two months. Every day I took part in the daily work on their land, growing corn and beans. Juanita and Andreas had seven children: Roberto, Davide, Faustino, Eliseo, Diego, Elisabeth and Maria. They also had a dog named Domingo. Domingo would follow ten-year-old Eliseo every morning when he walked the long route over the mountain to tend to the horses. Often on the way back old Domingo got really tired, and Eliseo would carry him the rest of the way home.
The images from Guatemala are part of my yearly print sale where you can purchase a museum quality print in 24x24cm for 100 euro. Only this week. You can see the entire selection at www.jacobauesobol.com or by using link in profile."
I,Tokyo - published in 2008. Out of print and highly collectable. This week during our Winter Sale, you can get it at 100 euro:) These images are also available in the print sale: www.jacobauesobol.com
Pictures from America. From my latest book With And Without You and part of this year 100 euro print sale. Only this week. Visit www.jacobauesobol.com

.

.

"Have you ever done any of these?üßê
.
Having coached many females competitors to the highest level over the last 5 years these are some common mistakes that i have seen:
.
1: Focusing on Glutes too much! üçë 
The fitness world got Glute obsessed over the last few years, and yes female competitors do need round firm glutes, but you need the WHOLE PACKAGE or your (often) genetically weaker upper body could let you down.
Do not see glute training as a ‚Äúquick fix‚Äù or a simple route to getting Bikini Comp ready!
Instead, take an objective and holistic look at your physique and make steady improvements to all relevant areas.
.
2: Too few calories, for too long! ü§ï
All too often the female trainee enters a massive calorie deficit often just above BMR/RMR and loses a tonne of muscle eventually. Yeah that muscle that took ages to build!
Increase your work volume over time and carefully manage your deficit instead!
.
3: Underestimating menstrual cycle ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Rapid weight fluctuations, changes in mood and appetite can seriously mess with your head when you‚Äôre just a few weeks out! üò©
Make an action plan, get comfortable with some water weight gain - and accept this temporary state üëåüèº
.
Which of the above resonates with YOU the most?? Comment below - or drop me a DM with your story!
.
The stunner in the photo is @morgs_j_fit who managed to avoid these problems with my guidance. She‚Äôs now ranked 3rd in Europe as Pro Bikini Diva with @wbff_official.
.
#teamjae #compprep #bikinidiva #fitnessmodel #ifbb #miamipro #ukbff #wbff #wbffpro #pca #fatloss"
"5 key mindsets üß† separating WINNERS from the rest!
(Comment below which 1-5 resonates the most with YOU!)
.
1: Before SUCCESS, many failures may come. Learn from your falls, get up and grow stronger!
.
2: Focus on improving yourself and NOT comparing to others! You have zero control over your competition.
.
3: The JOURNEY itself must be enjoyable, rather than a pure focus on the  results!
.
4: One missed workout won‚Äôt derail you, and one bad meal will NOT make you fat. Dust yourself off after a bad day, and GET ON WITH IT.
.
5: When you walk on stage - assume you‚Äôve already WON, and present to the crowd like they are there just for YOU!
.
Interested to see how this stuff resonates with you guys and girls. What other mindset tips would you share?
.
#teamjae #compprep #bikinidiva #fitnessmodel #ifbb #miamipro #ukbff #wbff #wbffpro #pca #fatloss"

A very special #Caturday as I have videos of a snuggle between best friends Liberty (a lion) and Tiger Lily (a tiger) at @noahsarkclub yesterday, as well as us sharing enrichment items with the great, lovable tiger Doc and sweet Liberty. Noah‚Äôs Ark is a sanctuary that has saved more than 1,500 animals, many of them previously owned as illegal pets or in roadside zoos and circuses or used in scientific experiments, and who can‚Äôt be returned to the wild. Please follow @noahsarkclub here on Instagram and show your support! #happycaturday #cat #cats #catsofinstagram #lion #tiger
Of the many great experiences today at @noahsarkclub was meeting Anna Lou, a very friendly Grizzly who was rescued by Noah‚Äôs Ark. As a cub, Anna Lou was rented out to people for a weekend or overnight. Being shuffled from person to person and being removed from her mother at far too early an aged caused enormous anxiety and behavioral issues. Today at 4 1/2 years old she is happy at Noah‚Äôs Ark rescue with a huge area to romp and play and take part in one of her favorite enrichment activities - painting (non-toxic children‚Äôs paints of course!) Some of her great works can be seen in the last photo above. Before that you can see Anna Lou just sitting and hanging out with me as I told her how beautiful she was, which she seemed to love. If you want to help Anna Lou and other rescue animals please consider making a small donation to @noahsarkclub. ‚ù§Ô∏è

"Happy Holidays loves! üéÑ 
This is my absolute favourite time of the year but also the most emotional. Growing up, we didn‚Äôt have much but I really appreciate being brought up that way because the true meaning of Christmas (and just everyday life) is about loved ones and spending time together, eating, drinking wine and just really feeling grateful for the things we have right now. Growing up I was so thankful for a roof over our head, food on our table and everyone in good health. It is hard at times as many of our family members are not in our lives anymore which I‚Äôm sure a lot of people out there also have to deal with. This year for Christmas, I decided to get something for my sister that I love but will always have me attached to it. I got her and I @Guerlain Rouge G customizable lipsticks, engraved on the mirrors, hers says ‚ÄòJanice‚Äô and mine says ‚ÄòHalle‚Äô which I thought was a perfect way to remind eachother that while we have been through a lot and life gets crazy, we will always have eachother as sisters forever.

Hurling through the air over the far southern reaches of New Zealand, a place far separated from us humans & where nature still has a chance to thrive & prosper..
Details from Sakurajima, the most active volcano in all of Japan that we were lucky enough to see have multiple small eruptions during our time in Kagoshima. Hands down one of the craziest things I‚Äôve ever seen. @visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed
"Japan or Cappadocia?  This wasn‚Äôt a scene I was ever expecting to see the when visiting Japan but during my recent visit I was lucky enough to attend the 40th anniversary of the Saga Ballon Fiesta. It was one of those I don‚Äôt believe this is happening moments when I looked up to see 100s of balloons floating in the sky almost as far as the eye could see, who ever knew this was in Japan? This trip to Kyushu has definitely opened my mind on how incredible Japan is and if you take the time to travel out of well known regions you might find a side of Japan you may never expected. 
@visitjapanau #visitjapan #japanrevealed"
"Surviving typhoons, world wars and located on a rugged and isolated peninsula the Yakushima lighthouse was built in 1897 & is actually one of the oldest lighthouses in all Japan. Kyushu has provided some many unexpected scenes and the coastline of Yakushima is provided a different side of Japan that I‚Äôve never seen before. 
@visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed"
Sassy Portrait of the Yakushima macaque a subspecies of the Japanese macaque that‚Äôs indigenous to Yakushima. Known for its wildlife and dense cedar forest Yakushima was a real surprise as nature still reigns supreme on this small slice of land off the southwestern coast of Japan. @visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed
"Sundown at the aptly named ‚ÄúPath of Light‚Äù or Miyajidake Shrine on the out skirts of Fukuoka. Its said that approximately 2 days per year the sun will set at the end of this road, today wasn‚Äôt that day but it was still evidently special to experience.
@visitjapanau #visitjapanau #japanrevealed"
"Day 1 in Japan and I arrived in Kagoshima the southernwestern most city of Kyushu which  lays in the shadow of Sakuarajima, one of Japan‚Äôs most active volcanos. It‚Äôs probably one of the most immense and unexpected scenes I‚Äôve ever had the privilege of seeing. Can‚Äôt wait to share more from my trip around Kyushu. #AD I want to share my promise with you all in collaboration with @jlo exciting new fragrance, promise, available at the @fragranceshopuk. Once I got out of my dark space I made a promise to myself to try and think positively no matter what and be grateful for what I‚Äôve got (even if things aren‚Äôt going to plan). I had my daughter nearly 3 years ago and since having her I‚Äôve realised how short life is... the years are literally flying by and I don‚Äôt want to waste any of my life. I know I never want to be in that dark place again. It felt impossible to get out of it, I was a prisoner of my own head. Knowing I never want to be like that again, I made a promise to myself, to cherish life and not worry about things I know I won‚Äôt worry about when I‚Äôm an old lady. I can‚Äôt control everything that happens in my life but I can choose how I react to things. Thank you @jlo for letting me share my promise of self love and being comfortable with myself. "Fam!
The holidays can bring out some stressful feelings when it comes to food, especially guilt. However, enjoying food you love should NOT make you feel guilty!! It‚Äôs the holiday season, and we all deserve to indulge sometimes. If we beat ourselves up afterwards, it takes all of the fun away.  I‚Äôve been eating nonstop and I haven‚Äôt been working out as much, and yes, my pants feel way tighter than usual. But that is ok! Here is my advice: Eat your favorite foods when craving them and enjoy every bite. A few cheat meals won‚Äôt make or break your health, and guilt certainly won‚Äôt help either. Have fun, be thankful, move on, and know that it‚Äôs never too late to get back on track! PS. Follow my food account @idreamaboutfood üòú"

Today is #LatinaEqualPay Day, when Latinas "catch up" to what white, non-hispanic men were paid in 2018. The gap is widest for Latina workers, who on average earn only 54 cents for every $1 a man is paid. Meaning, they must work nearly two years to earn what white men earn in one year. This is unacceptable, and we need to act now. We work hard & we deserve equal pay! @phenomenal tee benefits @mujerxsrising, which protects the rights of migrant women.

... that time I used Tiger‚Äôs putter as a ski pole and slalomed down the sand trap. (His manager later told me that putter is worth over 20 million dollars) Point being: Never ask permission. #justdoit
