Today on World Soil Day it‚Äôs worth remembering the lessons of the Coon Creek Watershed of Southwest Wisconsin. In 1930 this was the most eroded farmland in America. With the help of the newly formed Soil Erosion Service farmers changed. They adopted strip cropping on the contours, put in terraces and stopped farming the steep hills to let the trees come back. Ninety years later this area is the very picture of fertility. It was saved. We need to do this on more of the world‚Äôs farmland. And we can. Saving our soil is saving our future. #worldsoil #terraton #indigoag
Skye has a rugged beauty at Sligachan where the river roars through the old Thomas Telford bridge when storms drop torrents of rain on the surrounding Red and Black Cuillins. Myths and legends abound, one being that you‚Äôll have eternal beauty if you dunk your head in the river for seven seconds. (Probably worth trying.) #scotland #isleofskye #storm @hiddenscotland
Another view over the shores of Sanday of the ongoing ‚Äúargument‚Äù between the sea and the sands that defines the character of these a North Sea islands. The farm at Overbister is caught in the middle of this geological bickering, wondering when the tides or a winter storm will choose to remake the coastline once again. Really hard to say what it looked like when the Vikings came, let alone when the Neolithic people started farming here 6,000 years ago. #scotland #orkney #visitorkney
Flying over Sanday you can see how dynamic the islands of Orkney truly are, constantly building dunes on one side while beaches are carving into farmland on the other. Here the sea has made a large incursion, breaking into the interior to create a tidal bay at Overbister. (Wonder how the farmer felt when this happened?) ‚ÄúBister‚Äù is old Norse for a farm. #scotland #visitorkney
Some places on the Isle of Harris have a moonscape look to them. But one hardly needs to invoke romance, the plain facts are evocative enough. To wit, I‚Äôll just quote from Wikipedia: ‚ÄúThe east coast of south Harris is known as the Bays. The best known section called the "Golden Road" as it cost so much money to build, when it was built in 1897. It runs from Miavaig via Drinishader, Grosebay, Scadabay and Cluer to Stockinish. From Stockinish the road is the Bays and meanders through the coastal townships of Lickisto (Liceasto), Geocrab (Ge√≤crab), Manish (M√†nais), Flodabay (Fle√≤ideabhagh), Ardvay (√Äird Mhighe), Finsbay (Fionnsbhagh) and Lingerbay (Lingreabhagh).‚Äù Such place-names. #scotland
Some chance encounters illuminate a place, make it human and join it to the stream of history. So it was for me when I met sheepherder Allan Gray gathering his sheep near the ruins of historic Kilchurn Castle on Loch Awe. There beneath the ruined walls (sent into permanent decline by a ferocious lightning bolt) Allan told me simple, personal stories, of the neighborhood, of his sheepdog (lurking just outside the frame, keeping the sheep at attention) and of the dog‚Äôs grandfather, who had been brilliant in ways that only come along every few generations, if ever in one person‚Äôs lifetime. Then the moment passed and I have not seen him again. #scotland #dogs
Granite boulders forming the Street of the Dead (Sraid nam Marbh) have lain here on Iona for more than 1,000 years. Along this processional way the bodies of Scottish Kings and royalty were carried to their graves in Reilig Odhr√°in from Martyr‚Äôs Bay, where Viking raiders killed 68 monks in 806 AD. (Plunder followed.) This small island holds that contradiction: a place of peace with a violent history.  #scotland  #iona
If I was a kid and somebody took me out on the little stone quay that pokes out into Loch Oich at the Glengarry Castle Hotel I‚Äôd probably think the world is pretty cool. #scotland
Loch Oich always seems a bit more mysterious than its neighbors on either side, Loch Ness and Loch Lochy. Perfect for a ramshackle boat tucked into a cove, no one seen, never moved. Not far away is the Well of the Seven Heads, a fine monument to the murderous revenge visited upon these shores in 1663 by Bald Iain. (Washed seven severed heads in the Loch, he did.) Pretty place. #scotland
Ousdale Broch is a gem, looking wild and overgrown on this hillside in Caithness, which has over 200 of these  2,000 year old tower houses!  The farmers and herders living here then had quite the view. A child growing up here lived in a world made lively with myths and legends. My guides were Kenneth and Iain from the Caithness Broch Project. These folks want to build a brand new broch. Follow @caithnessbrochproject to keep up on their progress. #scotland  #caithness
The moon and stars were aligned for me at the Stones of Stenness this summer. With just two days in Orkney I was delighted to discover that the full moon would be rising over the stones on the second night. Clouds that had obscured the moonrise eventually gave way to this scene, my reward on a beautiful evening. A car went by leaving the red trail of its taillights and I ran around lighting the stones with my little flashlight to complete the scene. #scotland #orkney #visitorkney

"Bridge Over Calm Water.
[ADS]
Maastricht was in so many ways a surprise to me: a beautiful old town with lots of retail, friendly people and wonderful food. And then, completely unexpected, the fog came! I have never experienced anything like this before: after a clear morning, fog starts to spread around noon. Amazing! Probably this only happens #InLimburg. 
@inlimburg"
"The Book Store.
[ADS]
The Dominicanen is a unique bookstore. It was opened in the ancient Dominicanenkerk (Dominican church) in #Maastricht. Two hundred years ago, the church lost its sacred function and was used since then e.g. as a reptile house, a bicycle storage, and a ‚Äòcarnival temple‚Äô. CNN says @boekhandel_dominicanen is the most beautiful bookstore in the world. In any case, it is one of the most beautiful bookstores for me. 
The building also houses a caf√©. Besides books, there are also records and CDs. When did you buy your last CD?
#InLimburg @InLimburg"

[Ads]
A late November evening, it rains when I arrive in #Maastricht, in the very southeast of the Netherlands. Maastricht It is the capital and largest city of the province of Limburg. 
I like the city right away with its white houses and brick houses. The city is already festively decorated and I'm looking forward to see more.
#InLimburg @InLimburg"

"For years I've wanted to write down my mom's full holiday meal that she has made since I was little. It has always been hard for her to just give me the recipe because she cooks ""to taste"" so nothing is ever written down or measured. She just wings it every time and every time it's my favorite. So I cleared my schedule and sat and watched her every move and wrote it all down. It feels like such a gift to finally have these recipes of my mom‚Äôs on paper, all written out. And the even greater gift was the time we got to spend together in the kitchen today.
This thanksgiving, I'm extra grateful for family, tradition, and good food ‚ù§Ô∏è#HappyThanksgiving"

Don‚Äôt panic, I‚Äôm slowly winding down for the year I promise üåÄ
Reunited with my favourite twitch streamer üëçüèº
If you asked me a couple of years ago that I‚Äôd be singing and acting on stage in the west end I wouldn‚Äôt have believed it. Something like this would usually terrify me, and it definitely did. Many times I thought ‚Äúwhat am I doing? I‚Äôm so out my depth here‚Äù and got the classic ‚Äòimposter syndrome‚Äô which a lot of youtubers get whenever they branch out into anything outside of the internet. But this show and this experience really has been a game changer for me on so many different levels. Ive always said from day one that I‚Äôve just been riding a wave of luck for the last 8 or so years and I‚Äôm so excited to see where this wave will take me next. Best bit about it all is the continued support from friends, family and the people that have stumbled upon my channels etc and decided to stick around. I appreciate ya all more than you know. If someone ever tells you to stick to one thing and stay in your lane, ignore them. We‚Äôre not on this planet for long. Try to make the most of it üëçüèº‚ù§Ô∏è

Protect Pacific walruses like Dozer @seaworldsandiego by taking steps to reduce your carbon footprint. Historically, the greatest threat to this species was commercial hunting. Today, this threat has been replaced with the loss of stable sea ice due to climate change. Walruses feed on the ocean floor in the relatively shallow waters of the continental shelf, where the sea ice sustains a rich food web. Sea ice is also a resting place for this species in between meals, and females will often leave their young on this frozen platform while they forage. Without the sea ice, walruses must swim longer distances to find food and a place to rest, which means burning through hard-earned energy stores that the walrus needs to survive. Warming conditions also mean more water vessels are able to venture into remote ecosystems that were once inaccessible, increasing the likelihood of boat strikes, water contamination, and entanglement in marine debris. By opting to walk, bike, carpool, or use public transport you reduce your transportation emissions which helps to slow the progression of global warming, protecting the homes of walruses and many other species. #walrus #pacificwalrus #bigtusks #climatechange #globalwarming #gogreen #greentransportation #WalrusAwarenessWeek #PhotoArk #savetogether
Despite the least bittern‚Äôs impressively long neck, this bird is actually one of the smallest members of the heron family. Five subspecies of least bittern can be found in brackish and freshwater marshes from as far north as Canada, all the way south to Argentina. These birds are wetland-based carnivores, feeding on small fish, frogs, salamanders, slugs, crayfish, and a variety of insects. Least bitterns will usually stand at the base of aquatic plants near the surface of the water and patiently wait for their prey to appear. Once in sight, the bird easily collects small animals from the water using its long, thin bill. Draining of wetlands and the introduction of invasive species of plants are the greatest threats for the survival of this species in the wild. @wrcmn, where this bird was photographed was founded at the University of Minnesota in 1979, and has quickly grown into one of the busiest wildlife hospitals in the US. Each year, the WRC will admit close to 15,000 patients, providing life-saving care to more than 192 different species. #leastbittern #heron #bird #longneck #stripes #bigbeak #wetland #marshes #PhotoArk #savetogether
This adorable toad is a plains spadefoot @unlincoln. Wondering how this species got its name? Each of these toads has hard, keratinous protrusions on their hind feet which allows them to efficiently dig backwards into the soil, much like a spade (digging tool) with a very similar function. These digging skills are super handy as spadefoot toads spend much of their time underground in burrows they must dig for themselves. In the wild, this species covers a wide range, from western Canada into the northwestern US, and further down south to Texas and northern Mexico. No major threats are known, though the species has been negatively affected by intensive urbanization and agricultural development. These toads are especially susceptible to vehicle collisions as populations attempt to move between breeding (usually temporary pools of water) and non-breeding habitats. Always keep an eye out for amphibians when driving in your neighborhood, especially after it rains - you never know who might be visiting those roadside puddles! #spadefoottoad #plainsspadefoot #WorldSoilDay #digger #amphibian #bigeyes #smile #toad #PhotoArk #savetogether
This southern vested tamandua @zootampa looks like he‚Äôs ready to dance, standing perfectly poised on his hind legs with arms outstretched. Tamanduas live throughout much of South America, and while they can be found in savannas, tropical rainforests, scrub forests, and mangroves, they most commonly occur near streams and rivers. Tamanduas mostly eat ants and termites, using their forelimbs and claws to dig up insect nests, though they also eat honey and bees. While the mouth opening at the end of their elongated snout is only about the width of a pencil eraser, their tongues can be nearly 16 inches long - perfect for slurping up tasty insects. Tamanduas are a toothless species, but have a muscular gizzard in the stomach to help them digest their food. When they are not active, tamanduas will take shelter in tree hollows. You can help protect this incredible species by avoiding animal skin products when you shop, even those marked as ‚Äúfaux‚Äù to ensure you are not contributing to the illegal hunting of this species. In certain regions, tamanduas are hunted for meat, or even for their skins, which can be made into leather products. #tamandua #vested #dancer #longtongue #claws #longsnout #cute #bigears #furry #shopsmart #PhotoArk #savetogether
A hen Indochinese green peafowl strikes a pose for the camera during a photoshoot @accb_cambodia. Also known as dragonbird, the green peafowl is a powerful flyer, capable of covering long distances as they travel from their nesting sites deep in the forest to feeding sites in marsh pastures along riverbanks. Their diet consists mainly of seeds, insects, reptiles, fruits and small animals, and is also known for hunting venomous snakes. The Angkor Center for Conservation of Biodiversity, where this photo was taken, aims to rescue and care for native Cambodian wildlife, rehabilitating species in their care with the goal of one day releasing these individuals back into the wild. #peafowl #greenpeafowl #Indochinese #hen #colorful #dragonbird #ACCB #PhotoArk #savetogether
This cute fellow is a golden Asian mantis at the Albuquerque BioPark (@oneabq). While many insects give people the creeps, mantids seem capable of winning the affections of almost everyone with their human-like heads and statuesque figures. Praying mantids earned their name because when they are waiting for prey, they fold their front legs in an upright position as if they are folded in prayer. While this species may look angelic, don‚Äôt be fooled - the mantid is a deadly predator. With the ability to swivel its head, there‚Äôs nothing the mantid can‚Äôt see, and once a bee or fly enters its line of sight, those forearms extend with lightning quick speed, instantly snatching up its prey. Some larger species of mantid can catch much bigger prey - lizards, frogs, and even birds! #goldenmantid #prayingmantis #predator #bigeyes #bugeyed #angelic #PhotoArk #savetogether

Happy Thanksgiving from this beautiful ocellated turkey @officialdwazoo! Endemic to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, Guatemala and Belize, ocellated turkeys, especially males, look similar to the North American wild turkey, but have more vibrant coloring and weigh significantly less than the birds in the States. Males weigh just over ten pounds and average three feet in length, while females are slightly smaller in size. Both sexes have bluish-gray tails with a well-defined, eye-shaped, blue-bronze colored spot near the end followed by a bright gold tip. These spots give the ocellated turkey its name, as the Latin word for eye is oculus. In the wild, large scale timber operations and slash and burn agriculture in Central America threaten the habitat of the ocellated turkey. To combat this threat, and create a better future for the species, @rainforestalliance is working to advance community forestry, sustainable agriculture, ecotourism, and environmental education, supporting local landscapes and communities in areas where this bird is found. #Thanksgiving #TurkeyDay #ocellatedturkey #colorful #bird #PhotoArk #savetogether
"George Divoky at home with 45 years of first hand documentation of the Black Guillemots of Cooper Island. #friendsofcooperisland By don‚Äôt of his singlehanded study of these birds George has also amassed one the truly detailed, resoundingly provable accounts of global warming on the planet. It‚Äôs all there in those notebooks. 
#SundayMorning @cooperislandak #portraitphotography #portraitoftheday #picoftheday #research #friendsofcooperisland #GeorgeDivoky #NikonAmbassador @NikonUSA #Z7 For the documentary film on George‚Äôs work: On our YT channel!"
"In 2001, I did a story on a patient, tenacious, gregarious ornithologist named George Divoky, who had spent 28 years and counting, living on a forbidding stretch of ice north of Alaska, 3 months a year, studying his specialty, arctic seabirds. Inadvertently, what he also did was amass one of the world's largest experiential accounts of global warming. A lot of theoreticians who project climate change use algorithms, and scientifically based modeling to project the loss of the ice pack. By contrast, George has lived it, all these years, sleeping on the ice, living in solitary, difficult conditions, and making painstaking notes in old school, battered, salt stained notebooks. When I visited him, it was basically the two of us, stranded on the ice for nearly ten days, eating Dinty Moore beef stew and living in pup tents. You get to know each other in these conditions. George and I became friends and remain so to this day. 
His study is now at 45 years in duration, and I went back up to Cooper Island this past July of 2019, with a film crew, to document his ongoing research, which is an astonishing and important act of perseverance. I photographed George standing once again in the very same place I photographed him all those years ago. Back in 2001, he was standing on ice. Now, in 2019, he is knee deep in water. To quote George, ""The Arctic is melting."" He is seen here in his shack which is his home (and protection from polar bears) for the three months he lives on Cooper. More on @nikonusa learn&explore, including full film and BTS. 
#WednesdayWisdom #NikonAmbassador
#Photooftheday #picoftheday #Z7 #environmentalportrait #GeorgeDivoky #FriendsofCooperIsland @NikonUSA @CooperIslandAK #Alaska #globalwarming #Arctic #climatechange #CooperIsland"

"The ever elegant @ambertutton in the woods. Three sources here, a main and a rim light, with a bounce fill. The two big lights are the Lastolite pro strip soft boxes which is a pretty new light I immediately embraced, and the fill is a skip off a silver halo reflector, also a new addition to the light shaper line. Fun to do and very mobile, using radio TTL in the woods. Thank you to the @lastolitebymanfrotto UK crew and to Amber for braving the cold out there! 
#SaturdayMorning #SaturdayStyle @ambertutton #lastolitebymanfrotto #manfrotto #Birmingham #UK #woods"
"Speedlights from outside! The upfront combo is pretty tried and true. Overhead ezybox w a Speedlite 2 Plus low and out of frame. But our subject‚Äôs amazing hair is lit from a clamped Speedlight outside the restaurant, fitted with a warm gel. Always look to establish volume and dimension by lighting in a way that is where light flows from naturally, i. e., the windows. 
#ThursdayThoughts #ThursdayVibes #lastolitebymanfrotto #lastolite #manfrotto¬†¬†#birmingham #portraitphotography 
#ezyboxspeedlite2plus. Go to the @lastolitebymanfrotto app for the whole series of lighting videos!"
"Light and fast on a cold street! One hand held flash up front and a gelled light on a stand in the background. Gotta keep things moving fast on a cold, blustery day on location. The upfront speed light is fitted with a @lastolitebymanfrotto Speedlite 2 Plus box ‚Äî stuff it in your camera bag type of easy to use light shaper. Played with angle of incidence -angle of reflection highlights to change the colour of the old canal walls. The background light has no shaper, just a raw light w a gel. Two lights, quick setup, next stop‚Äîcoffee shop! üòÑ

"From my book, Island of the Spirits - This was a magical evening in Tibubeneng, the small village where for five years was my home in Bali. It was the eve of Nyepi, the day known as the Day of Silence. Giant effigies called Ogoh-Ogoh‚Äôs are paraded around the streets at night in every village throughout Bali as a purification of the natural environment, cleansing any spiritual pollutants emitted from the activities of living beings, especially humans‚Ä¶we sure are a messy lot. An Ogoh-Ogoh (pronounced ‚ÄúOoogo-Ooogo‚Äù) can be gigantic in size, taking weeks to create out of paper mache and bamboo. Many are so heavy it takes 20 or more strong people to carry! An entire gamelan orchestra is also in the procession as everyone in the village walks, until nearing midnight when the Ogoh-Ogoh is burned in a massive roar of fire. Then begins the most magical moment‚Ä¶Nyepi. At midnight, no one is allowed out of their homes. No one can speak, except in short whispers. No lights or electricity can be used, nor open flames for the next 24 hours‚Ä¶the international airport in Denpasar is the only airport on earth that literally closes down, accepting no incoming our outgoing flights for twenty-four hours. We all need a day of silence to meditate on our lives, a period of time to collect our thoughts and being. It is so quiet, peaceful during Nyepi, a time when we allow the earth and spirits to be with us, without light pollution or any other distraction other than silence.
-

It was  beautiful afternoon in Ubud during a royal cremation, a day-long event filled with ceremonial rituals. When the family carried the remains of Tjokorde Isteri Muter up the cremation tower, everything for a few moments became silent, its massiveness towering 30 meters or more to the sky. Moments later it was burned, carrying the spirit of Tjokorde into the afterlife. Death in Balinese Hinduism is a mixture of mourning, a celebration of life and the afterlife to come. When I die, and we all will, celebrate a life lived as I wish for each of you, in acts of creating, doing, in unconditional love for the purpose we are all here.

Today feels just right to share this peaceful photograph on a day of giving thanks in the country I now live. I don‚Äôt accept the idea of single days in specialness, like Valentines day or Thanksgiving day to mentioned a few. Everyday, like in Bali, should be one of giving thanks and love to each other. There was so much being offered, occurring, using this beauty of a slow giving Holga camera. It was the first spiritual event I attending when creating the Island of the Spirits. I went with my dear friend and assistant, Bli Wayan Tilik, to the Bali Aga village in Tenganan. This day was the Perang Pandan, an ancient ritual where young men in the village fight each other using thorny padan leaves. I had never witnessed a ceremony like this anywhere before‚Ä¶the boys would thrash themselves till bleeding to show their respect to Dewa Indra, the god of war. After this ceremony I began to realize the challenges of working with a Holga could be overcame, that this simple plastic film camera was the right means to see and give kindness to a culture so steeped in tradition, where little had changed in centuries.

"Holiday Print Sale, link in my IG bio - To have one foot in the past, another firmly in the present, I chose to use a Holga film camera for my book, Island of the Spirits. This unique beauty allowed the timeliness of a culture so deep in tradition to be raw, real and truthful. The Holga speaks in this ephemeral nature how time is not really real. There were challenges using a Holga‚Ä¶light leaks, only 12 frames per roll, the slow methodology in changing film, all in movement of near meditation. When spiritual events like this man, deep in trance trying to stab himself during the cleansing ritual known as, Melasti, everything moved so quickly. There was only the ability to make one photograph, knowing that all the history before, all the history to come, would never repeat. I‚Äôve witnessed numerous Melasti‚Äôs while living in Bali and never have I seen anyone draw blood or hurt themselves, no matter how hard the pointed Kirs (a dagger-like sword) was pushed into skin. This protection, I am told, was due to the deep belief and faith that the spirits would protect those fortunate enough to receive such a heightened level of spirituality.
-

"Saya ikut memperingati Hari Antikorupsi Sedunia yang jatuh hari ini, 9 Desember 2019, dengan menyaksikan sebuah pentas sederhana di SMKN 57 Jakarta. Drama ini tentang anak sekolah dan penjual bakso.

Seorang siswa hendak menggunakan uang pentas seni untuk jajan semangkuk bakso. Tapi ia bertemu penjual bakso yang bijak. Anak sekolah dinasehati untuk tak menyalahgunakan uang bersama kepentingan pribadi.

Drama bertajuk Prestasi Tanpa Korupsi itu membawa pesan sederhana bahwa perilaku korupsi, sekecil apa pun bentuknya ‚Äì korupsi uang, waktu, nepotisme, dan lain-lain -- tidak diperbolehkan.

Oh ya, para pemeran drama singkat tadi sungguh istimewa. Tahukah Anda siapa penjual bakso dan anak-anak sekolah di pentas itu?"
"Mari membiasakan diri dengan nilai-nilai integritas dan kejujuran semenjak dini. Jadikan sebagai budaya kerja dan budaya keseharian kita.

Hindari korupsi dari yang sekecil-kecilnya."
"Memenangkan kompetisi itu penting, sportivitas olahraga juga harus dijunjung tinggi, tapi kemanusiaan di atas segalanya.

Apresiasi saya untuk peselancar Filipina, Roger Casugay, yang merelakan kesempatan meraih medali emas demi menolong pesaingnya, atlet Indonesia Arip Nurhidayat yang terjatuh dalam lomba.

Salam hormat dari Indonesia."
Balada si anak desa ...
"Panjangnya hanya 11 kilometer. Hanya ruas pendek di antara jalan tol lingkar luar Jakarta (JORR) II yang melingkar 110 kilometer antara Jakarta, Tangerang, Tangerang Selatan, Bogor, Depok, dan Bekasi. Akan tetapi, jalan tol ruas Kunciran-Serpong yang saya resmikan kemarin begitu penting.

Jalan tol ini menjadi jalur pengalihan sebagian kendaraan, terutama kendaraan berat, dari jalur jalan tol dalam kota Jakarta dan JORR I yang padat. Di jalur-jalur inilah, orang-orang yang bolak-balik Banten-Jakarta kerap mengeluh: ‚ÄúPak, kita ini bisa tua di jalan karena macet‚Äù. Waktu terbuang di jalan adalah sebuah kerugian yang besar karena menggerus daya saing kita dan pengeluaran biaya bahan bakar kendaraan.

Alhamdulillah, pembangunan jalan tol Kunciran-Serpong akhirnya rampung dan segera bisa kita manfaatkan.

JORR II terdiri atas enam ruas tol yang menghubungkan daerah Cengkareng, Kunciran, Serpong, Cinere, Jagorawi, Cimanggis, Cibitung, dan Cilincing. Sebagian besar akan selesai pada pertengahan tahun 2020."
"Bertemu dan berbincang sejenak dengan Ibu Inah, selepas santap siang di Kota Cilegon. Rupanya, Ibu Inah telah menunggu dan menyambangi lokasi kunjungan saya di Banten, dari sekitar helipad, lokasi peresmian pabrik, sampai di halaman masjid.

Akhirnya, keinginan Ibu Inah terwujud. Kami bersalaman dan berbincang di depan rumah makan. Semoga Ibu Inah dan putrinya senantiasa sehat dan sejahtera."
"Saya mengapresiasi investasi yang dilakukan PT Chandra Asri Petrochemical yang membangun pabrik baru di Kota Cilegon, Banten dan saya resmikan hari ini. Pabrik tersebut memproduksi polietilena, salah satu bahan baku produk pendukung infrastruktur dalam negeri.

PT Chandra Asri adalah pionir industri petrokimia di Tanah Air. Pabrik baru ini berkapasitas 400 ribu ton per tahun.

Akan tetapi, kebutuhan domestik polietilena sebagai bahan baku industri mencapai 2,3 juta ton per tahun, sementara kapasitas produksi nasional untuk bahan baku tersebut baru mencapai 780 ribu ton. Kita masih impor 1,52 juta ton.

Karena itulah saya berharap, investasi penanaman modal di bidang ini harus terus diberi ruang.  Kalau kita bisa membuat sendiri kenapa harus impor?

Selain itu, investasi industri seperti ini membuka lapangan kerja yang besar, yang berkontribusi menggerakkan roda ekonomi, tidak hanya di Cilegon dan Banten saja, tetapi juga perekonomian nasional kita."
"Setiba di Banten pagi ini, saya langsung ke RSUD Cilegon. Seperti sebelumnya di Lampung dan Subang, saya meninjau pelayanan BPJS Kesehatan. Terutama, hendak memastikan apakah yang berada di kelas III itu peserta BPJS.

Dan benar, angkanya sama: sebagian besar pasien yang datang berobat ditanggung BPJS. Sejauh ini, saya juga belum mendengar keluhan langsung pelayanan di tiga rumah sakit yang saya datangi tersebut.

Tentu saja masih banyak rumah sakit kita yang fasilitasnya perlu diperbaiki. Tapi itu tugas pemerintah daerah. Tugas pemerintah kota, pemerintah kabupaten, pemerintah provinsi sebagai pemilik hampir semua rumah sakit umum."
"Dari Pangkalan TNI AU Atang Sanjaya, Kabupaten Bogor, pagi ini, saya bertolak menuju Provinsi Banten dengan helikopter. Kunjungan hanya sehari tapi dengan beragam acara, dari meresmikan pabrik new polyethylene, meninjau Program Membina Ekonomi Keluarga Sejahtera (Mekaar), sampai meresmikan jalan tol JORR II ruas Kunciran-Serpong.

Selamat pagi."
Terima kasih. Ini kehormatan bukan untuk saya semata-mata, tapi untuk Indonesia.
"Rapat terbatas di Jakarta sore tadi, membahas pengelolaan cadangan beras pemerintah. Saya meminta manajemen pengelolaan cadangan beras segera dibenahi sehingga penumpukan stok beras yang tidak tersalurkan dapat ditangani, dan dicarikan jalan keluarnya sejak jauh hari.

Penumpukan tersebut meningkatkan biaya perawatan, juga dapat menurunkan mutu dari stok beras yang ada.

Selain itu, kepada jajaran terkait, saya mengharapkan data produksi beras yang betul-betul riil dan terkonsolidasi sehingga kita memiliki pegangan data yang kuat sebelum mengambil keputusan.

Produksi beras di setiap daerah tidaklah merata, ada yang berlebih dan mampu memasok ke luar daerahnya, ada pula yang membutuhkan pasokan beras dari luar wilayahnya. Jadi, selain urusan ketersediaan komoditas beras, manajemen logistik dan rantai pasok beras nasional juga perlu dibenahi."

"I‚Äôm excited to share a few photos from one of the most special places I‚Äôve ever traveled to or photographed: The ancient archeological site of Hegra (also known as Mada‚ÄôIn Saleh). I was fortunate enough to visit this site on my recent assignment in Saudi Arabia, and it absolutely blew me away. This amazing site constitutes the southernmost settlement of the Nabatean Kingdom, dating back to the 1st century AD. This is the same kingdom that built Petra (in modern-day Jordan) further to the north. However, this is far more expansive than Petra, and without the crowds. Designated in 2008 as a site of patrimony, this is Saudi Arabia‚Äôs first UNESCO world heritage site. The real jaw-dropping sights here are the elaborately cut rock tombs with their ornamental facades. The richer you were, the more elaborate tomb you could afford. Some, like this one called Al Farid, are incredible ornate and beautiful, especially when cut from a single freestanding rock in the desert. It was truly an honor to visit this special place. An important note: the site is currently closed for archeological excavation, and will reopen in October of 2020. Put it on your bucket list! 
#experiencealula #onassignment"
Approximately 25 miles northwest of the Turkish city of Antalya lies one of the greatest archeological ruins I‚Äôve ever laid my eyes on: Termessos. Alexander the Great, who didn‚Äôt bother to try to invade this strategically located city, once called Termessos the ‚ÄúEagles Nest‚Äù due to its precipitous perch 3000 feet high on top of a mountain. To walk through this ancient city now is a walk through time, full of ruined buildings, woodlands overtaking the fallen stones, and birds chirping in the crisp mountain air. The pathways, houses, and gathering places literally come to life as you wander through the scattered stones. The highlight of a visit to Termessos is, without a doubt, this incredibly preserved 4500 capacity Roman theatre. Can you imagine the views the spectators had while plays and orations were taking place in the round theatre below? Absolutely breathtaking. Although it is a bit of a trek to get here, and it is not necessarily on the tourist route, I‚Äôd highly recommend a stop here if/when you visit Turkey.
#sponsored I'm headed back to Africa soon and I am stoked to have picked up a new pair of Canon 10X20 IS Binoculars for close-up animal viewing on safari. I started out my photography career shooting @CanonUSA and have always been impressed by the sharpness and clarity of their optics. So it would make sense that those same high quality optics translate into these lightweight binoculars. And the best part is that they have built-in Image Stabilization...all the better to see you with, my dear. When bumping down those dirt roads on the lookout for big game, these will be invaluable. Giddyup! #CoCreateWithCanon https://lnk2.io/wxsj2kp
"Go back 100 or 200 years and if you saw these guys walking toward you you‚Äôd better run for your life. But now they are just actors recreating Saudi Arabia of many moons ago. These pretend soldiers were part of the inaugural festivities of the new UNESCO world heritage site at Diriyah, Saudi Arabia. 
#Diriyah #Diriyahgate #dgda #diriyahroyalinauguration @dgda_sa #onassignment"
"I recently had the incredible honor to attend the Royal Inaugural ceremony of a new UNESCO World heritage sight, Diriyah Gate, located just outside of the city of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The conservation and preservation of our collective world heritage sites is important to me, and are reasons to honor and celebrate our past. And this site definitely deserves its Heritage status. Established in 1466 AD on the banks of the Wadi Hanifa oasis, this mud-brick city became the capital of the first Saudi state in 1744 AD. Once open only to the Royal family, the designation of this new UNESCO site opens up this beautiful architecture for anyone who would like to walk through its labyrinth of rooms and learn about its fascinating history. But there‚Äôs more to this site than meets the eye. It also represents a new wave of openness and change for the kingdom. To me, the changes that are happening in Saudi Arabia are just as interesting as its historical landmarks. Stay tuned for more thoughts on my visit to what I felt was a special and amazing place...the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. 
#Diriyah #Diriyahgate #dgda #diriyahroyalinauguration @dgda_sa #onassignment"
"A room with a view. Cappadocia‚Äôs daily balloon rise at sunrise from the quaint town of Goreme is always a beautiful sight. This is especially true if you can witness it from the comfort of your bedroom in your jammies. 
#onassignment @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart"
"Yeah, it‚Äôs iconic. And yeah, everybody has a killer shot of it. But Maroon Bells sunrises are still awesome no matter how much it‚Äôs been over-shot. There are some natural views in this world that are almost too perfect for words..and this is one of them. 
#onassignment @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart @visitcolorado #Colorado"
"Closely related to the Blue Jay of the eastern North America states, the Steller‚Äôs Jay is a distinctive bird native to western North America. I grew up watching Blue Jays in our backyard feeder, and I could instinctively see that this bird was different. But it still had the bossy, noisy, crow-like tendencies that I saw in the blue jays of my youth. I had been hoping that I could find a moment where the beautiful dark blue of the Steller Jay could be contrasted with the yellow Aspen trees as the quick moving bird rested for a few seconds on a branch. Sometimes, with enough patience, you get lucky. As a photographer, it can be a huge asset to know color theory..which colors complement/contrast well with others. Blue is on the opposite quadrant of the color wheel as yellow, and can make for an instinctively pleasing contrast. Do you think about color theory in your photography? 
#onassignment @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart @visitcolorado #Colorado"
"We wait so long to catch a glimpse of the few weeks that the trees put on their magnificent displays of yellows, oranges, and reds. And when it happens it is an absolutely glorious thing. Like most of the best things in life, it never lasts as long as you want. As a photographer trying to capture this special time of year, the initial excitement and overwhelming elation to the absolute beauty in every direction eventually turns to finding the really special moments of light. It was here, where the light on the aspens played and danced with the shadows below, that I started to find the compositions that touched my soul. This was one of them. 
#onassignment @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart"
"Big world, tiny people. Hiking up to Crater Lake just below the Maroon Bells (outside of Aspen, CO) during fall foliage is always going to be a beautiful and crowded experience. Luckily, you can find some peace if you try hard enough 
#onassignment @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart"
I recently spent a beautiful night shooting the Milky Way above the famous Maroon Bells outside of Aspen, CO. It was cold, it was dark, but it was oh so amazing to see this incredible spectacle. Shot with the FUJIFILM GFX100 (a 100 mpx beast of a camera!). #onassignment @fujifilmx_us @fujifilm_northamerica @natgeoimagecollection @natgeo @natgeofineart
"Most people visit Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska to see the massive grizzly bears feasting on the salmon run. Yeah, we saw that too, and I‚Äôll share some photos soon. But we also saw lots of other beautiful animals, such as this curious young wolf. We had heard that he was snooping around and eating leftover salmon bits early mornings along the riverbank and so we decided to get up super early to see if we could catch a glimpse. Not only did we see him that first day, but every morning thereafter. You had to get up before the birds...around 5:00 am...to catch a glimpse of him, as he didn‚Äôt stay around a long time. But the lack of sleep was totally worth spending a few precious moments with this magnificent creature. And he even got brave enough to venture close and lock eyes with the strange creatures watching him. Any day you get to see a wolf in the wild is a good day. 
#onassignment @katmainps @natgeocreative @natgeo @natgeofineart"

"I miss you already...üôÅü•∫üò¢üò≠
If I thought giving birth was the hardest thing a woman had to go through in her life then I was wrong! Separating a woman from her baby is a million times harder.
I thank every day that we have been blessed with a job we enjoy and make millions of people happy with us, but the work requires us to travel quite a bit, which means we have to leave Ariel in the hands of her loving grandmothers.
Maya is a true hero the way she flies off for work every time despite the difficulty in parting from Ariel and manages to put her future ahead of her own personal struggle. She keeps saying that separating from Ariel is the hardest thing she's ever experienced, and it doesn't get easier from time to time, even though it makes sense it will. So, there is no sense in parenting... Only what the heart feels.
Being a career person while raising a family is perhaps one of the most difficult challenges we would have to face in life. I don't know what we would do without both of our amazing mothers. I guess mother love to her child has no expiration date.

I discovered @livelarq last year when I was Christmas shopping. I ended up buying everyone in my family one (instead of a bunch of stocking stuffers, we had everyone pick one gift to get each person). If you're like me, then you probably have a water bottle on you at all times. I made it a part of my routine a few years ago and it's dramatically changed how much I drink water, which has been incredibly helpful while pregnant and now breastfeeding. BUT I'm pretty sure it's everyone's goal to drink more water in a day. I love @livelarq for more than just being a water bottle though...1) they have a purification system built in that uses UV light to kill 99.9999% of bacteria and viruses 2) they're double insulated so they keep cold water cold and hot drinks hot 3) they come in really cute colors so they attractive to look at 4) they make the perfect gifts! I've been using mine for over a year now and I'm giving them a full review over on galmeetsglam.com  today #drinkbrilliantly #sponsored

March‚Äôs birthstone was also thought to enhance the happiness of marriages. "[LALAoUNIS Take-Over] The final pieces I, Maria Lalaouni @iliaslalaounis, have chosen to share with you today are very festive. They have a lace-like effect and are inspired by a metalworking technique used in jewellery from the 3rd century AD until the Byzantine era called opus interrasile. Both pieces are articulated and playful and have a textured gold surface sprinkled throughout with diamonds. They are part of our Aurelia collection, which means ‚Äòthe golden one‚Äô. Wether I am wearing a small ring with symbolic references or an impressive pair of earrings, it always makes me feel special. Jewellery has a feel good factor. What we chose to wear expresses our individuality, complements our beauty and like in our ancestors' times also at times empowers us. Thank you Katerina for inviting us to share your Instagram with your followers. From all of us at LALAoUNIS we send you all our very best wishes for a Golden year!!!
.
.
.

"#Bromo in translation from Javanese means the name of one of the Supreme gods of Hinduism ‚Äì Brahma. Local citizens called tenggerese, direct descendants of the ancient Kingdom of Majapahit, have been carried sacrifices to the volcano for more than five hundred years with the requests not to erupt. By the way, volcanoes of the Bromo-Tengger-Semeru National Park are located in the sand sea ‚Äì the mixture of the sand and ash which forms so-called erg. This place is unique ‚Äì in Indonesia you won‚Äôt find erg nowhere else. The area is protected by the government from the beginning of 20th century

#letsfeeliran #ŸÅŸÖ_ÿ™ÿ±€åŸæ #shiraz #pinkmosque #iran #visitiran #–∏—Ä–∞–Ω"
"The name ‚Äòtraditional Iranian house‚Äô usually means nothing to a person who has never been to Iran. Frankly speaking, I was also confused ‚Äì these houses don‚Äôt have usual stars, like hotels, and to understand what awaits you there when you came to the country is really difficult.
The reality is that such houses are built only by a very wealthy owners for whom high level of service are not just words. Houses usually have a spacious yard, green garden and, necessarily, a pool in the center where a couple of watermelons usually float!Architectural solutions of traditional houses have almost no analogues in the world and allow to have perfect natural ‚Äòclimate control‚Äô. At summer, even in extreme heat, the lower part is always cool so it‚Äôs even possible to store fruits and vegetables there! And in the evenings guests are always welcome to have a cup of tea or coffee accompanied by the owners near the fountain with gold fishes!
x
–ù–∞–∑–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ —Ç—Ä–∞–¥–∏—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –∏—Ä–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏–π –¥–æ–º –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ –º–∞–ª–æ —á—Ç–æ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç —á–µ–ª–æ–≤–µ–∫—É, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π –Ω–∏ —Ä–∞–∑—É –Ω–µ –±—ã–ª –≤ –ò—Ä–∞–Ω–µ. –û—Ç–∫—Ä–æ–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ —Å–∫–∞–∂—É, –º–µ–Ω—è —ç—Ç–æ —Ç–æ–∂–µ —Å–º—É—â–∞–ª–æ ‚Äì –≤–µ–¥—å –ø—Ä–∏–≤—ã—á–Ω—ã—Ö –∑–≤—ë–∑–¥, –∫–∞–∫ –≤ –æ—Ç–µ–ª—è—Ö, —É —Ç–∞–∫–∏—Ö –¥–æ–º–æ–≤ –Ω–µ—Ç –∏ –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç—å, —á—Ç–æ —Ç–µ–±—è –∂–¥—ë—Ç –≤ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–µ –≤ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–º –∂–∏–ª–∏—â–µ –ø–æ –ø—Ä–∏–µ–∑–¥—É –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–æ—á–Ω–æ —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ.

"Borujerdi house is one of the best examples of the atmosphere of luxury that prevailed in Kashan in the 19th century. The merchant from wealth family Seyyed Mehdi decided to surprise the family of his future wife and for 18 years spent time on construction of this, perhaps, one of the most beautiful houses in the city. In 2014, Borujerdi House was nominated one of the best historical houses in Asia, and in 2015 - received the status of UNESCO Top Choice in Iran. Some often compare it to the houses designed by Gaudi in Barcelona

"–û–Ω–∏ –Ω–µ –∑–Ω–∞–ª–∏, —á—Ç–æ –≤–æ–π–¥—É—Ç –≤ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—é –∏ —á—Ç–æ –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º–∫–∏ –Ω–∞–∑–æ–≤—É—Ç –∏—Ö  —Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–Ω–æ ‚Äò–¥–µ–∫–∞–±—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∞–º–∏‚Äô üíî –æ–Ω–∏ –º–µ—á—Ç–∞–ª–∏ –æ –≤—Å–µ–æ–±—â–µ–º —Ä–∞–≤–µ–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ, –æ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–µ –Ω–∞ –∑–µ–º–ª—é, —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–µ –≤–µ—Ä–æ–∏—Å–ø–æ–≤–µ–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è, —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–µ –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä–∞, –∏ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞–ª–∏ —Å–≤–æ–π –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚ùóÔ∏è–ù–æ –ø–æ—Ç–µ—Ä—è–ª–∏ –Ω–µ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥—É, –ø–æ—Ç–µ—Ä—è–ª–∏ –∂–∏–∑–Ω–∏. –¢—ã—Å—è—á–∏ –∏—Å–∫–∞–ª–µ—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —Å—É–¥–µ–±. –°–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è –≤–µ—Å—å –≤—ã–ø—É—Å–∫ ‚Äò–≠—Ç–æ –∫–∏–Ω–æ‚Äô –ø–æ—Å–≤—è—â—ë–Ω —Ñ–∏–ª—å–º—É –°–æ—é–∑ —Å–ø–∞—Å–µ–Ω–∏—è‚Äô üé¨ –Ω–µ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–≤–∑—è—Ç—ã–π –≤–∑–≥–ª—è–¥ –Ω–∞ –æ–±—Ä–æ—Å—à—É—é –ª–µ–≥–µ–Ω–¥–∞–º–∏ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—é, –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ —Ç–µ—Ö —Å–æ–±—ã—Ç–∏–π, –Ω–µ–≤–µ—Ä–æ—è—Ç–Ω–æ –∑—Ä–µ–ª–∏—â–Ω—ã–π –∏ —ç–º–æ—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π! üîù–í—Å—Ç—Ä–µ—á–∞–µ–º—Å—è –≤ 8.10 –ø–æ –ú–æ—Å–∫–≤–µüíò–ª—é–±–∏–º—ã–µ! 
They did not know yet that they will go down in history and that descendants will call them in romantic way ‚ÄòDecembrists‚Äô üíî they dreamed of universal equality, the right to land, freedom of religion, freedom of choice, and made their  own choice ‚ùóbut lost not only freedom, lost their lives. "‚ÄúCan you work out on an empty stomach?‚Äù ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£This is a question I get a lot from the #BBGcommunity, and what I've noticed with my clients that everyone is different! For me, I feel sick if I do a high intensity workout on an empty stomach. Also, in the morning I usually wake up hungry, so the first thing I want to do is eat, not train. I want to make sure that I have enough fuel, or food, in my body to be able to work out.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
BEFORE my bootcamp on Saturday (which was at 2pm) I ate as normal, so for breakfast I had toast with spinach, mushrooms and avocado and then lunch was sushi. I also snacked on fruit a couple of hours before my bootcamp started because I wanted to make sure I had enough fuel to smash it! ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Some women find they can work out on an empty stomach first thing in the morning and they feel fine, but for others, working out on an empty stomach might make them feel ill or like they‚Äôre not actually performing at their best. For anyone who plans to work out later in the day or the afternoon, I would always suggest you eat your meals and snacks as normal too. However if you‚Äôre a morning person that wants to work out before breakfast, then that‚Äôs okay too. If you work out after work or in the evening, I would always suggest you wait one-and-a-half hours after eating before you train. The main thing to consider is what feels right for YOU and YOUR body. There's nothing worse than finishing a workout and feeling unwell, so do what makes you feel happy, confident and strong! üòÅüí™üèª"
What an incredible trip!!! I‚Äôve been away for almost a whole month in New York, Sydney and Dubai and it‚Äôs been amazing to revisit some of my favourite cities! I feel so lucky to that @tobi_pearce and I have been able to travel with Arna and show her the world - it just makes me want to explore more places with her and introduce her to new countries and different cultures. Even though I absolutely love travelling, there is nothing like that feeling of coming home, especially to see my sweet baby girl. I CANNOT wait to see her again! Being away from her these last few days has been SO hard but I know she‚Äôs being cuddled by someone in my family literally every second she‚Äôs awake lol. üòÇ It has been the most amazing month of connecting with the #BBGcommunity as well - thank you so much to everyone for your support, especially for my IGTV series, Begin Again. I was so nervous about getting out of my comfort zone and being vulnerable, but the comments and messages you have sent have made me realise just how lucky I am to be part of this community of women from around the world. You all make me feel so grateful and SO proud! üôåüèºüí™üèº PS there is a new episode of Begin Again coming out tomorrow and I promise that it will seriously inspire you - STAY TUNED!!! üì∫
To be honest, I was actually SO nervous about my Dubai Active bootcamp. In the weeks leading up to it I felt as though people would be wondering if I can actually do everything I say I can do. The incredible thing was that when it came time to start, I felt nothing but encouragement from you ladies - there was SO much excitement in the room and you made any nerves I had completely disappear. Thank you so much to everyone who was there, you KILLED IT! I‚Äôm SO ready for another bootcamp now - where should I go next? Comment below!

Bali
Personal footage behind the scene. Depicting the situation of Labuan Bajo. The other side of it.
"Art has the power to communicate; influence feeling and change perception. Art has the ability to interact with and educate the viewers about the earth issue, spreading awareness about such topics. We feel an instinctual need to take care of the things we feel connected to. Art can help renew, or sparks anew, our connection with nature.

A documentary project that I did with @_dozzy for @artotelgroup in collaboration with @wwf_id newest platform for environmental issue and sustainable movement.

In effort to raise awareness and donation for plastic pollution in Labuan bajo, @windisalomo as the art director invited @mulyakarya_yk, a collective of artist from Yogyakarta for a residency trip to create an artwork that reflect these issues.

I understand that we are facing a lot of environmental issues. But it comes along with an equal variety of solution for it. This is just a very tiny part of the effort.

Tomorrow I will share the full documentary, also @jessicajeli thinking process on developing the ArtotelEarth visual identity. Hope you guys enjoy it."
"It‚Äôs not always about the big idea, the tech solution and the grand plan. Sometimes all we need to make a better city is some humanity.

Humanity in harmony.

Hari ini kembali lagi ke Anyer, bersama keluarga tercinta."
Inisiasi sederhana dengan mimpi luar biasa. @stoiktrisula

"Building bridges with @OutwardBoundOman ‚Äì The Duke of Cambridge joined young Omanis taking part in a training exercise at the Wadi al Arbaeen.

Outward Bound, which launched in Wales in 1941 to equip young people with important life skills through learning and adventures in the wild, was established in Oman in 2009.

At the wadi, The Duke joined young people, instructors and members of the community as they took part in activities designed to develop skills including leadership, resilience, and teamwork.

Photos üì∑ PA / Kensington Palace

#RoyalVisitOman"
"Today, The Duchess of Cambridge became Royal Patron of @Family_Action.

Her Majesty The Queen @TheRoyalFamily has passed the patronage to The Duchess having held the role for over 65 years.

The Duchess joined children and families supported by Family Action at a Christmas tree farm and helped them to make Christmas decorations, eco-friendly reindeer food, and post their letters to Father Christmas!

Her Royal Highness also helped the children find Christmas trees for Family Action pre-schools, before heading back inside for some hot chocolate.

Family Action was founded in 1869 to help families in difficulty by giving them practical help and support. The charity works directly with vulnerable or disadvantaged children and families, and provides services including perinatal mental health services, counselling and therapeutic support, and the mentoring of children, young people and adults.

The new patronage aligns with The Duchess‚Äôs longstanding work on the early years, and the importance of supporting children and families during this seminal period of their lives."
"Near the Wadi al Arbaeen, The Duke of Cambridge visited the mountain village of Suwaih, where he received a spectacular musical welcome from the locals.

After meeting some of the locals, The Duke joined the village elders at an outdoor majlis seating area to learn more about life and challenges in the village today.

Photos üì∑ PA / Kensington Palace

#RoyalVisitOman"
"Last night, The Duchess of Cambridge joined The Queen, The Prince of Wales and other Members of the Royal Family at a reception for @NATO leaders at Buckingham Palace, to mark 70 years of the Alliance.

The North Atlantic Treaty - or Washington Treaty - forms the basis of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organisation). It was signed on the 4th April 1949 by 12 founding members.

The NATO Alliance is now formed of 29 countries. It exists to protect the people and territory of its members, and is founded on the principle of collective defence.

The Duchess, along with other Members of the Royal Family, welcomed NATO leaders, members of their delegations and NATO staff in the Picture Gallery."
"Joining local fishermen üé£ on the traditional fishing skiffs on the beach in Oman, The Duke of Cambridge heard about how they fish, the challenges to sustainability, and actions being taken to conserve Oman‚Äôs marine environment.

At the Marine Science Centre The Duke also met Omani scientists collaborating with @cefasgovuk, to learn more about how the UK is supporting Oman aquaculture and fisheries to become more sustainable, particularly in the face of climate change.

#RoyalVisitOman"
"The Duke of Cambridge has spent time in Kuwait üá∞üáº and Oman üá¥üá≤ understanding the important security history of the region, and the UK‚Äôs üá¨üáß current links with both countries from a defence perspective.

In Kuwait, The Duke joined Kuwaiti and UK troops at Exercise Desert Warrior for the bi-annual training exercise.

The Duke then travelled to Musandam in Oman to learn more about the Royal Navy of Oman‚Äôs responsibilities monitoring maritime traffic passing through the Strait of Hormuz.

Oman and Kuwait are key partners for the UK ‚Äì The Duke met military personnel in both countries who are sharing expertise to improve security üì∑ Kensington Palace / PA

#RoyalVisitKuwait #RoyalVisitOman"
"In a traditional Kuwaiti tent in the desert outside of Kuwait City ‚õ∫Ô∏è The Duke of Cambridge joined Sheikh Mohamed Abdullah and young Kuwaitis for a special event to experience what makes rural Kuwaiti culture so unique üá∞üáºincluding traditional Kuwaiti music and crafts, pit cooking and falconry.

#RoyalVisitKuwait #Kuwait"
"Shooting hoops üèÄ at the Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre (@ascckw), where The Duke of Cambridge saw how the museum is educating and engaging young Kuwaitis in innovative ways across a range of areas, from space exploration and robotics to natural history and human biology.

The Duke joined children from local primary schools as they explored a number of the museum‚Äôs interactive zones, and heard more about how the cultural centre is enhancing UK-Kuwait üá¨üáßüá∞üáº relations, particularly in education and culture.

As part of his visit, The Duke also highlighted the role played by the British Council (@kwbritish) in empowering the next generation, particularly through the programme ‚ÄòTaqaddam‚Äô, (Arabic for ‚ÄòMoving forward‚Äô) which encourages innovative thinking among Kuwaiti school children to build up their life skills.

#RoyalVisitKuwait #Kuwait"
"On the first day of his official visit to Kuwait, at the Jahra Nature Reserve The Duke of Cambridge learned more about Kuwait‚Äôs ambitious plans to protect its natural environment from human and environmental challenges.

Scientists from Kuwait‚Äôs Environmental Public Authority (@epa_kw) üá∞üáº and the UK‚Äôs Centre for Environment, Fisheries & Aquaculture Science (@cefasgovuk) üá¨üáß are working in partnership to promote Kuwait‚Äôs biodiversity and inform its approach to marine environment conservation.

The Duke joined them on the reserve‚Äôs salt marshes, reed beds and sandy sabkha flats for several activities studying the wetlands‚Äô wildlife üî≠  including identifying some of the 300 species of birds seen at the reserve.

Kuwait is working to tackle the global issue of plastic pollution through a combination of raising public awareness, recycling, education and organising beach cleans - The Duke also joined a beach clean at the reserve.

#RoyalVisitKuwait #Kuwait"
"üéÑ We invite you to join The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Mary Berry as they serve a festive feast to thank those who are spending their Christmas helping others.

On the BBC‚Äôs A Berry Royal Christmas üì∫ The Duke and Duchess are joined by cookery legend Mary Berry across four engagements as they prepare festive food for a very royal event to thank all those working and volunteering over the Christmas period...take a look at our other post to find out more.

"NEW‚ùóÔ∏èadidas x Dan Freebairn
If you‚Äôve been following my Instagram Story the last few weeks (see my highlights if you haven‚Äôt), you will have seen that I‚Äôve been working on a poster for next years adidas Superstar Anniversary. The print is now finished and I spent this afternoon hand signing and numbering 100 of them. Info on how you can get your hands on one will be announced soon. ‚úåüèª
‚Äî
Like all my projects with @adidasoriginals, I was really excited to be working with them again. But this one felt extra special... if you‚Äôve followed me a while, you‚Äôll know my favourite shoe is the Superstar. So when adidas asked me to be the one to tell this story and use my illustrations to highlight key moments in the shoe‚Äôs 50 year history, I was truly honoured. (Thanks to the team, you know who you are) I already knew a lot about the shoe, but I dived deeper to learn more and really immerse myself in the project. Then came the challenge of narrowing down 50 years of collaborations, anniversary colorways, introduction of new technologies, hyped releases and of course general releases. This I couldn‚Äôt do on my own. So I brought in two experts, @dave.lurky and @superstar_luke, both highly respected guys within the UK scene especially when it comes to shell toes, and both have unbelievable Superstar knowledge and collections. (I can‚Äôt thank you both enough for your input). I wanted the final list of shoes to touch on the Superstar‚Äôs early development, changes in design, shape, manufacturing and materials. As well as highlight key collaborations, pairs only true Superstar collectors will appreciate and iconic releases known by us all. I think we got the balance just right and I‚Äôm really happy with the final outcome. I can truthfully say I‚Äôve never put this much effort, detail and thought into a single poster before. I hope you like it, there‚Äôs more photos of the signing session in my story (shots to @morelifemyg for the shots), and as I said previously, stay tuned for info on how you can get one. A little teaser, these will be available for FREE. Put your money away üòâ‚úåüèª
‚Äî
@adidasoriginals
#adidasSuperstar
#CreatedWithadidas
#Superstar50"

‚Äî

What‚Äôs your favorite?

Chardonnet-Vengetind-Chardonnet-Lofoten"
It was 2 days before the Golden Trail Series final in the Annapurna‚Äôs region in Nepal, probably the most intelligent thing was to taper and do something short, but it is just hard to stay quiet on those surroundings. @davidemagnini had enough of sitting in a car so did I, so we jump down and started running, then that afternoon we went for a ‚Äúchill‚Äù run up to 4000m and on the way down we hit this sunset. I like racing but when we‚Äôre in places like that the energy that is given by the environment is just to strong. That day we ran 3,5h 25km with 2900 elevation meters. At the end it wasn‚Äôt that bad decision since I won the race and Davide was the runner up.
I think this image summarizes on a good way what sport means to me. A mean of transport, a (long) path to try a difficult goal, the mental processes of imagining how to do it, the connection between us and the mountains, that smallness feeling, the solitude, the acceptance of probable failure, the will of embracing compromise.

"In 2012 my feet measured 25cm long. Same as now, same as the previous years. But somehow I thought it would be a good idea to try a smaller ski boot (to win 4 or 5 grams, to be more fitted, or just to try...) so I asked @pierregignouxcarbonskiboots for a 24 size. In the first trainings it wasn‚Äôt that painful, and I thought that with the time the boot (or my feet) would adapt. But apparently the carbon doesn‚Äôt mold as I thought. The only problem was (1) when it was very cold and (2) when it was very long. In the first case, after a long cold day in Migot at Chardonnet (previous post) my big toe was a bit cold (for a few years). In the second, my feet were bleeding a bit after every world cup race. So after 3 month I went back to my size 25 boots...
#obsession #failandlearn"
"7 years ago @vivianbruchez introduced me to steep skiing. That day we meet at the bergschrund of Chardonnet, we climbed to its summit and skied the north face via the Migot spur line. Before that Stephane Brosse had introduced me to the more classical steep skiing limes in Cham and the Aravis, and show me a bit of the wonders of this way to climb and downclimb summits. That day in Chardonnet was the first time I skied with Vivian (and with ‚Äòlarge‚Äô skis) and afterwards I have been learning a lot from him in all our journeys. Since that day steep skiing has been one of my main activities.

"Headstand is the foundation of all other inversions. Put in the work to build good technique when you‚Äôre learning to balance in Sirsasana and you‚Äôll have a stable base to progress from. But that also works the other way. Whatever bad technique you learn gets multiplied as the poses get harder. So what may have been ok for headstand can sometimes create serious structural issues in forearm balance or handstand. If you have a slight banana shape in headstand, you‚Äôll have an ever more pronounced banana shape as the inversions get more demanding. Good technique is not about right and wrong. It‚Äôs about physical efficiency, energy optimization and long term health of the body. 
_
Tips‚Äî
1. Foundation‚Äîwork your shoulders and keep the elbows rooted. If you feel your foundation shifting, don‚Äôt try and lift up.
2. Core‚Äîkeep a slight engagement of the front body while in headstand and draw the lower ribs in.
3. Center line‚Äîpractice orienting towards the center line of the body by using all the muscles to draw in and up.
4. Patience‚Äîbe willing to put in the work even if it means you won‚Äôt do the pose for awhile, be willing to fail properly rather than fake succeed. 
5. Feeling‚Äîconsciously feel the body and work from a place of embodiment and understanding rather than from force.
6. Practice‚Äîkeep practicing, keep the faith.
_

"We have been told there is someone perfect out there for us who will complete us, a knight in shining armor, a fairytale princess, the mythic ‚Äúone‚Äù we have been waiting for. But we must each fall madly in love with ourselves to be whole. No other person carries the key to unlock your hidden potential. It‚Äôs you who has to make your own magic.
_
We have been trained to want a linear, straight path forward and up. More, bigger better, stronger, deeper. The endless cycle of desire devouring everything in its wake, thinking that just one more thing will finally be enough, but it never is. Real life is full of peaks and valleys. Joy and happiness are part of very foundation of the journey, not the prize you get for running up the mountain all fast and furious. 
_
We sleep walk through life, like zombies, following subconscious orders that lead to our own demise without ever realizing. We are conditioned to be cogs in a machine whose sole end is to devour everything. That is, until we wake up from the dream and jailbreak our minds. Then, it all changes. You no longer wait to live a good life, you allow life live out its goodness through you.
_
Awakening is returning.
The spiritual path is nothing more than a homecoming. 
You are who you have always been.
But you are not who you think you are.

"What is Yoga?
_
Hint: Yoga is much more than just bending, twisting and lifting the body.
_
Yoga as it is understood and practiced in the contemporary Western world usually begins with the body. Many students come to the practice in search of physical healing or physical benefits, such as increased flexibility or strength. Others come to the practice thinking it will be a good workout. The body and the yoga poses, known as asanas, are not ends in and of themselves. Instead these are tools used for the cultivation of a more subtle state of mind. 
_
Truly understanding what yoga is can be difficult. And perhaps yoga is many different things to many different people. As a beginner, you may think of yoga as stretching, twisting or bending the body. Some may think of yoga as another fitness trend that promises health. If you skim through media images, you might think yoga is all young, fit, flexible, able-bodied people doing handstands at beautiful destinations around the world. For some aspiring yogis, yoga represents a career path. For the ancient yogis of India, yoga was something much deeper...
_
Read the full blog on https://www.kinoyoga.com/what-is-yoga/
_
Sign up for my new challenge on https://omstars.com/challenges/yoga-is-30day-challenge-with-kino"

"Where you are going is not always where you have been. Good times may pass you by in fits of obliviousness and naive disregard. Happiness always appears like it will last forever. Bliss feels eternal. But, everything changes. The highs and lows twist and turn, leaving waves of growth and change in their wake. You might only realize where you‚Äôve been once everything has shifted. It‚Äôs often in retrospect that you see that the very moment you took for granted was indeed special, filled with its own blessings. It‚Äôs easy to miss the magic whileworrying or stressing about some uncontrollable outcome. It requires great maturity and awareness to recognize happiness as happiness, joy as joy, sadness as sadness, anger as anger, and all as impermanent. 
_
I have changed so much since this photo was taken that it feels like I live in a whole new galaxy. Sometimes I am embarrassed about the bad decisions I made, how I was swept away by materialism, ego, fame, and other worldly goals. But then I remember not to beat myself up about the person I was. Everything I‚Äôve been through has lead me here, to a place of peace filled with a joyful kindness I never imagined possible. Where I‚Äôve been does not define where I am, where I am is not where I‚Äôm going. And yet, I am here, whole, complete, going nowhere and everywhere, same, same, but oh so different. 
_

"Asteya. Non-stealing. What does this mean to you and how do you apply this core yogic concept to your practice and your life?
_
If you run a business it could mean to refrain from engaging in unethical business practices, such as stealing, bribery, intimidation, bullying, deceit, cheating, copying, misrepresenting, misappropriation, and other similar morally questionable and harmful actions. 
_
In your practice, it could mean not doing poses or practices that your body isn‚Äôt ready for even if your mind desires then. It could also mean not claiming the knowledge or teaching of another person or culture as your own. For Western yogis, it could mean consciously refraining from acts of cultural appropriation.
_
I‚Äôm not here to provide the definitive answer, but I am here the spark the processing of questioning. How else do you see Asteya and how else would you apply it to practice and life?
_
#practiceyogachangeyourworld #onebreathatime
Photo @ifilmyoga üåª
_
Outfit is my design by @liquidoactive

Black Friday deals are on. You can get all my designs and a yes let membership to @omstarsofficial for a steal (pun-intended). üòä"
"I heard a rumor that there‚Äôs only a day or two left before the @secondhome_la Pavilion closes at La Brea Tar Pits here in Los Angeles. So if it‚Äôs something you‚Äôve seen or heard about and you were waiting to go to, don‚Äôt wait anymore. I recently had the chance to see it when my dear friends @mumhad1ofthose & @descurran were visiting from London, and I was relieved to find it is free to enter. I‚Äôm always a fan of art that‚Äôs free for all to experience because it‚Äôs one of the most beautiful things in life. And while I understand it can‚Äôt always be free, when it is, it removes that barrier to entry and gives everyone the chance to be inspired in the way art can be inspiring and entertaining.
.
Anyway, the #secondhomela pop up ‚Äútent-like‚Äù structure designed by SelgasCano known as an art sculpture is part of Second Home which is a socially responsible British business with a belief that diversity makes creativity stronger. They create spaces that bring diverse groups of people together and that‚Äôs something I admire. While it has been here in LA, it has hosted live music, performance art, talks, dances and screenings. Their hashtag is #lovelettertoLA but they might as well say it‚Äôs a love letter to humanity and what can happen when we come together in a safe space where differences are celebrated and community is valued.
.
That being said, the co-working and private offices spaces that Second Home offers which are permanent are not exactly affordable. But this is a feed about travel and that‚Äôs another conversation for another day. If you‚Äôre traveling around Los Angeles this weekend, stop by the Pavilion before it closes and let me know what you think of it.... üòâüíõ
.
.
.
#kaguideLA #discoverLA #publicartwork #publicartinstallation #selgascano"
"Didn‚Äôt sleep well last night after seeing my dear friend @neumarc‚Äôs Stories from a Venezia where there is a flooding event occurring, bringing high tides just shy of the devastating record-high ‚Äúaqua alta‚Äù of 1966. St Mark‚Äôs Basilica is flooded. Which, before 2018, had happened only 4 times in more than 900 years. Or only 6 times total in 1,200 years depending on what and where you read online. üôÄ Because Marco is my friend, I worried for his safety and I still worry as the danger is not passed.
.
It‚Äôs stamped a much more personal note on a crisis that I‚Äôve already been aware of and have been trying to do my part to combat. We can try to ignore it, we can choose to believe it‚Äôs not as bad as some say or even that we can‚Äôt do much to change things. But we can. And we must.
.
We all have hundreds of choices a day that, made the right way - can help make a difference. We can try to eliminate all single use plastic from our lives. We can fly less and take cleaner transportation when we do travel. ‚úàÔ∏è We can donate to organizations that plant trees which absorb co2 or even more importantly, give to organizations that protect old trees from being cut down since older trees absorb co2 more rapidly than younger trees. üå≥ We can vote in representatives and leaders that believe there is a climate crisis and that will fight to make laws and processes that will combat the problems. You can request that your energy supplier only use clean energy - something Dant√© & I have done here in California. üí° We can unplug or power off our tech when we‚Äôre not using it. üîå We can choose not to waste food, grow our own food, eat less meat and buy local whenever possible. ü•¨ü•ï We can choose to walk, ride bikes or take public transportation instead of an Uber or Lyft. üö≤ We can choose to buy less and consume less. And so. much. more.
.
I know it‚Äôs not always easy to see how these actions might directly have a positive effect on lessening the occurrence of floods or wildfires. But they do. Research has proven that. We just have to choose to listen. And act. If not for ourselves, then for those we care about. ‚ù§Ô∏è"
Like I said yesterday, I partnered with @Ford and @LonelyPlanet to discover greater Los Angeles. #ad A map, that was painted on a wall just off Melrose, acted as the springboard for my adventures into the history and culture of Los Angeles. üå¥ My first stop was the mural which then led to Olvera Street, created in 1930 ‚Äúto preserve and present the customs and trades of early California." Today the area boasts many vendors who are second or third generation sellers as well as museums dedicated to Chinese, Italian & Mexican heritage. üá≤üáΩ Next I visited downtown‚Äôs Central Library, home of LA‚Äôs written history, beautiful rotundas and (when I was there) an exhibition of Ansel Adams photographs. üìö Then Highland Park Bowl, home of LA‚Äôs oldest bowling lanes and a dynamic spot to just hang out. It has a bar area with a steampunk-meets-vintage-sports vibe. The restored lanes are backed by a stunning mural that looks like it depicts California‚Äôs iconic Redwood and Sequoia trees. üé≥ I was happy to see the Original Farmer‚Äôs Market was part of this map-based exploration since it is one of my favorite places to go where the French store Monsieur Marcel is usually my first stop if I am planning a picnic or want a bottle of wine for a special occasion. It‚Äôs also a great choice if you‚Äôre craving multiple cuisines and want to share lots of small plates with friends. There are grocery vendors, a toy shop, a stall with the largest selection of hot sauces that I have ever seen and more. üá´üá∑ Ending closest to our home at El Capitan theatre, I watched a movie from a balcony seat which took me back to the days of going to plays and musicals with my mom when I was a kid. üé≠ After perusing all the classic black and white Hollywood photos in the hallways, I was pretty much the last one to leave before seating for the next showing started and what was happening outside? Of course, setup for a movie premiere! üìΩ Check out my Stories for video from all these stops üöô #everydayexplorations
I‚Äôm excited to bring you two posts telling the story of how I partnered with @Ford and @LonelyPlanet to discover greater Los Angeles. #ad A map, that was painted as a mural on a wall just off Melrose, acted as the springboard for my exploration of the history and culture of my city. I traveled around from Highland Park to Hollywood to Downtown Los Angeles to discover and document five total spots represented on the map. Have you ever wanted to know more about the Mexican culture of Los Angeles or the historic theaters that often host the premieres for the movies crafted in and outside of Hollywood? Then you will enjoy what I have to share! I‚Äôm looking forward to sharing more tomorrow and here is a teaser from my journey, an image captured in an area that‚Äôs dedicated to celebrating, preserving and protecting the city‚Äôs past. Check out my Stories today and tomorrow for a deeper look into the whole journey with videos from the spots I found on the mural. #everydayexplorations
"Thrilled to announce I‚Äôm partnering with @passionpassport for their latest Instagram Challenge with @hoteltonight. The big question is - what role does spontaneity play in your travels?
.
Are you a ‚Äúfly by the seat of your pants‚Äù traveler or do you like to plan ahead? ‚úàÔ∏è Do you prefer your days to be all scheduled out? üìù Or do you like to have the freedom of unplanned discovery that can lead to pleasant surprises? ü§î
.
I believe not every journey should have a planned itinerary and I‚Äôve come to think that way because most of my best travel memories were made in the space that a lack of planning provided. That‚Äôs why I was so happy to find out the theme for this particular challenge. üòç
.
