"Living in California has given me a new perspective on nature. Both its majesty and inherent wonder but also its capacity for destruction as I‚Äôve watched communities and lives all around our own home, affected by fire. When I took this photo many people assumed that‚Äôs what this was. In fact, it‚Äôs the effect of a 20 second exposure that captured the lights of cars as they drove through marine layer fog in Malibu Canyon.
.
Yet just after I posted this, the same hills were engulfed in flames and a year later, it‚Äôs happening again not far from where I stood to take this and in many other places around California.
.
I‚Äôve watched my friends displaced from their homes and can‚Äôt help but feel grateful to our public servants like firefighters and first responders who walk right into danger to ensure the rest of us go to sleep safely at night and wake up safe the next morning. I know that by choosing to live here it‚Äôs probably not a matter of if but just when, I will have need of the same protection. And that‚Äôs ok. Living here has taught me the value of gratefulness and the importance of cherishing each and every day when it‚Äôs happening.
.
If you‚Äôre a firefighter or first responder or anyone who helps keep others safe, thank you. If you know one, be extra kind to them, don‚Äôt take them for granted. And thank you too for supporting them because being their support isn‚Äôt always easy either. ‚ù§Ô∏è"
"Happy Halloween! üéÉüîÆ My treat, not trick, for the holiday is this last photo from picturesque Franconia in Germany. As delectable as the wines were, the half timbered-homes, towns and villages were almost enough to steal the show during my press trip with @germanytourism.
.
From B√ºrgstadt to Miltenberg to Volkach to Iphofen and K√∂nigsberg, there was no shortage of picturesque vistas and charming facades to capture so even if [gasp! üôÄ] wine isn‚Äôt your thing, Franconia still has much to inspire and thrill with its towns, food, people and history. I‚Äôll be publishing a full photo essay on my site before the weekend showing more. But for now, Stories will continue to go live and there‚Äôs already an article on every winery we visited live on kirstenalanaphotography dot com. Link in profile of course! #visitfranconia
.
.
.
.
#prettycities #halftimbered #halftimberedhouse #k√∂nigsberg #k√∂nigsberginbayern #germanytourism #germanytravel #visitgermany #culturetrip #living_destinations #prettylittletrips #europestyle_ #europestyle_germany"
Unless memory fails me, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äòve been in a wine region during harvest. What a special time it was to be in Franconia! The region is large enough, the soil diverse enough and the physical landscape changes in such a way that harvest was just completed in some of the towns we visited with @germanytourism while in other locales it was still occurring. I noticed that harvesting by hand was more common than I‚Äôve heard of in the industry at a larger scale, as were more traditional ways of processing grapes such as stomping them physically instead of using machines. The first image was taken in @hassbergetourismus where we went for a long walk in the rolling hills covered with vineyards, overlooking a valley punctuated by picturesque villages, and were able to see harvest taking place by hand before sitting down for a picnic lunch amongst the vines. What a magical experience, which I truly hope anyone who loves wine can have at minimum once in their life. To see the vines that grew the grapes that were in the wine we were drinking while talking with the people who harvested and made the wine, had an effect on the taste [for me] that is challenging to quantify. Though I‚Äôm realizing that as a photographer and storyteller, I value the connection to local people most of all while traveling. Now wine harvest is something I want to experience elsewhere to see how it might differ from place to place. After all, the same grapes can be used to make wines with such variety, the landscapes of wine areas can differ so much and yet the culture of the people who make wine can also have so many similarities.  I think it‚Äôs like humanity as a whole, in that we have more in common than we like to think and I wish we concentrated more often on what unites us rather than what divides us. Speaking of that, the group I did this press trip with was made up of people from Sweden, the Netherlands, China, Slovakia and the USA. Many have already begun to publish their articles and I wonder, would you like me to link to some of them in Stories so that you can read them in your native language if you‚Äôre from any of those countries? I‚Äôm happy to do so! ‚ù§Ô∏èüçáüç∑ #visitfranconia
"Do you like traveling to wine regions? Tasting wine when you travel, at wineries and in vineyards? I certainly do and yet, as I said before, I was surprised when I was invited by @germanytourism to #visitfranconia that not only did I not even know about this wine region but also that it's not exactly ""new."" Instead, just like in other wine areas around the world, there is a tradition of wine making in Franconia that goes back to at least the 1800s (even though some newer wineries were only formed in the 1970s, there's variety for sure, still it) means there are beautiful cellars and dramatic underground spaces all around the region. I showed a few, like the one pictured here at Zur Schwane in Volkach, in Stories already and those are saved as a permanent highlight in my profile. Another thing I was happy to learn while on this press trip is that Franconia has its own wine bottle in a shape that's quite unexpected. See the second photo to understand what I mean. There are many stories from many different residents that might explain its history but I think the most likely is that it's meant to symbolize the shape that was created when parts of animals were once used as the vessels to carry around liquid. When hung from a belt or trousers, the vessel bulged at the bottom and had a longer neck. It makes sense! Though doesn't exactly make me thirsty. Still, it's another fun piece of history and trivia for a region that has much to surprise and delight already. And I always love a good story.
.
Both images were taken with my #Pixel3 which has been impressing me with it's low light capability. I've always loved experimenting with smartphones of all kinds for photography and now that I have the 3, I can understand why so many of my photo colleagues are firmly #TeamPixel"
"Franconia Wine Region in Germany is a bit of an underdog in the landscape of European wines [in my experience]. Even working in travel now where wine is a significant part of so many stories, having grown up in a family where wine was always important in celebration, and having worked in a wine store in Brooklyn with my dear friend @joeybear85 where we often sold German white wines‚Ä¶ I departed for this trip thinking, ‚ÄúFranconia? Have I even had any wine from Franconia?‚Äù
üç∑
Did you know there was a German wine region called Franconia? Or Franken?
üç∑
Obviously, there is - I‚Äôve been there now and wow is it ever a great example of how we should never bet against the underdog. Like other regions in the country, Franconia boasts some incredible white wines with the Silvaner heavily featuring in many winery lineups. It was sometimes referred to, during my visit, as THE grape of Franconia. But the region also boasts other award-winning White wines and a slew of notable Red wines. The changing climate has enabled the region to diversify production which has also been helped by the generational shifts that naturally occur in so many industries where children take over from parents. Some Franconia wineries are only on their 2nd generation of ownership but are already producing wines that should get far more recognition worldwide than they do. Some families, like F√ºrst [VDP] who own the land pictured in this image, have been making wine since the 1600s.. But more recent generations have been the ones to truly innovate & facilitate change. For instance, it was Paul F√ºrst & his son who actually undid some of the modernization that had occurred in the family‚Äôs system of making wine and returned many processes back to an older way of doing things. When we visited, grapes were being stomped by foot ala ‚ÄòI Love Lucy.‚Äô And a photo from that moment is one of my favorites that I took during the trip. As were, the F√ºrst wines. I brought a bottle home with me that will age well, which I will save to share with loved ones during some special moment in the future. I hope to inspire you to take a similar journey with the posts I will share about this press trip. ‚ù§Ô∏è"
"Just home from drinking all the wine and wandering all the most absurdly picturesque streets I‚Äôve ever wandered in @germanytourism and now that I‚Äôve finally gone through the thousands of photos I took during my press trip, I‚Äôm looking forward to sharing the stories of the adventure, starting tomorrow.
.
But it would mean the world to me if you‚Äôd head to @bryanminear‚Äôs profile or @wethecreatorspod and listen to Bryan‚Äôs latest podcast episode where he and I discuss the ups and downs of a life on social media, what drives me as a travel photographer, why Ansel Adams is the bomb and what countries I always end up saying are my favorite even though I really have a dozen favorites....
.
Podcasts are having a moment again and I‚Äôm grateful Bryan took the time to feature me on his. I‚Äôd so appreciate if you all show him some love and also let me know what you think of the episode. üôèüèºüíõ"

.

It‚Äòs outrageous, unimaginable!
Iran, a beautiful country with beautiful people. But at the moment people are dying there in silence. The regime has shut down the internet since saturday to prevent Iranians from sharing their stories. Protesters are being killed. Thousands arrested. It‚Äôs hard to get any news out into the world since they are being totally cut off. My thoughts are with the iranians. Stay strong! #iranprotests

"These past few weeks have been so unimaginably hard for Bahamians, especially on the islands of Abaco and Freeport. People have lost everything- loved ones, family, possessions, homes. Whatever you cherish it‚Äôs gone for these communities. This is far from a quick fix, it will take years and years of rebuilding. The @thompsonfamilyfoundation will do everything in its power to help with relief efforts right now and for many years to come. All contributions no matter how big or small will go long way and are greatly appreciated.

Secondly, shame on our current administration for not welcoming our Bahamian neighbors in their greatest time of need. I‚Äôve been so lucky to visit my family in Nassau since childhood, and in those times I‚Äôve seen countless Americans use the Bahamian islands as their playground for letting loose and vacationing. And now we turn our back on the people who welcomed us with open arms, when they‚Äôve lost everything !? There‚Äôs no excuse for this... and if you have one your a real piece of üí© 
Bahamians will persevere, but help along the way is greatly appreciated. Thank you ‚ù§Ô∏è üáßüá∏"

"goodbye november, goodbye golden times - i think #autumnwasokay here in #berlin for sure.
took this shot from top of the berlin victory column towards tiergarten park by using the manual focus of my #HuaweiP30Pro to adjust the sharpness in this close up.
#hfk #huaweifotokonsortium @huaweimobilede | ad/anzeige"
"a few days ago i already showed you the entrance hall of the #goetheanum complex, that‚Äôs located near basel / switzerland (have a look at my recent posts if you missed it).
here are some final #outofthephone snaps from that quirky place that left me like something between brutalism and hobbiton. what do you think?
it‚Äôs definitely a place to visit for all #archilovers plus people who like batik-looking stairwells!
enjoy your friday everyone!
#dornach #rudolfsteiner #goetheanumstyle"
"captured some #residensity on my very short stop in #mannheim last friday.
these #brutiful towers are actually some of the tallest in the region (100m tall) and if you swipe left you can also see a view from above + some perfectly aligned birds at the nearby river #neckar.
after christmas i‚Äôll be in mannheim again, trying to make more time to take shoot the city.
took all pictures straight #outofthephone using my @huaweimobilede #HuaweiP30Pro in 5x zoom (135mm focal lenght) - i can only repeat it became my favourite lense on this device.
#hfk #huaweifotokonsortium | ad/anzeige"
"another snapshot from last week‚Äôs short stop in rainy #basel when @vomstreunern stuck inside ‚Äòintersections‚Äô by #richardserra - a monumental outdoor sculpture that you can find right in front of the basel theatre.
#bepartofart #puddlegram #outofthephone"
"this week i had the chance to visit the #goetheanum building in #dornach (switzerland), maybe you‚Äôve seen some of the footage in my stories earlier.
the location is known as the world center of the anthroposophical movement, founded and designed by #rudolfsteiner in the 1920‚Äòs. as you can see in this picture he turned away from the concept of using right angles as a basis for the building plan, which leads to many odd shapes and architectural details and means you won‚Äôt find any real symmetric structure throughout the whole complex. all of these organic looking walls, columns and ceilings have been set up with visible concrete, which wasn‚Äôt very common at this time either - a vanguard of brutalist architecture so to say.
as i went to a rudolf steiner / waldorf school when i was a kid and teenager, it was kinda like a school time flashback for me to visit that place too.
#concretewonderland #tinypeopleinbigplaces #outofthephone"
"who else had a typical melancholic november sunday? i went for some hours by train through silent and gloomy germany today and had lots of time to think and contemplate but also to review this picture that i took only 3 days ago in #berlin. yes, it‚Äôs yet another classic sunset view but totally fits my mood today...
just like many other pictures on my account i took this picture handheld straight #outofthephone with my @huaweimobilede #HuaweiP30Pro - i guess the 5x zoom became easily my favourite weapon of choice when i take photos, even in lower light situations. always surprised by the outcome!
#hfk #huaweifotokonsortium | ad/anzeige"
"mixed memories of my latest trip to #eindhoven and #helmond - two dutch cities in the region of #brabant, only 15 minutes away from each other and both with a lot of interesting urban projects as you could hopefully see.
thanks to @visitbrabant for including me in this years #brabantisopen campaign, i‚Äôve learnt a lot about the region during my two trips in september and november and felt some great hospitality too.
you can check out all the other posts via #konaction_brabant if you like.
picture locations:
1&3: eindhoven - volta galvani
2: helmond - cube houses
4&5: helmond - brandevoort district
6: helmond - helmond museum
7: eindhoven - hartje new york building
8: eindhoven - underpass close to the central station
#visitbrabant | ad/anzeige"
"one more interesting project i‚Äôve visited in #eindhoven 
it‚Äôs actually a former philips radio factory complex from the 1920‚Äòs. just a few years ago it got transformed by @diederendirrix architects into a modern residential housing project. the industrial building is heritage listed, so the architects retained many traces of the past, that would still fit the overall look and feel. you can see the original concrete beams in the pictures above for example.
nowadays the building is used for social housing with quite affordable rents, which i find quite amazing.
special thanks to @nappyc taking time and showing us around that hidden gem.
#thisiseindhoven #strijps #antonbuilding #brabantisopen"
"ad/anzeige | only 15 minutes by train from eindhoven you‚Äôll reach the pitoresque city of #helmond with more cool places to discover.
i went there for about 24hours and was especially curious to see some of the first cube houses, designed by dutch architect #pietblom from 1977 - even earlier than the famous golden #kubuswoningen in rotterdam.
for helmond he made 3 prototypes first and 15 more later, that are nowadays still inhabited by normal residents. his plan was to tilt the cube of a conventional building exactly 45 degrees to optimise the use of space and light within the houses.
although the should look like a group of trees standing next to each other, i had the impression the look like mushrooms growing out of the pavement.
anyway, it‚Äòs been great to try to capture these truly unique buildings in different light situations.
since tiny houses are becoming en vogue again, they might helpful to overcome the split between increasing urban density and personal individuality on the other hand.
i am really curious what you guys think about this kind of buildings. would you even like to live in some of these or does it seem to impractical for you? let me know in the comments!
#visitbrabant #brabantisopen @visitbrabant @helmondmarketing"
"ad/anzeige | 5 pictures to proof that #eindhoven is a great place to visit if you wanna get inspired by bold architectural projects and progressive urban living (swipe left)
pic1: entrance of a bicycle garage in the city centre, designed by #massimilanofuksas 
pic2: facade of a student apartment complex by @vissersroelands 
pic 3: courtyard of blok 61 residential building by @architecten.en.en 
pic4: fragment of volta galvani - urban development project by @geurst_schulze architects
pic5: cultural redevelopment of the old philips factory complex at #strijps area.
which one is your favourite colour pop?
#thisiseindhoven #visitbrabant #brabantisopen @visitbrabant @eindhovencity"
"ad/anzeige | hello from colourful #eindhoven - this week i am spending my time in the south of the netherlands, invited once again by the friendly guys from @visitbrabant 
the city impressed me with a lot of cool locations, especially newer architecture projects.
for example this amazing sports hall complex by @liag_architects was on my list to see for sure.
what are your thoughts about that kind of design? let me know in the comments if you like!
#visitbrabant #brabantisopen #thisiseindhoven @eindhovencity"
"that classic #berlin autumn shot, taken from top of the victory column looking down towards tiergarten park...
last time i was up here is already a few years ago and i haven‚Äôt seen that view in autumn either. guess it was worth checking out, despite some really rainy and windy weather yesterday.
.
it‚Äôs also my image for saying a quick goodbye to berlin as i am travelling to the netherlands for a few days again.
have a look at my stories if you wanna know what i am up to this time
#autumnisokay #berlinclicheshots #outofthephone"

.

.

~ So it‚Äôs probably already clear that my favorite animals to photograph are foxes. I was going trough my archives for my up coming book when I realized that I have photographed foxes at least in six different countries! That‚Äôs pretty cool! So here‚Äôs a fox portrait collection from my past five years of intense fox photographing all around the world. ( Countries: Netherlands, Greenland, Chile, Finland, Iceland & Svalbard) Which fox is your favorite? ü¶ä
~ 6 am in the streets of Nuorgam the northern most town in Finland. I‚Äôm on my way to the airport, tired after week of shooting on a project in the Arctic region. I‚Äôm rushing towards the airport when I suddenly see a familiar looking movement on the side of the road. It‚Äôs -28 Celsius that morning so the fox is on a full winter fluffy coat. I jump out of the car and observe the movements of the fox for a few minutes before it‚Äôs gone to do its daily routines. A brief moment of joy and sense of no time. I jump back to the car and I am back to do my own daily routines. It‚Äôs these little moments and encounters that I live for.
~ Approx. 2000kg (4,400lb) Walrus curiously watching my moves in the wildernesses of Svalbard.
~ Views from the Arctic
~ Fox mother heading out for the evening hunt.
~ Beaver looking for delicious sticks for lunch.
~ First signs of winter
~ Midday rest in the Arctic
~ Frozen Arctic. Here‚Äôs a collection of photos from last week‚Äôs adventure in Lapland and from the Northern Norway. Which one you like the most? #thisisarctic @thisisarcticcom
~ Photogenic roads in the Northern Norway. #thisisarctic

For those of you that are inspired by me, remember this, always help the people around you. Don‚Äôt always make it about you. Don‚Äôt be selfish. Don‚Äôt just have yes men around you, have people that will tell you how it is and be real with you 100% of the time.

Time to end Logan‚Äôs career tomorrow... üì∑: @bastakespics
It‚Äôs almost that time... üì∑: @thisisamandaw
The Best Ever @floydmayweather
Fight camp done. This has hands down been the hardest thing I‚Äôve ever done in my life. Training twice a day (3 times on Tuesdays) and mountain runs on the Saturdays with Sundays to rest. My body has been pushed to a point I never knew I had. I came to Vegas to be trained by the best with no distractions and I have come out an absolute beast. Throughout this period I have missed my family, my friends and my beautiful girlfriend, but they all understood that me training in Vegas was necessary. I‚Äôm not lying when I say this, Logan Paul will not be able to handle me. I‚Äôm gonna drag him into deep waters. Shannon Briggs and all his other yes men can motivate Logan all they want, but when November 9th comes and he‚Äôs staring into my eyes in that ring, he will know he‚Äôs already lost. I hit hard, you know that, so I hope you‚Äôre prepared to work Logan, because 6 rounds of hell is coming your way...That‚Äôs if you last that long...Thank you @cityathleticboxing for your hospitality.

A ravaged camp 1, deep in interior #Antarctica 7 years ago. Oh the things we do for fun! Taken on my very first assignment for @natgeo @natgeochannel on what was among the hardest expeditions I‚Äôve ever been a part of with @mikelibecki @coryrichards @freddiewilkinson . I‚Äôve been blessed with a life of fun and adventure but this weekend I‚Äôll be starting the biggest yet with my wife @danahrichardson as we sit at the hospital preparing to meet our son! More on this soon ‚ù§Ô∏è
Portrait of a prince / Kalahari @southafrica
Railroad tracks, illuminated as they cut through the twilight in #TolarGrande #Argentina. The sun had been down for nearly 45 minutes when I shot this but the landscape was still glowing, reflecting off the sky and exaggerated by the inordinate amount of dust kicked up by the wind. As we crossed the tracks I could faintly make out the scene, but through my camera and a long exposure it was a completely different sight. As a photographer you‚Äôre always chasing light and moments like this are always special and fleeting. I snapped off a handful of long exposures as the remaining light quickly faded out, leaving me with this picture to remember the evening.
One of the best parts of every shoot are the in between moments, the banter, the people you meet and the conditions you work in. This carousel of content here is a lot of behind the scenes from a recent shoot in Veracruz Mx on the Alsesca River I was DP on for @jaybirdsport and @camp4collective. It was a blast and an experience I‚Äôm sincerely grateful for, hope you enjoy this mini BTS look into the shoot! Big thank you to @isidrosoberanes for his bad ass paddling skills, director @timkemple second camera and drone op @tjtriage and photographer @angelajpayne üôèüèª #earthproof
Jeff Jackson racing dark clouds to summit the Crystal Tower before getting slammed with rain and hail. Throw back to some good rowdy times in the Rocky Mountains with @rockandicemag
In the flamingo world, vibrant pigment is a sign of health and nutrients. I photographed this stunning #flamingo here in South Africa, it‚Äôs beautiful pigment is directly correlated with a high keratin based diet, likely from shrimp.
Nature is the culmination of chaos and calm, within these transitions is where the best moments unfold. Fiery mammatus clouds over grassy fields in northern Oklahoma. Captured while #stormChasing with friends @nampix @krystlejwright @skiparmstrong @tobypike
I can‚Äôt get over the look on this #leopardSeal‚Äôs face. As cute and adorable as it appears, it‚Äôs actually sizing me up to see if I‚Äôm competition for food in anyway. This 10 foot long, curious seal had me swimming in circles to keep it from getting behind me and occasionally displayed its teeth to me and the 8 inch dome of my camera that was surely acting like a mirror of sorts. Once establishing that I was either too ambivalent or stupid to hunt, it playfully went on with its business. Shooting in the icy waters of Antarctica is no easy thing - your fingers and toes can only handle so much and your face swells up and feels like it‚Äôs full of Novacaine. A small price to pay for such an incredible experience like this. Photographed for @natgeo on an unforgettable assignment with @paulnicklen @mitty @andy_mann @sealegacy

"UNCONDITIONAL LOVE.

What does it mean to you?

I think many of us believe we love unconditionally, because ‚Äúunconditional‚Äù feels like the right word to describe the intensity we feel when we deeply love and care for someone.

But unconditional love is one of the most challenging things we human beings can master.

This doesn‚Äôt just start and end with intimate relationships - it‚Äôs apparent in friendships and parenting too.

We allow ourselves to expect a lot from one person. And a lot of the time, if those expectations aren‚Äôt met then we feel disappointment, annoyance, anger or frustration towards them.

To love unconditionally means there are no conditions and there are no expectations.

It means you accept them for who they are, both their shadow and their light.

It means you honour and respect their boundaries and triggers and consciously avoid causing them any pain.

It means you forgive their mistakes instead of holding it against them.

It means you hold space for them when they need it, even if it feels uncomfortable for you.

It means you consciously communicate with them, rather than the ol‚Äô blame and shame.

And it means every single day, you commit to your own self development and growth so that you can be the highest, healthiest and happiest version of yourself to benefit not only them, but every other person you connect with in your lifetime too.

Photography by @she.is.water"
"Babes! A while ago I asked you what values you look for in a partner and almost all of you said trust.

So I went on a little explore of trust - what it means and how we can get our hands on some of it.

If you want to hear more, have a listen to my latest podcast Cultivating Trust on itunes and spotify (search Temple of Her) and insight timer (search my name)

Love love x"
"To create real connection with another person, we have to allow ourselves to be seen. And we can‚Äôt truly be seen without first becoming vulnerable.

Yet we have attached so many negative connotations to vulnerability. We see it as a weakness and something to be ashamed of.

I encourage you to speak openly about your worries, fears and doubts. Speak about them whilst they are there, instead of once they are all packaged up and dealt with.

True vulnerability is speaking your truth amidst your pain and suffering.

There is no shame in carrying pain. It is a part of the human experience and none of us will escape this life without it. So let‚Äôs break open, embrace our vulnerability with open arms and share our challenges with one another.

There is a different kind of life and love you will experience by living whole heartedly through your vulnerability.

And by remaining open and honest, we can watch those intimate connections we have always dreamt of ~ come to life.

Photography by @sleepykiwis"

"I‚Äôve been living with an outdated narrative.

Valuing past experiences as too expensive.

Allowing them to define who I am.

By holding on to them, I am validating an old part of myself that no longer serves me.

I am not my thoughts.

I am not what happened to me.

I have evolved, grown and lived because of them, but they do not define me.

I am grateful for all the experiences I have been through, they have all been a vital part of my journey.

And because of them, I have been guided into a place where I have learnt to trust myself even more.

Where I have learnt that I am safe.

I am loved.

And I am whole. üïä

"For those interested in photography, I‚Äôve finally started to release the photography tutorial üì∏series that I worked on back in February! I‚Äôm going to be trickling them out on my IGTV üì∫channel on the ‚ÄúGet Camera Confident‚Äù series. I‚Äôve also just opened sales of my online photography course again in time for Christmas üéÖüèªüéÅ, and the link is up in my bio. üì±The first free tutorial video dropped this week, and you can catch it in my feed or on IGTV - it‚Äôs all about backlight! üåû For those that don‚Äôt know, shooting backlight is when you position your subject (person üíÅüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è, animal ü¶Å, subject üå¥) between the sun and your camera. It‚Äôs one of the more frustrating and challenging techniques to nail because the bright sun ‚òÄÔ∏è hitting your sensor is constantly confusing your light meter. So I‚Äôve talked about my tips for still nailing a beautifully exposed shot. Enjoy. üíõ #GetCameraConfident .
.

.

#BacklightPhotography #LearnPhotography #PortraitPhotography #PhotographyTutorial #Backlight #Sunset"
This year has been one of the most transformative and difficult years of my life, if not THE most transformative and difficult. I have said no to all but a handful of travel jobs (despite this being my main source of income since I left my old career üë©üèº‚Äçüç≥.) I ran my first tours to Zimbabwe amongst a huge amount of self doubt and fear, and with a lot of unnecessary stress playing a part on the side (Long story, I‚Äôll tell it one day!) I went off the pill despite spending my previous years on earth swearing I didn‚Äôt want children, and now I‚Äôm pregnant ü§∞üèº. I spent all of my money, and I did it intentionally to break a rigid and negative money mindset. (It was all invested back into my business and into personal development and upskilling.) I also; massively leveled up the Travel Bootcamp with the girls, co-released a new program into the world (Summer Camp üòçüèÑüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è - it‚Äôs a Bootcamp thang), lost a best friend (her choice) , opened my heart to more people than I thought possible ‚ù§Ô∏è, had deeper conversations with people than I‚Äôve ever had in my life, released stored emotion that manifested as back pain from my body, mended the relationship with my cousin, severed the relationship with my brother, improved my relationship with my partner in a million ways and lost my dad to cancer. And through it all I‚Äôve somehow lost my fear of change and learned a lot of lessons along the way. Namely: 1) We actually have nothing to fear - lean into that feeling and get comfortable being uncomfortable. There‚Äôs so much joy on the other side. 2) The human heart has a limitless ability to love and forgive. Let others really see you. Vulnerability is strength. 3) Sometimes people are not meant to be in your life. Don‚Äôt hold onto relationships that don‚Äôt serve you, but don‚Äôt give up too easily either 4) If we don‚Äôt change, nothing changes. Spend the time to get to know yourself. Slow down, stop the negative self talk, journal, create, tell yourself that you‚Äôre beautiful and kind and enough. Do it daily.  5) This world is what we make of it. ‚ÄúWe do not see things as they are, we see them as we are.‚Äù - Ana√Øs Nin. Beliefs are only thoughts and they can change.
"The Victoria Falls are alive, well and FLOWING! Yes, Zimbabwe is currently experiencing drought but no, the falls are far from drying up! (They‚Äôre even still getting the rainbow in the spray üåàüåà.) "Have you ever taken a photo that you can‚Äôt even believe is your own? üò± Like, I look at this and I like it so much that it doesn‚Äôt feel like I took it, no arrogance intended! üòÇ This was one of those rare instances where technical know-how meets total fluke moment in time. This place is in Tsumago, a post town on the Nakasendo route in Kiso Japan. ‚ù§Ô∏èüáØüáµ My guide Taka had told me that morning that he was bringing me to a museum that had great morning light and showed me a photo. I was like üëâüèªüò±üò±. He absolutely didn‚Äôt lie! This effect is the result of low, slat window blinds, smoke from a fire üî• and fall/winter months when the sun is low in the sky. üçÅ‚òÄÔ∏è I was across the other side of the room shooting on a zoom lens to nicely compress the scene and avoid distorted lines on the walls, ceilings and floor. Next minute someone was stoking the fire and I was there and ready. This light makes me drool! ü§§ü§§ü§§ #VisitKiso #KisoMe

"So, the shot I posted yesterday of the Torii Gates at the Nezu Shrine is actually the same location as this shot. In fact, the entrance to the gates are to the left of this image. ‚õ©‚ù§Ô∏èThis is the entrance to the shrine, and to our surprise when we arrived, there was a large group of locals gathering around and stretching. ü§∏üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüßòüèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è At 6:30 AM on the dot ‚è∞üìª the radio started to blare out a fun, upbeat exercise program in Japanese üáØüáµ and all of these people started to stretch and move in unison. üíÉüèΩüï∫üèΩ My biggest pleasure in Tokyo this time around was definitely having the time to explore at my own pace, and the opportunity to discover my own sites. üåè Tokyo is famous for its unique blend of tradition and innovation, and if you look carefully you can see this wherever you go. Within the grounds of the Nezu Shrine we could have been in Tokyo of a hundred years ago, but take one step onto the street and new Tokyo is everywhere. Such an intriguing juxtaposition, and one that I thoroughly enjoyed experiencing. üëòüç±üçú @tokyotokyooldmeetsnew #TokyoTokyo
.
.
.
.
.
#Tokyo #VisitJapanAu #JapanRevealed #VisitJapanJP #Japan #NezuShrine #ToriiGates #MyTokyoIs #Exercise #Juxtaposition"

"POSTERIOR CHAIN WORKOUT üòàüôåüèª@coachmarkcarroll took me through this earlier in the week. It‚Äôs a killer!
-
Make sure you all LIKE & SAVE üí• our workout! It‚Äôs supports my content & tells me what more you want to see!üôèüèº
-
WORKOUTüëáüèº
-
1Ô∏è‚É£DEFICIT DEADLIFT 4x 6. The deficit allows for greater range of motion. Given the starting position you are in more of a squat and the glutes have a greater stretch. This is a good variation especially for someone who struggles with the initial conventional deadlift leg drive. Really focus on pushing  the ground away and control when lowering the bar to the ground. 3 seconds!
-
2Ô∏è‚É£BB Hip Thrust 4 x 15. Following the deficit deadlift the focus is more directly on glutes with hip thrust. Here the focus is just on top range reps. Notice my reps are quite shallow. These for high reps HURT in a good way! PUMP THEM OUT!
-
3Ô∏è‚É£Lying Leg Curl 1 & 1/4 rep top 4 x 8. After working my posterior chain through hip extension its also important to work knee flexion which also works the hamstrings. Using a 1/4 rep method at the top for a double contraction method.
-
4Ô∏è‚É£Machine Abduction forward lean - 3 x 20. After working both hip extension and knee flexion, to fully work the glutes we also need some abduction work. I love high reps here. 3 sets 20 reps with only 45 seconds rest.
-
5Ô∏è‚É£Walking Lunges - large step glutes emphasis - 2 x 20 each leg. A walking lunge works both quads and glutes but the large step further emphasises the glutes! Body weight reps up and back across the gym. Focus on powerfully driving forward each rep!
-
Let us know if you give it a go! üëäüèº‚ô•Ô∏è
-
‚ö°Ô∏èOutfit: My LSXRW Turquoise set & lifting shoes.
Available now! Shop @ryderwear"

"Let‚Äôs talk BALANCE üôåüèª The longer I am in this industry the more I realise the key to long term results is BALANCE! When I first started I was extremely restrictive.
-
No bad foods. No carbs. No days off.
-
However I soon learnt the hard way, that a life that purely revolves around the gym and your body goals leads to a massive imbalance of priorities. Missing out on social event, missing out on birthdays and most of all missing out on foods that I sometimes craved. It also really impacted my health. üòî
.
Each year I devote to fitness and this ‚Äúlife‚Äù I have created through the gym, each year it gets much easier to maintain my body and lifestyle. With it all ultimately coming down to recognising the key is to have a BALANCE of goals in life. A balance between the gym and a social life. And most of all a balance between physical but also mental health! ‚ô•Ô∏è
-
Don‚Äôt be afraid girls of occasionally enjoying foods you enjoy. Yes you can go out and have your favourite dessert. üòçüòç You don‚Äôt have to forever chose ‚Äòchicken & broccoli‚Äô on menus.
-
Don‚Äôt be afraid girls of missing a gym session for a birthday or social event. It‚Äôs not going to derail your progress.
-
There is nothing better than smashing your goals both IN and OUTSIDE the gym. A balance approach leads to a sustainable result. üîëüíó"

"A Matter Of Focus. 
These two photos show nearly the exact same scene. However, the shift of focus turns them into two different pictures, each telling a unique story. I‚Äôve found that the same principle applies to my life, too. My story is not determined by the circumstances I face, but rather what things and thoughts I focus on in each scene. While auto focus works fine most of the time, some shots require a conscious switch to manual mode. [anzeige/ad] #ManWithAVision #ChopardAlpineEagle @chopard"
"Horse Power.
Horses used to be the ultimate utility vehicle - strong and reliable. But over the past 100 years, needs have grown and technology has evolved. Today, the power of a few hundred horses can be packed into a single car. But what makes a car a great off-road vehicle and useful tool? The answers are currently being built into the all new @ineos_grenadier. [anzeige / ad] Ineos is building the best-in-class off-roader and I‚Äôm privileged to be a part of it. Pictures like these ones from Russia were made possible thanks to a 4x4, therefore I‚Äôm super stoked that Ineos is building the Grenadier - uncompromising and efficient. 
#Grenadier4x4
Check out the link in my bio to learn more about the project!"

The European parliament has declared a global ‚Äúclimate and environmental emergency‚Äù ahead of the latest UN global crisis summit. 
The vote came as scientists warned that the world may have already crossed a series of climate tipping points. 
In a separate vote on Thursday, MEPs backed a resolution stating that current EU climate targets were ‚Äúnot in line‚Äù with the 2015 Paris climate agreement and backed a tougher target of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030. While this is an improvement on the current 40% target, environmental campaigners said the EU's declaration wasn't backed by sufficient action. 
The Brexit party voted against both climate resolutions. . . . . . .

"#Regram #RG @aljazeeraenglish: ‚ÄúThis is climate chaos - what it actually looks like.‚Äù - Tim Gore, Oxfam‚Äôs climate policy leader.‚Å†‚†Ä .‚Å†‚†Ä Oxfam has found that people were three times more likely to be displaced by cyclones, floods or fires than by conflicts.‚Å†‚†Ä .‚Å†‚†Ä Here are some facts that show how it's mostly poor nations that are paying the price for climate chaos:‚Å†‚†Ä .‚Å†‚†Ä 1. In Pakistan üáµüá∞, repeated droughts and cyclones between 1999 and 2012 resulted in the forced displacement of entire communities. | üì∏: Muhammed Muheisen, @apnews‚Å†‚†Ä .‚Å†‚†Ä 6. .‚Å†‚†Ä 7. Small island developing states such as Tuvalu üáπüáª face the highest risk of internal displacement as a result of extreme weather events | üì∏: Dave Hunt-Pool, @gettyimages‚Å†‚†Ä .‚Å†‚†Ä 8. "#Regram #RG @cnnclimate:
In the past decade, climate-fueled disasters have forced about 20 million people a year to leave their homes ‚Äî equivalent to one every two seconds ‚Äî according to a new report from Oxfam. People are seven times more likely to be displaced by floods, cyclones and wildfires than volcanic eruptions and earthquakes, and three times more likely than by conflict, according to the report released Monday. Oxfam, a nonprofit that is working to end poverty, is calling on world leaders to reduce emissions as fast as possible, and asking the international community to do more to fund recovery programs for poorer countries affected by the climate emergency. (üì∏: Barcroft Media/Getty)"
"#Regram #RG @wmo_omm: Levels of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere have reached a new record high. This continuing long-term trend means that future generations will be confronted with increasingly severe impacts of climate change, including rising temperatures, more extreme weather, water stress, sea level rise and disruption to marine and land ecosystems.

Today we released the Greenhouse Gas Bulletin which showed that globally averaged concentrations of carbon dioxide (CO2) reached 407.8 parts per million in 2018, up from 405.5 parts per million in 2017."
At this time of crisis for the Amazon, I support the people of Brazil working to save their natural and cultural heritage. They are an amazing, moving and humbling example of the commitment and passion needed to save the environment. The future of these irreplaceable ecosystems is at stake and I am proud to stand with the groups protecting them. While worthy of support, we did not fund the organizations targeted. I remain committed to supporting the Brazilian indigenous communities, local governments, scientists, educators and general public who are working tirelessly to secure the Amazon for the future of all Brazilians.
"#Regram #RG @cnnclimate:
The amount of land affected by an oil spill in North Dakota is almost 10 times larger than initially reported, officials say. TC Energy, the company that owns the Keystone 1 Pipeline, shut it down on October 29 after discovering more than 383,000 gallons of oil had leaked from the pipe into surrounding wetlands. Initial reports from TC Energy and and North Dakota‚Äôs Department of Environmental Quality estimated about 2,500 square yards of land were affected ‚Äî now they say it‚Äôs more than 23,000 square yards. (üì∏: Andrew Burton/Getty Images)"

One year to the day and the life support machinery jolting your body still claims a part of my mind. The memory boils. The pumps, hoses, and beeps were your perpetrators, the religious trauma and unescapable self attrition, robbing your body of its autonomy. My most primitive thoughts were to dive through the ICU window, beat the fuck out of the doctors and carry you on my back to safety. But we couldn‚Äôt run this time.
